story:
When I am not creating ecologically tuned, aesthetically aware and sustainable habitats for the UK's pollinators and championing the Bee Cause - I am spending time stravaiging the most spectacular landscapes imaginable. I am passionate about Scotland's nature and wildest lands and It is life-affirming keeping company with the rugged mountains and glens, sparkling lochans, Caledonian pine forests, peatlands and machair with its mosaic of wildflowers.

We have some of the most valuable ecosystems and habitats supporting Scotland’s diverse wildlife - the elusive Scottish wildcat, badgers, corncrakes, mountain hare, red squirrels, water voles, white-tailed sea eagle, mountain ringlet butterflies and the great yellow bumblebee. I fervently believe that a healthy natural environment and experiencing ‘wildness’ is vital to our wellbeing and we should strive to maintain its integrity. By supporting the vision of our leading conservation charities, we can safeguard, conserve and restore our wildlife and wild lands for the enjoyment of future generations.

"I only went out for a walk, and finally concluded to stay out until sundown, for going out, I found, was really going in" John Muir

In support of the Scottish Wildlife Trust and John Muir Trust, I plan to eschew the comforts of home for a year, immersing myself in the beauty and wonder of the most spectacular landscapes imaginable by stravaiging the length and breadth of Scotland and wild camping in the 42 wild land areas. By making the wild land areas my home for a year, I hope to enjoy 365 sunrises and sundowns, be absorbed in the song of water and birds, be with the mountains, elemental wildness, catch sight of some of Scotland's most amazing wildlife - from the largest to the craiturie and study the flora, habitats and ecosystems. My hope is to enthuse and inspire others to have greater involvement in, enjoy, learn and act for nature.

I am keen to visit many of the sites that are being managed, restored and rewilded for the benefit of wildlife and people. I plan to keep records in the form of a blog and field notes to enable donors to follow my progress throughout this expedition. I am keen also to share the beauty and wonder of our wild land areas.

“The idea of wilderness needs no defence, it only needs defenders.” Edward Abbey

( Unfortunately my sponsor pulled out at the last minute, hence the need to request the support of some philanthropic individuals)

http://uk.virginmoneygiving.com/CerysTrayner

story:
Who We Are

We are Syli Solaire, a group of students, entrepreneurs, innovators, environmentalists, and passionate people, who are trying to make a difference in our home country of Guinea, and in the world as a whole. Syli Solaire is a community, with an aim to improve the lives of our fellow Africans, and at the same time create a business that employs, inspires and educates young people in the far reaches of the country.


Why We're Doing This

With the exception of some neighborhoods in the capital city of Conakry, most of Guinea is without electricity. 

For light, families turn to kerosene lamps, candles, and open campfires.  These energy sources emit flames that often cause fires, and emit an acrid smoke that burns the eyes and irritates the throat.  Some studies liken the long-term damage caused by daily use of kerosene lamps to that of smoking two packs of cigarettes per day.  

Additionally, it’s expensive, and not sustainable.  

The majority of Guineans live on less than $2 per day through blue-collar employment, like farming, construction and mining.  For this reason, renewable energy sources like solar panels are financially out of reach to most Guineans.  Our goal is to make solar power accessible to ALL Guinean households, not just to the country’s top earners.

The Solution

When families replace kerosene and candles with solar lights, they experience twice the available hours for studying, cooking, reading and working, as well as significantly better air quality.   The chance of a house fire decreases exponentially and families are left with cleaner, brighter light in which they can work and play together in safety. 

We aim to make solar panels available to everyone at a cost that is comparable with what the average family spends on fire-based light sources each week.  We understand that a solar panel comes at a much greater cost than kerosene, candles or wood.  

But what if a family could lease the technology? 

Instead of paying $2 per week at the market for fuel and equipment, what if they invested that into a solar panel that they could lease to own, over the course of a year or even less, depending on that family’s abilities?  Not only would that family have safer, cleaner energy, but in time, their energy costs will reduce to zero, as a result of owning the device.  

We need your help to launch a company which distributes panels, paid for over an agreed length of time, thus improving rural lives at an affordable cost.

Each participating family will receive a Solar Panel Kit, which comes with everything need to provide basic lighting, as well as phone charging.


If we are successful in developing this first project, we can make additional plans in our country and in other countries that have similar conditions, so we can multiply the benefits.  GLOBAL WARMING HAS NO BORDERS; we will all benefit equally.  

Why We Need Your Help

For Syli Solaire in to happen in Guinea, we are looking for $30,000, which is what is needed for an initial shipment of materials and to establish the adminstration necessary to support the growth of the company.  We have come to IndieGoGo with the hopes of involving our friends, family and the public in the venture.  

Everyone should have access to clean light and we are proud to say that we believe in you, and your ability to help us make this dream a reality.  

We all dream of making a difference in this world.  That’s why we’re asking you, our community, to help us reach our full potential. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute and that’s OK, but we equally appreciate any efforts you can make to help us by reaching out to your own circle of friends and family – by phone, emails and social media.
 

Tell everyone about us, get the word out, and make some noise about our campaign! 

Thank You!

Thank you so much for supporting this project! With your help, we can stop climate change by saving communities, and create a healthier world. By supporting, you make a statement about what you believe in, and what is important to you.

story:
BRIEF SUMMARY

Are you ready to rethink the way our society deals with plastics - a material made forever, yet we use it only for minutes in over 40% of cases. With the Traveling Trash Tour, we want to explore ways to change this plastic paradox and counter the current exponential growth in global plastic production. We'll cycle 1500km through France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Germany with a giant plastic waste sculpture and hold dozens of events with local changemakers that show how the circular economy, smart recycling, waste reduction strategies and plastic alternatives can help us save the planet and our own health before it's too late. In order to do this, we need your help to cover our expenses and maximize our outreach! 

 

WHY WOULD WE DO SOMETHING THIS CRAZY?

We currently produce roughly as much plastic per year as the entirety of humanity weights - around 300 billion metric tons - and as of now, 9% of that amount is recycled, 12% incinerated and the rest ends up in landfill or the natural environment. Almost half of our plastic production is for single-use products and packaging, used just once and then discarded - but plastic is made to last forever and almost every item made still exists in one or another form. By now, microplastics are already entering our bodies through the food, water and air we breathe, they are present in virtually every part of the natural world - and yet our production is growing at exponential pace and society is becoming more disposable every year. This is what I call the plastic paradox - and it’s the reason why the Traveling Trash Tour was born: To rethink plastics in Europe!

 

THREE BIG GOALS

  1. We want to reach 1 million people - online and offline - and make them reconsider their daily use of plastic. 
  2. We provide a forum of exchange for everyone actively changing European plastic production, consumption and circulation.
  3. We create a lasting portfolio of initiatives, companies and trash heroes that can become your go-to source of inspiration and best practice in the transition to the circular economy and a low-waste society.

 

HOW CAN YOU TAKE PART? 

The Traveling Trash Tour was created to be as open as possible: Come and cycle with us for as long as you want and join our events in your city! We’d love to see you there to learn, engage and get active for a more circular economy in Europe and a better future of plastics! And of course, we will let you take part digitally with videos, stories, livestreams, articles and more, don't you worry. Come on and become a trash hero by contributing to our campaign and sharing our story with your friends! 

If you have an initiative of your own, work for a circular company or are part of a citizen movement reshaping plastics and would like to collaborate with us, or would like to talk on the press/media about this, please get in touch!

 

WHERE WILL WE GO?

Have a look, this is our route:

 

WHAT DO WE NEED YOUR MONEY FOR? 

As the founder, I have so far invested incredibly much time and personal savings to prepare the tour and make it a reality - but now we need your help to realise the tour and cover expenses on the road! As we want to be as transparent as possible with you, here’s a rough budget:

1300€ for bike and equipment (like lights, bags, camping stuff and more - you can donate this in kind, or lend it, too!)

500€ for tech equipment (we want to keep you permanently up to date through stories, photos, videos and more!) 

1200€ For 60 days of food (think about it: 58 days of tour + 1 pre and 1 after; no real possibility for cooking, so calculating 20€ per day)

100€ for transport to the starting point and back home to Munich (car sharing or busses, no flights of course!)

300€ for emergency accommodation when there is no friend, friendly host, warm shower or couch-surfing available 

350€ for bike repairs, flat tires, or other unforeseen breakdowns (you know these are inevitable!)

350€ for printing material like flyers, event banners, stickers etc. (this is for our events and to spread the word and make this campaign as big as possible - everything printed sustainably of course!)

500€ for machines and material to build the plastic elephant & trailer (let’s make sure this statue survives rainy weather, bumpy roads and windy days)

400€ approx. fees for transactions and the crowdfunding platform (5% for the platform + 3% transaction fees + 30 additional cents per transaction, you can find this in the guidelines)

Yes, you counted correctly: this makes 5000€ of total budget for our two month journey!

 

WHO IS BEHIND THIS? 

The Traveling Trash Tour is an initiative by Clara Bütow, I am the founder of Impact Revolution and the Traveling Trash Tour and the one speaking to you in the video. But I’m not alone - there is a whole team of awesome volunteers that bring forward the traveling trash mission! Elisa is our head of PR and press releases, Clara Sophia does logistics and accommodation and helped create this awesome video together with our social media genius Jasmina and our creative head and event planner Olivia. Gilles, Janneke, Olivia and Noemie help to set up our local events so all of you can come, learn and engage. Our designer Sergio has worked the beautiful logo and layout; and Allan and Diego, who have both toured thousands of km by bike already, provide professional advice and connect us to the bikers' community in Europe. Although Diego and I will (so far) be the only ones cycling the whole way, you’ll be able to meet more of our team members along the way as they join for parts of the tour.

 

WHAT IS OUR SCHEDULE? 

Here you have the final schedule for both biking and events. All details for local events will be uploaded on our facebook page as the dates get closer. 

 

WHERE CAN YOU LEARN MORE? 

There really are pleeeenty of options to get in touch!

Visit our website: www.impactrevolution.eu/ttt

Follow us on Facebook : https://www.facebook.com/theimpactrevolution/

Join the Traveling Trash Tour Group : https://www.facebook.com/groups/travelingtrashtour

Find us on Instagram : https://instagram.com/impact_revolution/

Listen to our Podcast Impact Revolution on Spotify or on iTunes .

And feel free to write us a message on social media or through this campaign!

 

THANK YOU FOR ENABLING US TO MAKE THIS HAPPEN!

story:
The Soil Not Oil Coalition

  • The Biosafety Alliance/Soil Not Oil Coalition has been organizing annual conferences and launching campaigns of great social impact for over 10 years. 
  • This year, San Francisco is hosting the Global Climate Action Summit, a gathering of global leaders and corporations discussing ways to profit from advanced technological climate change "solutions." There will be thousands of policy makers, scientists, farmers and environmental activists participating in the summit and in counter-actions. This is the perfect opportunity host the Soil Not Oil conference in the city where we live and organize, to promote applicable and practical solutions to climate change.

We need to raise $20K to cover costs.

  • The rents in San Francisco are very high. We have reserved several spaces including the Grey Area/Grand Theater and the Women's Building, and are working on securing a kitchen.
  • We need funds for promotion and travel expenses. Basically, we will need your help to make the conference happen. 
  • Speakers donate their time to participate in this conference and for this we are very grateful.
  • Every year, many tickets are distributed to volunteers and people of color and low-income people at no-cost, your donations make this possible.
  • As in previous years, we are planning to serve free, healthy, non-gmo meals and snacks to all attendees.
  • Even if we don't reach the $20K, all funds raised will still go directly to the project and every contribution will encourage other individuals to help sponsor the conference.

The Impact

We are expecting to host this year the largest ever Soil Not Oil International Conference.

  • This year the Soil Not Oil Conference will take place September 9-11, 2018 and will showcase agro-ecological practices—regenerative agriculture, no-till/bio-intensive farming, permaculture solutions.  We will feature community powered solutions that people in the global south have creatively implemented to adapt and prevent the ecological and social impacts of climate change.
  • People from around the world have attended the conferences, and gone on to implement what they learned in their communities. Many connections have been forged and steps taken for a better future for us all. 
  • Past conferences have featured international scientists, farmers, elected officials and environmental activists including: Dr. Vandana Shiva, Dr. Rattan Lal, Andrew Kimbrell, Wenonah Hauter, Miguel Altieri, David Zuckerman, Adelita San Vicente Tello, Wenonah LaDuke, Starhawk, John Jeavons, Tim LaSalle, Penny Livingston, Paul and Elizabeth Kaiser, and hundreds more.
  • The conference encourages local investing to grow our community capacities and enable local development. We highlight the traditional knowledge of indigenous people and we honor the borderless collaboration among organizations led by women, caretakers of the land, elderly, youth and others, who are rarely appropriately represented. This year our goal is to provide a platform in which the voiceless can speak on behalf of their communities in live-streamed presentations.
  • Presentations will be recorded and available online to further spread this critical information, many with Spanish translation. 
  • We make this conference accessible to all ages, socioeconomic classes, genders, ethnicities through diverse speakers, reasonable ticket prices and discounted tickets. 

Risks & Challenges

As we are always focused on networking with people involved with very diverse issues and highlighting the connections among these issues to build a strong inclusive movement, we face the risk of missing the momentum to achieve our goals if we don't raise enough money.

  • We rely on hundreds of volunteers that in the past have helped in different tasks, and also in dozens of community businesses that every year help donating food, materials and sharing logistics elements to make the conference happen.
  • We are continuously exploring different ways of collaboration with old and new friends and allies, and our partners honor the importance of our work.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can't help with funds?

  • Please help us and share this campaign with 10 folks in your networks that care about the planet and believe in community powered solutions to climate change.
  • Remind them that they and their children will be the beneficiaries of our work!
  • Volunteer! We need help with outreach, flyering, kitchen crew, and more.

story:
Help us fight climate change!

We have 2 days left and have $200 left to raise! YOU could be the one to help put us closer to meeting our goal. Please support us and become a part of the journey!
If you'd like to speak with us directly right now about making your personal gift, and the impact your gift will have, call 408 924-1187 or email Kelly at kelly@greenninja.org.
We have a little message for all our fabulous supporters so far. We could not have done it without you!

The Green Ninja Project is excited to be a part of this years California Climate Ride as a team and beneficiary.  The California Climate Ride is a 320-mile cycling charity tour that begins in Eureka and ends in San Francisco with an overall goal of raising awareness about climate change and supporting environmental non-profit organizations. 

The Green Ninja Project is a non profit organization that aims to inspire youth to take action on climate change and provide the tools to do something about it.  Be a green ninja and help us pedal to fight climate change!

Help support these four working women. Balancing school, work, and training is tough stuff. Your donation will help us meet our $2800 per rider funding to participate. Half of the funds we raise go back to support the Green Ninja Project.

Your Impact

The Green Ninja Project is an educational initiative created to inform the upcoming generation on climate change and inspire them to take action. Collaboration between students of various departments on campus make it happen. The Green Ninja Project provides job opportunities for SJSU students like us to gain professional experience. If you make a leadership gift level of $500 or more you will be having an incredibly important impact in helping us take on this 320 mile cycling challenge. We cannot do this without achieving the fundraising goal, and know that  you can claim pride of the accomplishment in helping us reach the finish line.

Meet the women you'll support

Kelly Chang: The fearless captain of the Green Ninja team…..Kelly is the outreach and partnerships coordinator for the Green Ninja Project. She's passionate about getting active, being outside and protecting the environment. The Climate Ride was her way of connecting her friends and family with the outdoors in hopes that they will develop the same appreciation for the environment as she has. 

Huong Cheng: A student who just learned to ride a bike at the age of 24…Huong is the creative designer of the Green Ninja Project and a SJSU animation student. Huong joined the climate ride because she wants people to support the Green Ninja Project to educate youth about climate change, but she also hopes to inspire friends and family to take on challenges in life with a can-do attitude.

Ramya Shenoy: A masters student who rode her bike 11 years ago….The last time Ramya rode a bicycle was 11 years ago to pick up groceries for her parents in India. Even with having asthma, she wants to ride 320 miles-pretty incredible! As a female software engineer student at SJSU she hopes to inspire other women to take on the tech world without fear, like a WARRIOR!
Gaby de la Cruz: A student biking to inspire future generations…Gaby is an SJSU meteorology student, so she gets it-climate change is a major challenge and it's at the heart of her studies. She joined our team because she said she needed to be more FEARLESS. She's also a rad climber in case you wanted to know. 

Get the word out!

If donating to our campaign is too much, help us get the word out. Share our campaign on all your social media channels, talk about it with your family and friends or shout it out to the world. We appreciate the exposure just as much! Be sure to take advantage of Indiegogo's share tools!

story:
Summary of GEC Organics Corp.

GEC Organics Corp. was formed in late 2011. We are located on a 70 acre site in Castleberry, population 625, in Southern Alabama.  Although we operate in a small farming community, our products and their impact on agriculture and environmental remediation have  world wide implications. 

Our Campaign is designed to raise the needed capital to expand our business and deliver the message of sustainable practices in farming and the promotion of healthy soil in all countries.  The Indiegogo campaign will give us the opportunity to deliver our message globally and make sure we continue on the road to a safe environment for generations to follow.

Your contributions will allow us to achieve maximum results and reach our goals in ways that we would never have imagined and will not be possible without your help.  Your assistance  will allow us to employ the needed sales agents who will market our soil amendment and demonstrate the benefits of our products to the agricultural community. We will also be able to purchase more raw material to increase our production and acquire additional heavy equipment to expand and grow.  Our message of a robust, sustainable agricultural system starts with "good soil".  Soil feeds and aerates the plants; it's not just dirt!

 
What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking initial funding of $250,000 which will give us the much needed money to maintain our facility and continue to reach out to farmers, nurseries, turf producers, farm co-ops and retail outlets who will use our all-natural soil amendment.  We call our product;  O.N.E™ ; "Organic New Earth".  It is our hope that this Campaign will continue to grow beyond our initial funding goal and give us the opportunity reach out to agricultural communities in many countries.   

Our USDA approved, odorless compost is made from chicken manure and green waste as well as food waste.  We eliminate the need for the agricultural industry to rely on synthetic fertilizer and harmful pesticides.  However, what separates us from other organic compost producers is our ability to generate Greenhouse Gas ("GHG") Emission Reduction Credits;  known as Carbon Credits. 

Every time we convert a ton of waste to our nutritious organic soil amendment; O.N.E.™, we remove many tons of GHG Emissions from the atmosphere. 

The funds you provide will increase the volume of this activity and allow us to save our precious farmland.  In the process, we eliminate millions of tons GHG Emissions from the environment.  This process has given us the chance to offer a unique perk for your help.  We are seeking contributions beginning with our 1st Tier Perk of $50.00 and higher multiples of all of our Perks are welcomed. 

 * For each 1st Tier contribution of $50.00, 10 Carbon Credits will be awarded. 

* In the 2nd Tier, this increases to 22 Carbon Credits for our $100 Contributor. 

* The 3rd Tier Perk will offer 60 Carbon Credits for a $250.00 Contribution.

These Carbon Credit Certificates are valuable because they can be held for the future or sold on a number of Carbon Credit Exchanges in many countries or directly through the GEC Organics network of buyers.  Although we cannot guarantee the selling price of these Certificates, sales have ranged from $5.00 to $10.00 per credit with the market price predicted to rise over time. 

This is a unique Perk as it will repay your contribution and hopefully create a profit for you in the future.  We will assist you when you wish to sell these Credits through our own network of buyers or with qualified Carbon Brokers worldwide. These Carbon Credits will be issued to us by two of the most  highly regarded, non-profit Carbon Credit Registries;

(1) Gold Standard Foundation, Geneva, Switzerland; www.goldstandard.org and

(2) Climate Action Reserve, Los Angeles, California; www.climateactionreserve.org. 

Starting in the 1st Quarter of 2016 we will hold specific Carbon Credits in your name or electronically distribute these Carbon Credit Certificates to you as they are issued to us.  Each Contributor will be entitled to his or her Credits according to the date of their Contribution.  We will also pay a fee to both non-profit registries each time they issue a credit to us.  This will assist them in their good work as they endeavor to stop the practices which are negatively impacting our environment.

The next level of Contributors will be given our soil amendment, O.N.E™, as a Perk for those who are able to use this all-natural substitute for synthetic fertilizer.  O.N.E™ can be used around your home, garden or farm in any agricultural application.  If you are too far from our site to pick-up this product, we will donate it to a local or regional non-profit organization in your name.  Schools, parks, Little League fields, religious organizations, Universities and so many more would welcome the chance to use this all-natural material.  A tax deduction will be given to you for this Perk.

Finally, our highest level of Contributor at $500 will be given a combination of both of our Perks.  For individuals and companies seeking a larger contribution, we will combine 20 yards of O.N.E™ available at our site and we will also send you 100 Carbon Credits which can be re-sold at a number of Carbon Exchanges worldwide.  As with our other soil amendment Perk, we recognize that many Contributors may live too far from our location to take advantage of receiving our Compost. We can donate the 20 yards of O.N.E™ to a local charity for their use and provide you with a tax deduction for this portion of the Perk.  

All levels of Contributions can be contributed in multiples and additional Perks will be given accordingly. We also welcome our Environmental Contribution of $10.00 (see Perks) as an acknowledgement of your support of healthy soil and the removal of GHG emissions. 

 
The Impact

Your contribution will have a very positive impact on our Project.  Our mission is to change the practice of modern day agriculture and to eliminate the problems caused by the overuse of synthetic fertilizers and pesticides. Please remember that soil is ALIVE and needs to be nourished!  Our O.N.E™ will grow plants on "bad earth" so that more food can be produced by our farmers.  We will eliminate the need for  the land to lay fallow so that it can recover from the overuse of synthetic fertilizers which is today's practice. 

Your contribution will help us achieve worldwide coverage and get our message out to the agricultural industry about our Planet's need for good soil. 

 

Risks & Challenges

We have researched the market and the need to protect our food supply.  It has taken 4 years to develop our products, O.N.E™ (in solid and liquid form) for healthy soil and the removal of Greenhouse Gas Emissions generated from the disposal of waste.  We believe we have overcome the resistance of farmers and the agricultural industry by proving  successful crop yields using our O.N.E™.   

The reduced need for landfill sites alone has helped us overcome much of the resistance to change by the big agricultural conglomerates!  Food waste deposited in landfills produces more harmful emission of Methane Gas than any other waste material.  Nevertheless, there are always risks but the Organic Movement is here and there are no longer all the challenges we experienced in the past.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable at this time to contribute, please help us get the word out.  We are embarking on a Soil Revolution and we need all the help we can get.  Our team at  GEC Organics is attempting to do its part to sequester the harmful gases that create Global Warming while at the same time rebuilding the Earth's soil for a healthy sustainable environment.  Please tell your friends about us while we follow the advice of so many world leaders!  Thank you very much.

story:
Welcome!

Do you care about Wildlife and want to protect Elephants, Wolves, Lions, Rhinos, Frogs, Butterflies, Birds, Bees, and all the great and small species that inhabit this world.

Do you care about the Environment and want to breathe Clean Air, drink clean Water, swim in Clean Oceans and hike in what’s left of our pristine Forests?

Do you want to do something about Climate Change, Biodiversity Loss, and prevent the CURRENT extinction of flora, fauna and animals?

I do too and that is why I was inspired to make this film. To raise awareness about the origins and causes of biodiversity loss, and what we can do to reverse the destructive trends we currently practice around the world. It is not too late, but we must act now. If you also care, then consider helping me spread the message. 

The purpose of this Indiegogo campaign is to raise funds to purchase the video footage used in Heaven's Falling. This project has been 13 years in the making. I first wrote the song Heaven's Falling when I lived in China in 2002 and witnessed, firsthand, the horrible effects of deforestation. I officially recorded the song in 2013 and have been working on the video ever since. In addition to writing and performing the soundtrack song, I also handpicked the footage from Pond5 (an online marketplace for stock footage and photos) and edited the film that you are about to see.

I am seeking financial support for this campaign so I can publish the video and get the message out there, but I NEED YOUR HELP TO DO IT.  My hope for this video is that it reaches people around the world (through film festivals and the internet) and inspires those who see it to do more. To take action. To change how they interact with this world. It starts with them seeing what we have to lose through this video. There is so much natural beauty on this earth, but we take it for granted. It will be too late before we notice it’s gone. WE NEED BIODIVERSITY in order to survive.  My next target is the Global Climate Sumit happening in Paris, in November of this year.  If I can complete the film in time, then I will personally email it to every leader representing each country that plans on attending the summit.  Perhaps it will help to remind them of the job they need to do in order to protect the world from Climate change.

I also wanted to stand behind an organization that was working on improving the environment and was inspired to produce Heaven's Falling for an organization called Voices for Biodiversity (V4B) as a “citizen Eco-reporter.” Voices for Biodiversity is 100 percent volunteer run, and operates as an online platform to give a voice to people who care about biodiversity, the environment, and the creatures that inhabit this world WITH US. This video is my contribution to V4B’s cause and mission.

We need to get the word out that there. There is no time to lose. It will take a lot of work if we are going to save this planet and ourselves, but it starts with YOU. Start now. Consider contributing towards the purchase of the video footage that you see so that the film can be shared. Together we can spread the message and TAKE ACTION!

What Is Needed & What You Get

The cost for the footage is $3000. Please view the GALLERY tab in order to see how much each shot costs; there are 52 shots in total. If you contribute to the film, not only will you receive MY ETERNAL GRATITUDE but for $50 you will receive a DIGITAL COPY of the song HEAVEN'S FALLING.  If you contribute $100 you will receive a DIGITAL COPY of the SONG as well as an EXECUTIVE PRODUCER CREDIT at the end of the film, which automatically ADDS YOUR VOICE, showing that you also care about what is happening and that you want to do something about it. 

For the fundraising campaign: if I don't reach my goal, the funds that are raised will still go towards whatever footage I can purchase. Then if I need to, I plan on having a viewing/fundraising party in the Fall to finish it off. If you contribute to the film through Indiegogo, you of course are invited to the viewing party as well!

The Impact

In 2012 I successfully fundraised funds to finish my full-length feature documentary film Broken Hearts & Butterflies (on Vimeo). That film touches hearts in ways that I cannot even comprehend. I know that HEAVEN'S FALLING will have a similar impact. It is a message that needs to be heard and be seen. I cannot emphasize enough how valuable your contribution will be in supporting this passion and project of mine and how important it is for me to finish it. There are some days that are better than others, but nothing will stop me from getting it done, even if I have to purchase one shot a month myself for 52 months!  I will do it!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to financially support this particular film, you can still help out by spreading the word about this Indiegogo campaign.  Post it on your social network sites like Facebook and Twitter. Explain to people why you care about this issue. At the end of the film, there is a list of things that we can all do (big and small) to make a difference. How many of those things do you currently do? I am always evaluating how my daily living habits affect the planet, big and small - what I buy, what I put down the drain, what I eat. I hope that you do the same. Thanks for taking time out of your day to read this, and I hope to hear from you in one way or another about what you think. Thanks again for your support.

Sincerely,

Kimberley Rose

story:
Hi! We’re Gemma and Swati and we founded the 2041 Antarctic Youth Ambassador Programme (AYAP).  We’re taking 30 young people to the frozen continent in February-March 2013 to inspire and engage them in the protection of the Antarctic and the larger battle against climate change.

This is our story.

Gemma’s feet are aching as she writes this because she has just returned from a three week walk in the desert in South Australia, walking to show the Australian government that a community once controlled by coal is ready to build Australia’s first solar power plant. For the last three years she has been leading grassroots climate campaigns and youth education programmes in Australia with the Australian Youth Climate Coalition as their fundraising director and campaigner.

Swati’s lifelong dream is to see an orca. As the Assistant Editor of Sanctuary Asia, a wildlife magazine in India, she has been working on conservation issues for the last four years. She has helped organise national and international youth summits on climate change and is passionate about working with young people to involve them in environmental issues.

Our friendship started when we met aboard the 2011 International Antarctic Expedition with polar explorer Robert Swan and his organisation 2041.

Being in Antarctica is incredibly moving. We saw, firsthand, the impacts of climate change on the uninhabited continent and realised that we needed more young people to have the same experience. Antarctica contains 70 per cent of the world’s fresh water and 90 per cent of the world’s ice. Protecting the continent is vital to the water security of the world. In an era of climate change, unprecedented glacial melt in the Antarctic will cause a considerable rise in sea levels worldwide.
 The continent has no people so it needs to be represented by the generation which stands to lose the most from the impacts of climate change.  

About our programme

Recognising the need to focus on local sustainability issues, we designed the 2041 Antarctic Youth Ambassador Programme – a comprehensive climate leadership[ training that will enable our participants to initiate on ground projects when they return. We spoke with 2041 and they loved our idea and agreed to let us pilot the program in February-March 2013. 

About 2041 and Robert Swan

Swan is the first person to walk to both the North and the South Pole. He set up 2041, an organisation committed to educating people about the importance of Antarctica.

In 1996 Robert Swan took 35 young people to Antarctica to educate them on the Antarctica and to clean up an old site at Bellingshausen which you can read about here - http://www.esaa.org/files/ESAAAntarcticaSiteReport.pdf

In 2008, he set up the first renewable energy education base in the world on Bellingshausen Island in Antarctica. Run entirely on renewable energy, in the coldest, windiest, driest continent on earth, the e-base is a powerful symbol of what we can achieve if we are committed to a clean energy future.  If it can be done in Antarctica, it can be done anywhere. 

How we will use your contribution

By contributing to this program you will allow us to bring more young people to the Antarctic to join our programme. The cost is massive – 20,000 USD per person not counting their airfare and equipment costs. We’ve been working really hard to find sponsors but we need your help. We’re taking young people from some of the most vulnerable countries in the world – Iraq, Somalia, South Africa, Nepal, Sri Lanka and Bangladesh – these kids stand to lose the most to climate change and we want to empower them to fight this threat.

You can help us change their lives

Imagine studying by the light of a candle, walking for hours to get water or scrounging for food for your family. This is the reality of young people in developing countries – a situation that will be exacerbated by climate change. This is a reality we are not willing to accept.

If Antarctica is opened up to drilling and mining, the sea level rise from the ice melt will be unprecedented and countries around the world will be submerged.  The need to empower young people to both address local sustainability issues and to lobby for the protection of the Antarctic is immense. This is what we are going to do on AYAP 2013.

The programme we have planned is rigorous and is focussed on equipping our participants with the tools they need to fight for the environment when they return home. We’re working with each of them individually, to develop a project that will benefit their community, city, town or village. They will also be starting an international campaign around the year 2041 to bring the issue global attention. 

Even a contribution of a few dollars will help us achieve this and will help transform the lives of some fantastic young people who are very passionate about creating change.

The figures

Our participants will be flying from their hometown to Ushuaia, Argentina on February 28, 2013. We will be there for three days and then we will board a ship to Antarctica. The cost for the ship and their stay in Argentina is 20,000 USD.

It usually costs 22,000 per person but since we are taking young people from around the world, Robert Swan is personally raising 2,000 per participant, making the final cost 20,000 per participant, because he strongly believes they deserve the opportunity and that in inspiring them, we will be able to influence a wider community.  They also need to raise money for their airfare and equipment costs. 

Any money you donate will go towards a corpus for AYAP. We will be tracking our participant’s fundraising efforts and will allocate the money towards those who need it the most. We will tell you exactly what it has gone towards. 

If we don’t get all the funds we need we will use the money to do the best we can with what we have. But being able to give more incredible young people the chance to have an even more meaningful experience is what we really want.

Join the movement

We’re building an environmentally friendly time e-capsule filled with e-messages, videos and photographs from you and incorporating it into the 2041 e-base in Antarctica. Then in the year 2041 it will be removed and we will take these messages to the United Nations.

For your message to be included in the time capsule, please email your message and a copy of your IndieGoGo receipt to gemma@2041.com

For 10 USD, you can add a short message, and for a larger contribution, you can pledge your company’s support to the initiative or record a message for governments. Check out the perks on the side to know more!

story:
MARIN COUNTY DOG believes every dog deserves a place to run and play. 

Help us spread the word about the GGNRA's restrictive dog management plan. Dogs are banned from 99-percent of the federal lands that surround us. All we're asking is to leave our 1-percent alone. For Marinites, hiking trails and playing at Muir Beach with our dogs is woven into the fabric of our lives. Let's not let Washington DC take that away. 

What you can do: We need some help to pay for community outreach which includes:

  • An online advertising campaign
  • Printed materials for our volunteers to hand out on trails and beaches

We need your help so we can keep working our tails off. Please donate today.

Please share our website www.marincountydog.org with everyone you know and like us on Facebook.

story:
THE RAINFOREST WAS MY FAMILY'S HOME

  • My name is Bella Carriker and I am a junior in high school at Lakeside School in Seattle, Washington.
  • My goal is to raise money in order to protect the environment where my great grandfather Melbourne Carriker (an ornithologist and naturalist) lived and studied birds for over 50 years, because the area is being deforested and many of the birds he discovered are now becoming extinct.  
  • The land is currently being managed by a Colombian not-for-profit organization called ProAves  (www.proaves.org), which is working to preserve as much of the mountaintop as possible. By helping me raise money to support ProAves, you are protecting land that is not only important to the environment but meaningful to my family and has historical heritage for many naturalists. The biodiversity of the region is extraordinary, but the wildlife is vulnerable and needs our help in order to survive. 

HOW TO MAKE A DIFFERENCE

  • It only costs $100/acre to preserve this land and make it belong to the ProAves wildlife reserve.
  • My goal is to protect a minimum of 5 acres, or $500 worth of land.
  • No matter how much money is raised through this campaign, 100% of it will go to ProAves and will solely be used to purchase and protect this area. 
  • Please donate any sum, large or small, to help the rainforest and preserve the environment for future generations. 

REASONS TO CONTRIBUTE

  • The region is internationally recognized by over 60 conservation organizations worldwide through the Alliance for Zero Extinction, and is designated as a Biosphere Reserve in Colombia by Unesco.
  • Only 1/8 of the area is currently under protection by ProAves, but you can prevent future loss of wildlife by giving to the cause so that eventually, the other 7/8 are also protected!
  • Colombia has 1,870 different bird species alone, more than anywhere else on earth. In an area of Colombia eight times smaller than the USA, 1/5 of all birds species in the world can be found. You can preserve this extraordinary biodiversity through your contributions. 

 

OTHER WAYS TO HELP

  • Besides contributing, please remember that you can help by simply spreading the word through your website, facebook, or even through emailing friends and family about this campaign.

The biodiversity of the region is extraordinary, but the wildlife is vulnerable and needs our help in order to survive. 



HOW TO MAKE A DIFFERENCE

It only costs $100/acre to preserve this land and make it belong to the ProAves wildlife reserve.
My goal is to protect a minimum of 5 acres, or $500 worth of land.
No matter how much money is raised through this campaign, 100% of it will go to ProAves and will solely be used to purchase and protect this area. 
Please donate any sum, large or small, to help the rainforest and preserve the environment for future generations. 


REASONS TO CONTRIBUTE

The region is internationally recognized by over 60 conservation organizations worldwide through the Alliance for Zero Extinction, and is designated as a Biosphere Reserve in Colombia by Unesco.
Only 1/8 of the area is currently under protection by ProAves, but you can prevent future loss of wildlife by giving to the cause so that eventually, the other 7/8 are also protected!
Colombia has 1,870 different bird species alone, more than anywhere else on earth. In an area of Colombia eight times smaller than the USA, 1/5 of all birds species in the world can be found. You can preserve this extraordinary biodiversity through your contributions. 

 
OTHER WAYS TO HELP
Besides contributing, please remember that you can help by simply spreading the word through your website, facebook, or even through emailing friends and family about this campaign.

story:
Our Story

 

MyFreshLocal.com wants to help bring down the costs of the healthiest freshest food so more people can afford it and it's easier to find and buy.

We will help make connections between consumers…and local farms, and farmers’ markets, and restaurants, and artisan bakers, and local recipes, and gardeners, and organic cookbooks, and soupmakers, and food co-ops, and CSAs, and so much more.

 

 

The Impact

 

Our current food system uses a ton of toxic chemicals, antibiotics, genetically engineered crops and fossil fuels. This way of growing food and distributing it is undermining public health, destroying the environment and increasing the costs of food for families.

 

When you spend one dollar at a big supermarket for food that’s grown far away, 80 cents of that dollar leaves your area. That money goes to industrial agriculture, to corporate executives and to oil companies for transportation fuel. The farmer who grew the food might keep 10 to 15 cents of the dollar.

 

If your dinner has eight ingredients from eight different areas, that food may have traveled thousands of miles, burning oil moving from where it was grown to where you eat it.

 

But when you spend one dollar at a farmers’ market or a locally-sourced restaurant, the money stays in your community. 

 

 

Local food connects us, it builds local economies and it improves our health. But it is currently too expensive and inconvenient, because large food companies control the food system driving small businesses out.

 

But with your help we are going to help change that!!!

 

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

We need to rebuild the site with new technology that allows us to do a lot more stuff automatically instead of trying to manage it manually with 1 unpaid staff.

We need better tools so we can focus on building the audience and letting the community grow organically!

We love the local movement! - we work really hard on the site and we give back to the sustainable food economy through advertising for farmers markets and by creating marketing resources to help food producers find buyers. Access to the site is free.

All the money we receive from our fundraising will pay for the upgrades to the site. We need to expand the database to include different types of producers like artisans and local grocers, we need to add tools for users to get the information they want easily and for us to grow the audience.

So by helping us build MyFreshLocal, you help build successful local food economies, in your area and around the country. As we are successful, the market for organic food grows and the prices for all of us come down.

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

Please help us live our dream of building a local food web for everyone. Even if it is just a dollar that you can give we promise we will make the most of it to build this community.

 

And if you can't give a dollar but you want to help please TELL ALL YOUR FRIENDS and share a link to our project!

And even if you don't invest in this project, you can make a difference by choosing local food. Use the food finder on MyFreshLocal to find farmers' markets and locally-sourced restaurants near you. Every time you choose local food, we all get one small step closer to a better food system.

story:
Our Story

We are the Northwest Atlantic Marine Alliance (NAMA). We work with community based, family fishermen on policy and market alternatives that let us have our fish and eat it, too. Why? Because policy decisions that have turned farms into food production machines with grave ecological, health and economic consequences are being mirrored on the marine side. Fishing is being turned into a highly extractive industry with similar consequences as agribusiness had on farming.

We are at a fork in the road: on one hand we can give away our marine fisheries and seafood system to the likes of Tyson, ConAgra, and Monsantos of the world, while on the other hand we can work with small and medium scale, community based fishermen. Knowing what we know about the history of agriculture and the degradation of our land based food system, soil and communities by agribusiness, the choice is pretty clear to us.

That's why we work so hard to connect family farmers and community based fishermen. By building alliances with family farmers and food justice advocates, our ocean and seafood production ecosystems can be protected. 

We have been partnering with family farm groups to connect fishermen to farmers, and since 2008 we have been sending fishermen to Farm Aid to get inspiration and feel the camaraderie so we can repeat the good stuff on the water and stop the corporate grab at the resources the ocean provides. 

This year we are back on the #Road2FarmAid, and this time helping NC local commercial fishermen go to Raleigh, NC from September 12 - 13, 2014 to tell how the theft of marine resources by large corporations is destroying fishing families, fishing villages, public access to local seafood, and the environment. Whether it's fishing rights, mining rights, drilling rights, or shoreline property rights that are being grabbed, these grabs have serious ecological, social, economic and food access consequences.

NC fishermen will share that message with an exhibit at the HOMEGROWN Village at Farm Aid, complimenting the message from family farmers and elevating the contribution of fishermen as food producers. Our exhibit will be the “Let’s Make a (ocean) Grab!” modeled after the game show “Let’s Make a Deal” complete with a game show host, visuals, and “doors” that the contestants can choose to determine what marine-based public resource they have “grabbed” and what are the environmental, social and economic consequences of such an action as well as solutions to fix the problem. We will be partnering with our friends at the National Family Farm Coalition to create a game that reaches across land and sea.

Resource grabs are resulting in the rapid contraction of family fishing operations as access to the rights to fish, ocean environment, marine resources and waterfront properties are restricted or allocated to large corporations and other privileged groups with the financial and political power to shape policy. 

This will be the sixth year we have facilitated the participation of fishermen at Farm Aid. For the first four years, we shared an exhibit space with our friends at the National Family Farm Coalition. In 2013 we had our own Homegrown Village space for the first time with the successful game of “The Price is Wrong!” highlighting the economic injustice of our food system particularly for fishermen and farmers.

Help Us Get Fishermen To Farm Aid

We need your help to get 12 fishermen and community-based fishing advocates to Farm Aid to share their message with the public, with the media, and with farm and food organizations.  Fishermen will be sacrificing time away from work to attend – if the fish are running that week, that could be a significant donation. So we want to raise $2,500 to cover the cost of lodging, travel and tickets for 12 fishing community volunteers as well as the cost of creating our exhibit at Farm Aid’s Homegrown Village.
You  may be thinking: why can't they pay their own way to go? Truth is that many small and medium scale fishermen are walking a thin line between profitability and loss. With privatization of fisheries, many are now having to pay to lease the rights to fish and the price at the dock is often not enough to cover all the costs. We call this fishing in the red, and it was the basis of our game in 2013's Farm Aid. With such low - or even non-existence - profit margins, it's faith and commitment that makes them go out everyday. And they are often too proud to ask for help. We want to remove the money barrier from their decisions because we know when fishermen get to places like Farm Aid they are inspired to keep going. So we want to make sure they get there.

Last year, it cost us almost $2,000 to send 10 people to Farm Aid in Saratoga Springs, NY. If we don’t raise all the money we estimate we need, we’ll put whatever we raise toward getting fishermen to Farm Aid. And should we raise more than $2,500 – which we hope we do – we will put it toward next year’s Fishermen to Farm Aid plans.

What Do You Get? 

From autographed copies of "Fish House Opera" by Susan West and Barbara Garrity-Blake describing the plight of NC fishermen to our book “Sharing the Ocean” by Michael Crocker to our “Who Fishes Matters” t-shirts and seafood wallet cards, and maybe even a fishing trip... we...

    What Can We Accomplish Together?

    Family fishermen need to know we care about who catches our fish. Your support sends them the message that collectively we believe there is a difference between fishing and extracting seafood. Being at Farm Aid is an uplifting experience for all of us, and just being there has energized us to keep fighting for a healthy ocean and healthy fishing communities.

    If our presence during the 2013 Farm Aid Homegrown Village is any indication, we’ll reach tens of thousands of concert-goers and the media. Last year, we created “The Price is Wrong” game to highlight the lack of fair price for fishermen and farmers - what we call fishing and farming in the red. Based on the concertgoers reception to that game, we know they engage with our new “Let’s Make a (Ocean) Grab” game and will learn about ways public policy can advance the cause of community-based fishing and roll back exorbitant fishing quota and permit leasing costs, the rapid conversion of working waterfronts to recreational and leisure uses, the graying of the fleet as fewer young people see a future in fishing, and how the viability of local fleets and their roles in environmental and cultural heritage stewardship can be restored.

    It Won't Be Easy

    We’re a small non-profit doing some majorly big work. We started as a regional group and are now working internationally all the while sharing our resources and power with those who are impacted most by our work: community based fishermen at the forefront of the struggle to save our ocean. We have refused taking funding from organizations and foundations that dictate how we work and what we work on. This means we do all that we do with very limited resources and with hard earned dollars. That’s why we need your help.

    Even though funding is always on our mind, when it comes to our plans at Farm Aid our biggest challenges are:

    1)  Making a compelling and engaging game. Based on last year’s experience, we know it doesn’t take much to create an engaging game. We’re putting the same creative brains and hands to work this year to create the “Let’s Make a (Ocean) Grab” game.

    2)  Making it easy for fishermen to attend. Much like farmers, fishermen are having a harder and harder time making ends meet. So taking time off from work – in their case fishing – and to pay for travel, lodging, and other related costs is simply out of the question. But we’ve been able to demonstrate to them that being at Farm Aid will give them hope, allies and spiritual uplifting. Knowing this makes it easier for them to take the day off from work. So we are coming to you to help us with making the rest of it possible by contributing to the travel, lodging, tickets and materials costs.

    The risk is that some people won’t understand why fishermen are having a presence at Farm Aid. But that’s a risk we’re willing to take as with every year we’ve been at Farm Aid we have seen an increase in the knowledge, interest and participation of those who have come to realize why community based fishermen and family farmers are important if we are to have our food with smallest ecological footprints but the biggest social and economic impacts. 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    In addition to – or instead of – a contribution, you can:

    -  Spread the word about our HOMEGROWN Village exhibit at Farm Aid and about our Indiegogo campaign. 

    -  Join us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter and sign up for our e-newsletter to keep abreast of real time action opportunities before and after Farm Aid.

    -  Follow these principles when buying seafood:

    • Buy from local fishermen whenever possible

     • Choose seafood that has traveled the least distance 

    • Choose wild seafood whenever possible 

    • Avoid farmed finfish and shrimp 

    • Avoid fake or imitation seafood products

     • Get involved in a Community Supported Fishery (CSF)

    • Ask how, where, and when your seafood was caught

to connect fishermen to farmers, and since 2008 we have been
sending fishermen to Farm Aid to get inspiration and feel the camaraderie so we
can repeat the good stuff on the water and stop the corporate grab at the resources the ocean provides. 
This year we are back on the #Road2FarmAid, and this time helping NC
local commercial fishermen go to Raleigh, NC from September 12 - 13, 2014 to
tell how the theft of marine resources by large corporations is destroying fishing
families, fishing villages, public access to local seafood, and the
environment. Whether it's fishing rights, mining rights, drilling rights, or shoreline property rights that are being grabbed, these grabs have serious ecological, social, economic and food access consequences.
NC fishermen will share
that message with an exhibit at the HOMEGROWN Village at Farm Aid,
complimenting the message from family farmers and elevating the contribution of
fishermen as food producers. Our exhibit will be the “Let’s Make a (ocean)
Grab!” modeled after the game show “Let’s Make a Deal” complete with a game show
host, visuals, and “doors” that the contestants can choose to determine what
marine-based public resource they have “grabbed” and what are the
environmental, social and economic consequences of such an action as well as
solutions to fix the problem. We will be partnering with our friends at the
National Family Farm Coalition to create a game that reaches across land and
sea.
Resource grabs are
resulting in the rapid contraction of family fishing operations as access to the
rights to fish, ocean environment, marine resources and waterfront properties
are restricted or allocated to large corporations and other privileged groups
with the financial and political power to shape policy.  
This will be the sixth year we have facilitated the
participation of fishermen at Farm Aid. For the first four years, we shared an
exhibit space with our friends at the National Family Farm Coalition. In 2013
we had our own Homegrown Village space for the first time with the successful
game of “The Price is Wrong!” highlighting the economic injustice of our food
system particularly for fishermen and farmers.
   Help Us Get Fishermen To Farm Aid
We need your help to get 12 fishermen and community-based fishing advocates to Farm Aid to share their
message with the public, with the media, and with farm and food organizations.  Fishermen will be sacrificing time away from
work to attend – if the fish are running that week, that could be a significant
donation. So we want to raise $2,500 to cover the cost of lodging, travel and
tickets for 12 fishing community volunteers as well as the cost of creating our
exhibit at Farm Aid’s Homegrown Village.

You  may be thinking: why can't they pay their own way to go? Truth is that many small and medium scale fishermen are walking a thin line between profitability and loss. With privatization of fisheries, many are now having to pay to lease the rights to fish and the price at the dock is often not enough to cover all the costs. We call this fishing in the red, and it was the basis of our game in 2013's Farm Aid. With such low - or even non-existence - profit margins, it's faith and commitment that makes them go out everyday. And they are often too proud to ask for help. We want to remove the money barrier from their decisions because we know when fishermen get to places like Farm Aid they are inspired to keep going. So we want to make sure they get there.

Last year, it cost us almost $2,000 to send 10 people to Farm
Aid in Saratoga Springs, NY. If we don’t raise all the money we estimate we
need, we’ll put whatever we raise toward getting fishermen to Farm Aid. And
should we raise more than $2,500 – which we hope we do – we will put it toward
next year’s Fishermen to Farm Aid plans.

What Do You Get? 
From autographed copies of "Fish
House Opera" by Susan West and Barbara Garrity-Blake describing the plight of NC fishermen to our book “Sharing
the Ocean” by Michael Crocker to our “Who Fishes Matters” t-shirts and seafood wallet cards, and maybe even a fishing trip... we...


  What Can We Accomplish Together?

Family fishermen need to know we care about who catches our
fish. Your support sends them the message that collectively we believe there is
a difference between fishing and extracting seafood. Being at Farm Aid is an
uplifting experience for all of us, and just being there has energized us to
keep fighting for a healthy ocean and healthy fishing communities.
If our presence during the 2013 Farm Aid Homegrown Village is
any indication, we’ll reach tens of thousands of concert-goers and the media.
Last year, we created “The Price is Wrong” game to highlight the lack of fair
price for fishermen and farmers - what we call fishing and farming in the red. Based on the concertgoers reception to that
game, we know they engage with our new “Let’s Make a (Ocean) Grab” game and
will learn about ways public policy can advance the cause of community-based
fishing and roll back exorbitant fishing quota and permit leasing costs, the
rapid conversion of working waterfronts to recreational and leisure uses, the
graying of the fleet as fewer young people see a future in fishing, and how the
viability of local fleets and their roles in environmental and cultural
heritage stewardship can be restored.
  It Won't Be Easy

We’re
a small non-profit doing some majorly big work. We started as a regional group
and are now working internationally all the while sharing our resources and
power with those who are impacted most by our work: community based fishermen
at the forefront of the struggle to save our ocean. We have refused taking
funding from organizations and foundations that dictate how we work and what we
work on. This means we do all that we do with very limited resources and with
hard earned dollars. That’s why we need your help.

Even
though funding is always on our mind, when it comes to our plans at Farm Aid our
biggest challenges are: 
1) 
Making a compelling and engaging game.
Based on last year’s experience, we know it doesn’t take much to create an
engaging game. We’re putting the same creative brains and hands to work this
year to create the “Let’s Make a (Ocean) Grab” game.
2) 
Making it easy for fishermen to attend.
Much like farmers, fishermen are having a harder and harder time making ends
meet. So taking time off from work – in their case fishing – and to pay for
travel, lodging, and other related costs is simply out of the question. But
we’ve been able to demonstrate to them that being at Farm Aid will give them
hope, allies and spiritual uplifting. Knowing this makes it easier for them to
take the day off from work. So we are coming to you to help us with making the rest
of it possible by contributing to the travel, lodging, tickets and materials
costs. 
The risk is that some people won’t understand why fishermen are
having a presence at Farm Aid. But that’s a risk we’re willing to take as with
every year we’ve been at Farm Aid we have seen an increase in the knowledge,
interest and participation of those who have come to realize why community
based fishermen and family farmers are important if we are to have our food
with smallest ecological footprints but the biggest social and economic
impacts. 
  Other Ways You Can Help 

In addition to – or instead of – a contribution, you can:
- 
Spread the word about our HOMEGROWN
Village exhibit at Farm Aid and about our Indiegogo campaign.  
- 
Join us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter
and sign up for our e-newsletter to keep abreast of real time action
opportunities before and after Farm Aid.
- 
Follow these principles when buying
seafood:
• Buy from local fishermen whenever
possible
 • Choose seafood that has traveled the
least distance 
• Choose wild seafood whenever possible 
• Avoid farmed finfish and shrimp 
• Avoid fake or imitation seafood
products
 • Get involved in a Community Supported
Fishery (CSF) 
• Ask how, where, and when your seafood
was caught

story:
Short Summary

For 15 years, Brownsboro Alliance (BA) has worked to renew and reconnect the economy, environment, and people of Brownsboro into a sustainable, innovative rural community.  In August of 2014, BA opened the first phase of the trail system to membership by connecting existing trails and roadbeds that have been used informally by landowners and their guests for generations.

What We Need & What You Get

We need your help to extend this trail system beyond Phase I.  Additional sections of the trail are planned and will be implemented as license agreements, manpower, and funding become available for trail building and continued maintenance.  With your donations, we can:

  • buy chainsaws, loppers, and other equipment for trail maintenance;
  • pay for construction, like erosion control and earthwork;
  • build bridges;
  • and increase trail signage.

Certain donors will receive a trail membership, good for one year.  See Perks for more details.

    The Impact

    According to the Centers for Disease Control, Kentucky is among the top ten states for obesity rates nationwide.  Our children today are experiencing chronic illnesses once reserved for adults.  BA is responding to the need for adults, children, and families to find recreational opportunities and become more active.  The BA trail is an antidote for growing girths and is a great addition to any fitness regimen. 

    BA is also delighted to partner with Brownsboro farm owners to offer a scenic recreational opportunity in the outdoors.  Trails are accessible to hikers, walking with or without a dog, and to horseback riders.  The trail allows BA to preserve land, trees, flowers, waterbeds, and animal habitats for future generations to enjoy.  Members can enjoy bird watching, spring wildflower walks, and a rainbow of colors in fall foliage. Much like nature itself, the picture will change and grow… and the opportunities are endless.

    Risks & Challenges

    Brownsboro Alliance Trail System is organized without government funding, so we rely on the generosity of people like you.  We do not own the land used for this members-only trail system, so many public grants and other scholarship opportunities are not available to us. 

    BA has worked with landowners and attorneys to ensure that the trail system and its users are protected by Kentucky laws.  As we go forward with additional segments, we will work to protect landowners rights as well as the safety of trail members using the trail.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Some people can't contribute, but we need more than just financial donations:

    • Volunteer your time and talents to work on the trail.
    • Tell your friends about the Brownsboro Alliance Trail System!

    We'll see you on the trail!

story:
When I am not creating ecologically tuned, aesthetically aware and sustainable habitats for the UK's pollinators and championing the Bee Cause - I am spending time stravaiging the most spectacular landscapes imaginable. I am passionate about Scotland's nature and wildest lands and It is life-affirming keeping company with the rugged mountains and glens, sparkling lochans, Caledonian pine forests, peatlands and machair with its mosaic of wildflowers.

We have some of the most valuable ecosystems and habitats supporting Scotland’s diverse wildlife - the elusive Scottish wildcat, badgers, corncrakes, mountain hare, red squirrels, water voles, white-tailed sea eagle, mountain ringlet butterflies and the great yellow bumblebee. I fervently believe that a healthy natural environment and experiencing ‘wildness’ is vital to our wellbeing and we should strive to maintain its integrity. By supporting the vision of our leading conservation charities, we can safeguard, conserve and restore our wildlife and wild lands for the enjoyment of future generations.

"I only went out for a walk, and finally concluded to stay out until sundown, for going out, I found, was really going in" John Muir

In support of the Scottish Wildlife Trust and John Muir Trust, I plan to eschew the comforts of home for a year, immersing myself in the beauty and wonder of the most spectacular landscapes imaginable by stravaiging the length and breadth of Scotland and wild camping in the 42 wild land areas. By making the wild land areas my home for a year, I hope to enjoy 365 sunrises and sundowns, be absorbed in the song of water and birds, be with the mountains, elemental wildness, catch sight of some of Scotland's most amazing wildlife - from the largest to the craiturie and study the flora, habitats and ecosystems. My hope is to enthuse and inspire others to have greater involvement in, enjoy, learn and act for nature.

I am keen to visit many of the sites that are being managed, restored and rewilded for the benefit of wildlife and people. I plan to keep records in the form of a blog and field notes to enable donors to follow my progress throughout this expedition. I am keen also to share the beauty and wonder of our wild land areas.

“The idea of wilderness needs no defence, it only needs defenders.” Edward Abbey

( Unfortunately my sponsor pulled out at the last minute, hence the need to request the support of some philanthropic individuals)

http://uk.virginmoneygiving.com/CerysTrayner
