story:
Who am I and what's a Tapuio?

My name is David Bond. I am a (soon to be) 53 year old English teacher living in Brazil and Tapuio is my home. I am an American who sold everything in 2007, left Texas, and moved south, just got on the bus and headed south, until I stopped in Tapuio, a mountainous spot of Atlantic Forest in the southeast state of Espírito Santo. 

Tapuio is located in the municipality of Iconha in the state of Espírito Santo in Brazil. It is a zone of mountains suddenly rising 2296 feet up. From the upper reaches of Tapuio, you can look out at approximately 150 miles of Atlantic coastline. Heavily depredated in the past, it was long ago abandoned because of its inaccessibility and today there are no permanent residents. The forest returned, the plants returned, the wildlife returned, and when I first moved there in 2008, ant eaters, foxes, boas, armadillos, monkeys, parakeets, paca, and more were all quite common. Porcupines would walk around and on the house at nights. Orchid spores blew in with the wind, sprouted, grew, bloomed. Vanilla vines and passion fruit vines blanketed the trees. 

In 2009, people in the area began talking about eco-tourism, which for some reason means exactly the opposite around here: bring in as many people as possible, pave roads, cut down trees, get rid of snakes, so that eco-tourists can walk safely all over the place. It didn't really happen, in part because I was ferocious in my opposition, but the damage was done. Massive deforestation. The tourists didn't come (thankfully) but hunters did, in large numbers. They decimated much of the wildlife. Now, fruit falls from the trees and rots on the ground. Bird hunters flocked into the upper reaches to collect birds for the illegal bird trade. Orchids disappeared, bromeliads disappeared. Cattle farming expanded, agriculture expanded, and the area is dying. Local protection groups remain indifferent. Since no politically important people live here or own land here, it isn't politically important to them. 

I want to try to save this area from further damage and destruction. I have an overall plan to record the loss, use the images to generate support for this beautiful area, and either acquire the area or find a patron who can. Recording the loss is the first step.

This first step is crucial. Without a recording of what is lost, I cannot convince people of what needs to be saved. Your help will enable me to do this.

The Give and Take

When I moved into Tapuio in 2008, I had a nice camera and my Mac Book Pro. I took photos constantly, learning photography while preserving the images of Tapuio. In 2009,  five of my photos were used in the exhibit for my region at the 2009 EXPOTUR in Vitória. Through my photography, I was able to generate concern, control hunters, and record the wildlife. Unfortunately, in 2010 my camera was stolen. 

I have all my photos saved on my computer; however, early this year my computer suffered damage due to a power surge. Fire came out the power connection and the CD slot. Even though my computer still works, it was badly damaged and now overheats regularly. It has slowed down, is unable to process volumes of information, and I fear I will lose my photos. I can barely work with the photos I saved.

So for this first step, I need a new computer and a new camera. I could do with a few lenses as well, but I that is not necessary. 

I don't need a new Mac Book Pro. I don't need to carry my computer out into the field. So I decided on a Mac Mini. It has the computing power I need, is easy enough to move should I need to, and is less expensive. I chose Mac because that is all I've ever used. 

For a camera, I have a certain loyalty to Olympus. My stolen camera was an Olympus. It's what I used, what I know. The Olympus E-5.

My goal of $5000 is a little higher than the cost of the two items. The extra money will be applied to the cost of a site I use to write about Tapuio, where I can post the images and write about the what is happening. The site is also a place where I can publicly flesh out details about where I want to take this project long term. The additional money will also allow me to print and produce in tangible fashion my images for display. 

If I do not meet my goal, I will apply the money either toward a new computer or a camera, depending on how much is actually raised. If it isn’t sufficient for either, then I will apply it toward printing the images I currently have from 2008-2010, website maintenance, and rent on the space I use for teaching which I can also use as a space for awareness about Tapuio.

For those interested in receiving perks for their contributions, I can offer access to high resolution images of Tapuio (your choice of image) for reproduction, high quality printed images, or t-shirts with images of the leaves of Tapuio. 

Why do this?

                                   

I’m sure everybody knows about the Brazilian oil discoveries. And with oil comes development, not all of it ecologically sound. Well, that oil is right off the coastof Espírito Santo, right where I live. From my house in Tapuio I can see the gas fires on the platforms 100 kilometers out at sea. Construction is everywhere and everything is tinged with urgency, possibility, greed. Looking out from the top of Iconha all the way to the ocean in all directions all you see are empty brown hills with wandering cattle, construction, and eucalyptus and rubber. The Highway 101 which runs through the center of Iconha is a constant never ending stream of cars and trucks and noise and pollution. Quality has never been considered a lucrative concept in this region: you had to wait too long for the money. So the drive is to construct and create quickly, cheaply, to accommodate as many people as possible in as small an area as possible. 

While some regional municipalities are changing their views and incorporating the concept of quality, Iconha is hurtling headlong into quick-and-cheap. The city is a dreary chaos of noise and traffic incessant traffic with the major highway passing right through the middle of the city. Nobody takes advantage of this traffic to create any kind of quality attraction. All Brazil drives through the heart of Iconha yet there is no attempt at capturing that traffic in terms of education, culture, quality business. 

The interior of Iconha, on the other hand, is beautiful. Mountains and waterfalls and spectacular views and nature form the backdrop to this horrible little city. Mountains rise up to almost 3000 feet. The Atlantic Ocean is only about 10 miles away and the river that flows down the mountains in Iconha flow into the Atlantic Ocean. 

Five and a half miles from the center of the city and straight up 1000 feet or so is Tapuio, facing the Atlantic Ocean. Long ago abandoned due to difficult access, it was ignored until recently. Because the rain pattern is from West to East, Tapuio is dryer than the same region on the western side of the slopes, creating a different biozone from the surrounding zones and regions. Because the incline is abrupt, not gradual, the climate is also different: summers can be dreadfully hot and dry in a region of summer rains. Winters can be painfully cold even at altitudes as low as 1300 feet, the altitude of my house. Cacao will not produce above this line, coconuts barely grow and never fruit here. My thermometer has recorded winter lows as low as 45ºF and I know it has been colder, something not usual in other areas at the same altitude.  The result of this is a flora and fauna different from the surrounding areas. 

This is also a zone of transition in terms of human use. For years it suffered from the extraction of granite and marble and during that time many families lived here. That came to an end (the cables and blocks are still strewn about in Tapuio with blocks of granite simply sitting around) and families who had made a living here farming and extracting granite moved away. Abandoned, the forest grew back, animals returned. Some people continued farming, but by and large it was simply ignored. Orchids sprouted on coffee plants. Trees grew up, flowered, seeded, spread feeding a growing population of paca and foxes and ant eaters and bats. Jussara (a kind of açaí), sapucaia (similar to Brazil nuts), avocados, pink pepper and other even more exotic trees and plants, some already rare in other parts of Brazil, were everywhere up here. 

                   

Water is spring fed and good, but not plentiful. The few springs feed the two houses still operating in Tapuio as well as many families below. 

The area is unique, beautiful, rare. In the past few years due to speculation about tourism, hunting, and expanding agriculture the area has been massively deforested. Large trees are felled every week. Cattle now wander the mountainsides eating everything, resulting in erosion, depletion of the soil, death of the area. The mountain soil is literally washing into the ocean with each rain. The risk of landslides has increased. Dry spells and heat have both increased. And people talk about building tourist condos, cheaply made to accommodate the greatest number of the lowest quality tourist who will use up all the water, leaving the area dead. 

Animals are disappearing at an alarming rate. Hunting has increased to the point there is no longer anything to hunt. Avocados and passionfruit fall from the trees and rot. I haven’t seen an ant eater in three years. I haven’t seen an irara in two years. The last fox disappeared two years ago. Even the spiders and snakes are disappearing. 

I have a long term plan to try to stop the destruction and reverse the damage, but it is a plan in various steps. My ultimate goal is somehow to acquire (or convince someone else to acquire) the land and convert it into a very restricted retreat, 5 houses at the most to be used for very limited periods of time by a very limited number of people for the purposes of rest, research, and artistic work. This would stop the “development” and completely eliminate hunting and depredation. Their presence could also contribute to a more quality growth in this area: any artistic work could be displayed and/or sold in Iconha, thus capturing some of that heavy traffic that courses through the city every day without stopping. I’m sure you can see how this can spur other forms of quality growth. (For example, there is no decent restaurant in the city. Not one. There are a couple self-service pit stops designed for people to fill their bellies and move on.) 

Maybe you can’t contribute

I understand. Believe me, I understand. I look at my  bank account and cry! But contributions aren’t only in the form of money. There are a number of things you can do.

• Share Share Share. One of my biggest frustrations on Facebook has been that instead of sharing, people hit like and move on. Nobody else sees it, nobody else knows, nobody else gets involved. Please share. Let people know. 

• Come down for a visit, see for yourself. Spend a week in Tapuio and then go back and talk. Or if you can’t, suggest it to a friend, a college student looking for a research topic, an adventurer looking to go somewhere he wouldn’t otherwise consider. 

• Give me advice, let me know what I can do better. 

I know there are better places, more beautiful places, more interesting places. But Tapuio is my home, it is where I live, and it is beautiful. Help me keep this spot of life alive.

The additional money will also allow me to print and produce in tangible fashion my images for display. 
If I do not meet my goal, I will apply the money either toward a new computer or a camera, depending on how much is actually raised. If it isn’t sufficient for either, then I will apply it toward printing the images I currently have from 2008-2010, website maintenance, and rent on the space I use for teaching which I can also use as a space for awareness about Tapuio.
For those interested in receiving perks for their contributions, I can offer access to high resolution images of Tapuio (your choice of image) for reproduction, high quality printed images, or t-shirts with images of the leaves of Tapuio. 
Why do this?                                   
I’m sure everybody knows about the Brazilian oil discoveries. And with oil comes development, not all of it ecologically sound. Well, that oil is right off the coastof Espírito Santo, right where I live. From my house in Tapuio I can see the gas fires on the platforms 100 kilometers out at sea. Construction is everywhere and everything is tinged with urgency, possibility, greed. Looking out from the top of Iconha all the way to the ocean in all directions all you see are empty brown hills with wandering cattle, construction, and eucalyptus and rubber. The Highway 101 which runs through the center of Iconha is a constant never ending stream of cars and trucks and noise and pollution. Quality has never been considered a lucrative concept in this region: you had to wait too long for the money. So the drive is to construct and create quickly, cheaply, to accommodate as many people as possible in as small an area as possible. 
While some regional municipalities are changing their views and incorporating the concept of quality, Iconha is hurtling headlong into quick-and-cheap. The city is a dreary chaos of noise and traffic incessant traffic with the major highway passing right through the middle of the city. Nobody takes advantage of this traffic to create any kind of quality attraction. All Brazil drives through the heart of Iconha yet there is no attempt at capturing that traffic in terms of education, culture, quality business. 
The interior of Iconha, on the other hand, is beautiful. Mountains and waterfalls and spectacular views and nature form the backdrop to this horrible little city. Mountains rise up to almost 3000 feet. The Atlantic Ocean is only about 10 miles away and the river that flows down the mountains in Iconha flow into the Atlantic Ocean. 
Five and a half miles from the center of the city and straight up 1000 feet or so is Tapuio, facing the Atlantic Ocean. Long ago abandoned due to difficult access, it was ignored until recently. Because the rain pattern is from West to East, Tapuio is dryer than the same region on the western side of the slopes, creating a different biozone from the surrounding zones and regions. Because the incline is abrupt, not gradual, the climate is also different: summers can be dreadfully hot and dry in a region of summer rains. Winters can be painfully cold even at altitudes as low as 1300 feet, the altitude of my house. Cacao will not produce above this line, coconuts barely grow and never fruit here. My thermometer has recorded winter lows as low as 45ºF and I know it has been colder, something not usual in other areas at the same altitude.  The result of this is a flora and fauna different from the surrounding areas. 
This is also a zone of transition in terms of human use. For years it suffered from the extraction of granite and marble and during that time many families lived here. That came to an end (the cables and blocks are still strewn about in Tapuio with blocks of granite simply sitting around) and families who had made a living here farming and extracting granite moved away. Abandoned, the forest grew back, animals returned. Some people continued farming, but by and large it was simply ignored. Orchids sprouted on coffee plants. Trees grew up, flowered, seeded, spread feeding a growing population of paca and foxes and ant eaters and bats. Jussara (a kind of açaí), sapucaia (similar to Brazil nuts), avocados, pink pepper and other even more exotic trees and plants, some already rare in other parts of Brazil, were everywhere up here.                    
Water is spring fed and good, but not plentiful. The few springs feed the two houses still operating in Tapuio as well as many families below. 
The area is unique, beautiful, rare. In the past few years due to speculation about tourism, hunting, and expanding agriculture the area has been massively deforested. Large trees are felled every week. Cattle now wander the mountainsides eating everything, resulting in erosion, depletion of the soil, death of the area. The mountain soil is literally washing into the ocean with each rain. The risk of landslides has increased. Dry spells and heat have both increased. And people talk about building tourist condos, cheaply made to accommodate the greatest number of the lowest quality tourist who will use up all the water, leaving the area dead. 
Animals are disappearing at an alarming rate. Hunting has increased to the point there is no longer anything to hunt. Avocados and passionfruit fall from the trees and rot. I haven’t seen an ant eater in three years. I haven’t seen an irara in two years. The last fox disappeared two years ago. Even the spiders and snakes are disappearing. 
I have a long term plan to try to stop the destruction and reverse the damage, but it is a plan in various steps. My ultimate goal is somehow to acquire (or convince someone else to acquire) the land and convert it into a very restricted retreat, 5 houses at the most to be used for very limited periods of time by a very limited number of people for the purposes of rest, research, and artistic work. This would stop the “development” and completely eliminate hunting and depredation. Their presence could also contribute to a more quality growth in this area: any artistic work could be displayed and/or sold in Iconha, thus capturing some of that heavy traffic that courses through the city every day without stopping. I’m sure you can see how this can spur other forms of quality growth. (For example, there is no decent restaurant in the city. Not one. There are a couple self-service pit stops designed for people to fill their bellies and move on.) 
Maybe you can’t contribute
I understand. Believe me, I understand. I look at my  bank account and cry! But contributions aren’t only in the form of money. There are a number of things you can do.
• Share Share Share. One of my biggest frustrations on Facebook has been that instead of sharing, people hit like and move on. Nobody else sees it, nobody else knows, nobody else gets involved. Please share. Let people know. 
• Come down for a visit, see for yourself. Spend a week in Tapuio and then go back and talk. Or if you can’t, suggest it to a friend, a college student looking for a research topic, an adventurer looking to go somewhere he wouldn’t otherwise consider. 
• Give me advice, let me know what I can do better. 
I know there are better places, more beautiful places, more interesting places. But Tapuio is my home, it is where I live, and it is beautiful. Help me keep this spot of life alive.

story:
Hogar Casa Venard

Es un hogar transitorio de rehabilitación y resocialización de personas sin techo en el Viejo San Juan. El hogar depende de donaciones para subsistir.

Necesitamos crear un huerto hidroponico para poder cosechar vegetales y educar a los participantes en la agricultura. Utilizaremos el huerto como medio de terapia y relajación.

Que necesitamos?

Para crear el huerto necesitamos los siguientes materiales:

  • Bombas electricas
  • Tubos PVC
  • Nutrientes
  • Carpa 10 x 20
  • Semillas!!! :)

Impacto

El inmenso impacto positivo en los participintantes cuando aprendan y se ocupen del mantenimiento del huerto es incalculable. El huerto creara responsabilidad y compromiso, pasiencia y amor propio!

Otras Formas de Ayudar

El hogar tambien provee vestimenta, si tienes ropa traela!

  • Ana Irrizary - 787-612-7265
  • http://www.hogarpadrevenard.org/contact.htm

Ayudanos a ayudar!

Cualquier donacion es importante, sea de $1 o de $1000, el objetivo es unirnos
como Pueblo para mejorar nuestra comunidad.

story:
WHAT WE DO

We believe access to nature is a human right. At Insight Garden Program, participants engage in weekly, three-hour classes that support personal transformation and skills development. Our year-long program is organized into four semesters and uses a holistic curriculum focused on the interconnection of self, community, and the natural world. Gardens, designed and installed by participants, are used as teaching tools for learning organic growing practices, permaculture landscape design, and a means to practice patience, care, and commitment:

Environmental Education | Deepening commitment to environmental care
Permaculture Gardening | Providing hands-on training in our prison gardens
Inner Gardening | Promoting behavioral change and personal transformation 
Reentry Preparation | Planning for successful reentry to society

    

 

IMPACT

We sprouted our roots in California with the launch of our program at San Quentin Prison in 2002. Fifteen years later, we’ve expanded to eight California facilities, have two programs in Indiana, and support a reentry collaboration in New York with Hawthorne Valley Farm and the Bard Prison Initiative.

We’re a nationally recognized and evidence-based program, with a less than 10% rate of return to prison. When IGP graduates leave prison and get employment with environmental justice community partners, the recidivism rate is 0%.​

In California, it costs taxpayers nearly $60,000 to incarcerate one person annually.
To sponsor one person in our program for an entire year, it only costs $500. 

 

WHAT YOUR CONTRIBUTION MEANS

Support Insight Garden’s #BloomingBehindBars campaign to help us grow more gardens, launch new programs, and expand community services and green job opportunities for returning citizens. 

Together we can end cycles of incarceration
and create greener and safer communities.

 

JOIN US

#BloomingBehindBars is about growing community! Working together with our participants and people in reentry, we strengthen our community and ultimately, our civil society. Now more than ever, we honor the importance of reconnecting with self, each other, and the natural world to weave a web of health, restoration, and wellness. Follow us and stay connected!:

  • Facebook
  • Instagram
  • Twitter

 

THOUGHTS FROM THE GARDEN


Darrell mentioned that he’s"learned in this program that we are all really connected; the minerals that are in the soil are the same minerals that are in us. It’s a relationship between us and the plants. We need each other to be able to survive.”


Sky says "Life springs forth and life recedes. We do what we can while the life is there to nurture it, water it, feed it, and then the seasons change. Things come and go. And that’s the nature of living.”

 

Azraal said, until our garden was installed, it had been 12 years since his last interaction with nature.“It’s a bit of freedom. All the constraints and stressors of the routine here are gone. It’s fun to get our hands in the dirt, smell the flowers, hear the buzzing of a bee. That’s something that we all need to thrive, and to feel alive.”

 

MORE ABOUT US

Read more about our work on our website insightgardenprogram.org 
For more stories about our program's impact, visit BeyondPrisons.us

 

 

All donations are tax deductible and
we are always looking to partner with like-minded organizations.
Together we can transform lives and create safer communities! 

 

THANKS TO OUR COMMUNITY SUPPORTERS!

 

Page photos courtesy of Carlos Chavarria, California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation and BeyondPrisons.us

story:
Provide local recycling facilities, promote reduce, repair & reuse ideas AND generate income for local schools.

About Us: 

Recycle for Education is a joint project with Sven Baumgärtel from Has Den Bosch University Holland, APE (Association for protection of the Environment) and volunteers from Projects Abroad.

Local waste in Khao Nor Chuchi, Thailand is usually burnt or taken to local landfill, government recycling facilities are not available. Many recyclable materials are disposed in this way polluting the environment and increasing demand on natural resources to make new products.

We are working together to increase the accessibility of recycling within the  Khao Nor Chuchi area. 

The project we have developed in conjunction with a local school is to set up recycling collection centres at schools in the area. The school will maintain the facilities and in return can use the income from selling recyclables to provide much needed funds to improve educational facilities and develop sustainability projects providing food for student's lunches.

We will have a launch workshop and produce and trial educational materials on environmental issues and waste.

But we don't want to stop there, we know that recycling isn't the best long term solution so we want to promote reduce, repair and reuse. We are going the extra step and are building the recycling centre from old plastic bottles, showcasing a great reuse idea. Lets hope that this creates a few more eco buildings in the area, our test build has certainly generated a lot of local interest!

So it's win, win, win. The environment benefits, reduce, repair, reuse is promoted & showcased and local schools raise money for education and sustainability projects! 

Where Will Your Money Go?

This money is to develop all the educational materials and work in a minimum of 2 schools to build a basic recycle collection centre. We will launch the scheme with a workshop and provide 4 follow up lessons per school. We can then analyse the results and improve the system before being ready to roll out to more schools in the region in 'phase 2'. Any money left over will go to setting up the system in more local schools as part of phase 2.

We will...

Develop and produce educational materials (posters, signs, flags etc) for the Reduce, Reuse, Repair & Recycle part of the project.

Buy building materials to make 2 easy to maintain, rainproof recycle centres in local schools, showcasing as many reuse ideas as possible.

Provide a fun Reduce, Reuse, Repair, Recycle workshop to launch the project and 4 follow up lessons per school. 

Monitor & develop the facilities and prepare the scheme for phase 2.

Perks:

  • $5 we'll send you a jungle screen saver from international rainforest artist Simon Buck.
  • $20 we'll plant a local forest tree in your honour, label it with your name and post a photo of it on our facebook page for you to download and treasure.
  • $30 we'll send you a mightily popular APE T-shirt.
  • $40 we'll plant a tree and send you a t-shirt
  • The Impact Locally:
  • We were shocked when we visited local landfills to find them full of recyclable materials... by making recycling more accessible in KNC we hope to improve this sad situation reducing the drain on our planet's limited natural resources.
  • Clean up Krabi, a lot of the bottles we used for our test ‘bottle wall’ were from local beach and roadside cleans, which not only clean up but also raise awareness of waste issues among locals and tourists. For example did you know that many sea turtles get sick from eating clear plastic bags thinking they are jelly fish?
  • Educate local children and their families about the importance of the 4 R's - Reduce, Reuse, Repair, Recycle. APE work in local schools and we know how many great ideas kids have, encourage young minds to develop eco solutions for themselves and help shape the future.
  • Showcase reuse ideas in our workshops and in the recycle centre itself. We have already built one wall with old plastic bottles and volunteer labour, so we know it's possible.. you just have to give the money, that is a lot easier than filling 4500 bottles with mud! But luckily we have volunteers and school children to help us!!
  • Generate income for local schools :) - need we say more?

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot spare money for the project then don't despair, maybe you know someone who can? By passing on the information about this great project you can help us with one click!

Remember to your RRRR’s and if you have joined in any projects in your area feel free to share them on our wall.

Watch this space for updates and be sure to 'share' with all your friends and family.

Thank you to everyone for your support, time and contributions to Recycle for Education. from all of us :)

story:
Volunteer Work

I'm going to be in the Faroe Islands for ten weeks serving as an unpaid volunteer in a campaign being led by a well known and highly successful anti-whaling, or pro-whale, group and could use your support:

  • Hi, my name is Matt Johnson and I'm a vegan activist, technology guy, and a very concerned citizen about the earth's environment. 
  • If you feel that species are in grave danger because of humans and want to help whales then you are on the right page!
  • This campaign is very important to me because killing whales, iconic and beautiful animals, is a horrible thing to do and should be stopped.
  • Any funds that you contribute to this project will be used to directly support the volunteer work I'm doing. I will use the money to help offset my flight, food and sharing of vegan and anti-whaling information with the Faroese people.

Specific use of funds

  • I will not be receiving any stipend while volunteering so these donations will help cover my ten weeks in the Faroes.
  • Some of these funds will be used to buy dried vegan food in bulk and have it mailed to the Faroe Islands for the ten weeks while I am there.
  • Flights to the Faroe Island are expensive so some of the money will be used to offset the price of the airfare.
  • Many Faroe people are interested in becoming vegan. I would like to bring some literature in Danish so that they can begin envisioning a more compassionate way of living.
  • Just as a disclaimer, all funds contributed on this site are for my use during the campaign and are not being collected or donated to any larger non-profit group. I need to add that in as those larger groups do their own fundraising and this is something separate for friends, family and interested parties to fund one specific person.

The Impact

This goal of this campaign is to save the lives of as many cetaceans, whales and dolphins, as possible this summer in the Faroe Islands. Specifically the Faroese are known to kill many pilot whales and dolphins every year and we want to stop that:

  • This campaign is going to be critical in stopping the Faroese people from continuing their old tradition of killing migrating whales. If you love whales and believe that our oceans are at risk this is a great campaign for your contributions.
  • Did you know that just this past year the Japanese lost in the International Court of Justice and have been ordered to stop their commercial whaling? This happened because of donations to anti-whaling campaigns like this one.
  • Without people around the world banding together to support wild animals they face very real threats of pointless killing and even extinction. You can help out though with your donation, even if you can't personally go on this campaign.

Other Ways You Can Help

Don't have money to contribute, no problem you can still help:

  • If you know someone that might be interested in this campaign just forward this link to them, that'd be really great!
  • Apparently Indiegogo has some great sharing tools, you can check those out too!

Thanks so much!

story:
Our story

The Private Conservation Area (PCA) Tilacancha is a 14,000 –acre protected area located in the districts of Levanto and Maino in the “eyebrow of the jungle” (cloud forest) of Amazonas, Peru. It is one of the regions’ most important natural areas, not only for its numerous endemic species, but because it protects the water source of the downstream city of Chachapoyas- home to more than 30,000 people and capital of the region of Amazonas.

The rural communities of Levanto and Maino manage Tilacancha with technical help from the Peruvian NGO Asociación Peruana para la Conservación de la Naturaleza (APECO). Founded in 1982, APECO has worked more than 30 years to conserve biodiversity within Peru’s most endangered ecosystems. APECO understands that a healthy environment leads to healthy people. Thanks to their efforts in Tilacancha, the city of Chachapoyas receives clean, potable water 24/7- a rarity in Peru.

Tilacancha is also the site of one of the first payment-for-ecosystem-services programs in Peru. Through their water bill payments, citizens of Chachapoyas will help fund projects to improve livestock and agricultural practices in Levanto and Maino. In return, the citizens of Levanto and Maino have agreed to manage 50% of their communal land for water-source protection.

However, ongoing education efforts are essential to ensure Chachapoyas’ clean drinking water in the future. An interpretative center in the district of Maino will help create environmental awareness amongst local citizens and visitors by providing a creative and dynamic space to explain the relationship between humans, the environment, and the water cycle.

This interpretive center will be located in the municipality of Maino and include photos, videos, interactive exhibits, and a natural history library. The center will be free and open to the public including local school groups, community members, and tourists.

However, we need your help to make the center a reality! Your donations will help us produce educational materials, create the needed exhibits, and renovate the space.

Find out more information about APECO and our projects at our Facebook Page: Cucho Colibri

Pass the link to your friends and help us increase awareness of our water source Tilacancha and promote water conservation in Peru!

Nuestra historia

El Área de Conservación Privada (ACP) Tilacancha es un área protegida de 6 800.48 hectáreas ubicada en los distritos de Levanto y Maino en la "ceja de la selva" (bosque nuboso), provincia Chachapoyas, departamento de Amazonas, Perú. Es una de las más importantes áreas naturales de la región, no sólo por sus numerosas especies endémicas, sino por que protege la fuente de agua para más de 30 000 personas, habitantes de la ciudad de Chachapoyas, capital de la región de Amazonas.

Las comunidades campesinas de Levanto y San Isidro de Maino son las propietarias del ACP Tilacancha y la administran con el apoyo técnico de la ONG peruana Asociación Peruana para la Conservación de la Naturaleza (APECO). Fundada en 1982, APECO ha trabajado más de 30 años para conservar la biodiversidad dentro de los ecosistemas más amenazados del Perú. APECO entiende que un medio ambiente sano conduce a las personas sanas. Gracias a sus esfuerzos en Tilacancha, la ciudad de Chachapoyas recibe agua limpia y potable las 24 horas, una rareza en el Perú.

Además, Tilacancha es una de las 17 iniciativas, en el Perú, que vienen implementando mecanismos de retribución por servicios ecosistémicos. A través del pago del recibo de agua, los ciudadanos de Chachapoyas ayudarán a financiar proyectos para mejorar las prácticas ganaderas y agrícolas en Levanto y Maino. A cambio, los ciudadanos de Levanto y Maino han puesto de acuerdo para gestionar el 50% de sus tierras comunales para la protección de fuentes de agua.

Para garantizar una buena conservación de Tilacancha, es necesario poner nuestros esfuerzos en la educación ambiental; por ello, proponemos la creación de un centro de interpretación en el distrito de Maino que ayudará a crear conciencia ambiental entre los ciudadanos y visitantes locales, proporcionando un espacio creativo y dinámico para explicar la relación entre los seres humanos, el medio ambiente, y el ciclo del agua.

Este centro de interpretación se ubicará en el municipio de Maino e incluirá fotos, videos, exhibiciones interactivas, y una biblioteca de historia natural. El centro será gratuito y abierto al público, incluidos los grupos locales escolares, miembros de la comunidad, y los turistas.

Sin embargo, ¡necesitamos su ayuda para que el centro sea una realidad! Sus donaciones ayudarán a producir materiales educativos, crear las exposiciones necesarias, y renovar el espacio.

Obtenga más información sobre APECO y nuestros proyectos en nuestra página de Facebook: Cucho Colibri y vea nuestro video en español: https://youtu.be/cJS1mLummSg

Pasa el enlace a sus amigos y nos ayudarán a aumentar la conciencia de nuestra fuente de agua Tilacancha y promovemos la conservación del agua en el Perú.

The impact

Since 2007, we have worked hard to protect Tilacancha, gaining the trust of the Provincial Municipality of Chachapoyas to develop the extensive technical documentation needed to legally recognize Tilacancha as a conservation area.

Although Tilacancha has been recognized as a private conservation area since 2010, we have a continued responsibility to raise environmental awareness so as to ensure meaningful, long-lasting protection. At APECO, we are constantly looking for allies and donations to help support our educational and environmental projects in Tilacancha and the communities of Levanto and Maino.

With this interpretation center, we hope that more people will learn about the beauty and importance of Tilacancha. Through this work, we can protect our ecosystems and the biodiversity they support, ensuring a higher quality of life for residents of rural Peru in the future.

Every bit helps! Share this link with your friends and help us conserve our water source:Tilacancha!

El impacto

Desde el 2007, hemos trabajado arduamente para apoyar en la conservación de Tilacancha, ganando la confianza de la Municipalidad Provincial de Chachapoyas para desarrollar el expediente técnico necesario para reconocer legalmente Tilacancha como un área de conservación.

Aunque Tilacancha ha sido reconocida como un área de conservación privada desde 2010, tenemos una responsabilidad continua para aumentar la conciencia ambiental a fin de garantizar la protección significativa de larga duración. En APECO, constantemente estamos buscando aliados y donaciones para ayudar a apoyar nuestros proyectos educativos y ambientales en Tilacancha y las comunidades de Levanto y Maino.

Con este centro de interpretación, esperamos que más gente va a aprender acerca de la belleza y la importancia de Tilacancha. A través de este trabajo, podemos proteger nuestros ecosistemas y la biodiversidad, lo que garantiza una mayor calidad de vida de los habitantes de zonas rurales de Perú en el futuro.

¡Cada pedacito ayuda! Comparte este enlace con tus amigos y nos ayudan a conservar nuestra fuente de agua: ¡Tilacancha!

Risks and Challenges

The location for the interpretive center has already been confirmed. Difficulties in obtaining materials might delay installation.

Riesgos y desafíos

Ya se ha confirmado la ubicación para el centro de interpretación. Las dificultades en la obtención de materiales podrían retrasar la instalación.
story_txt:
Our story

The Private
Conservation Area (PCA) Tilacancha is a 14,000 –acre protected area located
in the districts of Levanto and Maino in the “eyebrow of the jungle” (cloud forest)
of Amazonas, Peru. It is one of the regions’ most important natural areas, not
only for its numerous endemic species, but because it protects the water source
of the downstream city of Chachapoyas- home to more than 30,000 people and
capital of the region of Amazonas.
The rural
communities of Levanto and Maino manage Tilacancha with technical help from the
Peruvian NGO Asociación Peruana para la Conservación de la Naturaleza (APECO). Founded
in 1982, APECO has worked more than 30 years to conserve biodiversity within
Peru’s most endangered ecosystems. APECO understands that a healthy environment
leads to healthy people. Thanks to their efforts in Tilacancha, the city of
Chachapoyas receives clean, potable water 24/7- a rarity in Peru.
Tilacancha
is also the site of one of the first payment-for-ecosystem-services programs in
Peru. Through their water bill payments, citizens of Chachapoyas will help fund
projects to improve livestock and agricultural practices in Levanto and Maino.
In return, the citizens of Levanto and Maino have agreed to manage 50% of their
communal land for water-source protection.
However,
ongoing education efforts are essential to ensure Chachapoyas’ clean drinking
water in the future. An interpretative center in the district of Maino will
help create environmental awareness amongst local citizens and visitors by
providing a creative and dynamic space to explain the relationship between
humans, the environment, and the water cycle.
This
interpretive center will be located in the municipality of Maino and include
photos, videos, interactive exhibits, and a natural history library. The center
will be free and open to the public including local school groups, community
members, and tourists.
However, we
need your help to make the center a reality! Your donations will help us
produce educational materials, create the needed exhibits, and renovate the
space.
Find out
more information about APECO and our projects at our Facebook Page: Cucho
Colibri
Pass the
link to your friends and help us increase awareness of our water source
Tilacancha and promote water conservation in Peru!

story:
WeWillMeet Productions is a theatre company. The mandate is to fight for the Love & the Environment. 

Watch what you're funding here on Vimeo- https://vimeo.com/63785409

Here's the great idea:

Nathan Barrett is an actor, emcee and musician born in Vancouver, Britsh Colombia.

He will bike 2000 km's to raise awareness on fracking.

His embarking on this zero emissions tour from New York to New Orleans is a grass roots approach to protest fracking. 

Enticing you to support art that moves audience to action. Crowd-funding, research and artistic momentum building is his mandate. The long commute is for our art and for our water, walking the walk to talk the talk.

 Contributions will make possible, the tour of a potent piece of theatre throughout Canada. The piece, which you can peep here- https://vimeo.com/63785409 -is a piece that challenges audiences to challenge themselves and challenge the highly influential oil industries running politics and many aspects of our day to day lives. "Fresh Water - A Fracking Tragedy" promotes awareness on an issue, &, without pointing a finger, insists on action... 

 Awareness without action is a fleeting. It affects no change.

 With donors support this piece will have an avenue for impact, hopefully to wake up audiences to the urgency needed to put an end to hydraulic fracking in our communities. 

 Water depends on it. Pledgers will facilitate shifts, action & help light the fire. The fire we all need to fight the fight. We need to do this together. 

 Money raised will be used on venues, outreach, promotion, education and the show will ultimately be seen by all at whatever cost. Not looking to preach to the converted, but to really reach those complacent or knowingly or unknowingly ignorant to the issue we wish to reach people of all walks of life, industry professionals to activists. & to perform for communities affected by Fracking directly.

 ---------- given these recent events I think it is pertinent that we explore the United States for answers and experience Since, in the last couple weeks of October in Moncton, New Brunswick a Houston, Texas company SWN got assisted by the RCMP in dispersing indigenous protesters. The Royal Canadian Mounted Police were also assisted by US militants, who were there to protect their investment. The 'protest' was blockading the Houstinites from their Seismicity equipment, they were unable to start their work and losing money every day.... A real skirmish broke out. the first of its kind in a long time. This is why I believe we are with the pulse of the fight------

{ I like to think those american soldiers had as hard a time as i did getting into the others respective country but I think there tactical guns weren't an issue for our border guards. I actually got my hatchet in the US without a problem, I'll certainly need it to chop wood, as winter is inching behind me, nipping at my heels in every moment. }

If you contribute you will receive a signed dvd (break out your dvd players guys-big time) the electric first performance of 'Fresh Water'  It took place in Vancouver BC April 2013 It features writer performers - Chala Hunter & Nathan Barrett -

 We'll reach our entire goal of ten thousand dollars and the funds will go towards this piece...

Why Tour the East Coast ...

 The first Frack took place in Titusville Florida in 1859. When an ex military experimentalist dropped explosives down an artesian spring. This shook the earth and underground oil began to run to the surface. this discovery was the kickstarter to an american oil industry. 'Torpedoes' became a common place method in oil production increasing production 12000%. Titusville will be one of many stops along the long road.

 With the recent protests across Canada (and the world) sparked by the peaceful blockade in New Brunswick it is clear we are with the pulse of this struggle against oil and gas industry.

New Brunswick has seen the damage Fracking can do and has done in BC, to land and its inhabitants alike. That's why the Elsipogtog in Moncton have stood against it.

Given the immediate and the historic relationship this eastern coast has to Fracking, I think it`s a worthy journey to take in the name of anti-fracking.

Fracking and You-

 In regions plagued by the fracking industry people are feeling repercussions. Communities living atop of tapped shale deposits or anywhere near active Fracking wells in BC are developing cancers never before diagnosed

 Springs that once produced pristine drinking water for thousands of years are being sealed off to the public because they are now producing tainted water. This is due to the communication between the ground water & shale gas, methane and sometimes even plutonium

this is of course insane. Unacceptable. But it continues.

 Fracking is a provincially and nationally endorsed industry. British Colombia has over 32,000 Fracking wells, almost exclusively up north in indigenous populated areas. The number is continually growing as you read these words.

No surprise BC's Premier Christy Clark supports the 'cutting edge' industry, Prime Minister Stephan Harper supports, and here in the US Barrack Obama does not contest it.

 I grew up in 'British Colombia' surrounded by evergreen trees, arbutus trees, ocean and tons of water. There's an ownership that you inherently feel over a place you grow up in even as a 'settler' which is what I am proud to be. Growing up with access to some of the cleanest municipal drinking water in the world is awesome a blessing. I would like my niece and nephew to share that blessing with me and you. It's pure life, two days without water, you perish.

 Its my responsibility as a local human to fight for our water. The only way I know how to is through performance art. It's an form with mortality & it can affect people mortally.  I will dedicate my life to ending this squandering capitalist spineless stupidity that is occurring in our backyards. with your help I can make an impact.

Nathan

PS...read these:

http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2013/oct/21/new-brunswick-fracking-protests


http://halifax.mediacoop.ca/story/rcmp-bring-60-drawn-guns-dogs-assault-rifles-serve/19358


http://leannesimpson.ca/2013/10/20/elsipogtog-everywhere/


http://cultivatingalternatives.com/2013/10/20/dear-rex-colonialism-exists-and-youre-it/


http://www.facebook.com/l.php?u=http%3A%2F%2Fpresscore.ca%2F2012%2Frcmp-supported-by-armed-u-s-infiltrators-attack-first-nations-canadians-to-cover-up-enviroment-canada-raid-of-irving-oil-canaport.html&h=CAQG8qV8q&s=1

and ..

http://m.youtube.com/watch?v=2JhyBcMpqKU

& double PS SHARE THIS CAMPAIGN.


!! HUGE THANK YOU !! TO GIANT BIKES MONTREAL !! & JAKE MADDISON !!

https://www.facebook.com/giantmontreal

story:
Campaign Summary

Simon & his wife Joyce live in a rural part of Eastern Kenya. They are trying to transition from subsistence farming of corn and beans to mango trees. Their region of Kenya is semiarid and punctuated with long dry seasons. This makes traditional crops risky to grow as they are 100% dependent of the rains for water. Special varieties of mangos have been breed to resist the dry seasons and represent a unique opportunity for profitable and sustainable farming in this part of Kenya. Unfortunately, mango saplings are prime targets for domesticated animals during the dry season and without a proper fence, the saplings will be destroyed before they can reach maturity (2-3 years). Please, help Simon and Joyce build a fence around their 61 mango saplings before the next dry season.  

What We Need & What You Get

All of the $3,160 will be use for material and labor, including:

  • The fence will be 250 meters (820 ft) long.
  • It needs 90 cement fence posts (wood posts only last 2-3 years because of the voracious termites in the area).
  • 3 rolls of barbed wire.
  • 15 rolls of chain linked fencing (needed to prevent goats from getting in).
  • 18-20 bags of cement and sand for the post footings.
  • Employment of expert fence builder and laborers.

Our humble offerings for your donations:

  • Donations of any level will receive a thank-you message from Simon and Joyce.
  • Sponsors of $250 or more will have a "Sponsored by... a name of their choosing" carved into a wooden plaque and placed on one of the fence posts.

The Impact

Your donations will make a real difference to Simon and Joyce:

  • With a fence they will be able to keep animals out of their farm, ensuring the mango saplings will develop into strong trees.
  • If Simon and Joyce and successfully transition to mango farming, it will improve their quality of life by providing them with higher incomes and less reliance on unreliable weather.
  • Finally, with a fence and a successful mango orchard, Simon will be able to use his increased earnings to self finance improvements to the rest of his farm.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even of you can't donate you can help us by:

  • Sharing the campaign with your friends and family.
  • Use Indiegogo share tools to share the campaign on social media!

And that's all there is to it.

If Simon and Joyce and successfully transition to mango farming, it will improve their quality of life by providing them with higher incomes and less reliance on unreliable weather.

Finally, with a fence and a successful mango orchard, Simon will be able to use his increased earnings to self finance improvements to the rest of his farm.


    Other Ways You Can Help Even of you can't donate you can help us by:  Sharing the campaign with your friends and family.
Use Indiegogo share tools to share the campaign on social media!   And that's all there is to it.

story:
The 15-Second Elevator Pitch

We're a couple of mid-lifers trying to do something grand before the old folks home claims us. We bought the historic Globe Elevator and started reclaiming its old-growth wood. But we ran into a recession and fell behind in our loan payments. We need to raise $56,000 to stay afloat long enough to find a new owner. Otherwise, the bank will foreclose and a vast amount of beautiful antique wood will go up in smoke - perhaps literally. In return for your contribution, we're offering a small piece of history and the satisfaction of knowing you are helping the planet by reducing greenhouse gases.

How We Got Here

The Globe Elevator, on the edge of Lake Superior, was the biggest grain storage facility in the world when it was completed in 1887.  Its three mammoth buildings contained over 6 million board feet of old-growth Eastern White Pine from the area’s virgin forests. The elevator was closed in 1988 and our little company, Wisconsin Woodchuck, began deconstructing it in 2006.

Woodchuck is the offspring of David Hozza, a one-time city planner from St. Paul, and Judy Peres, a retired newspaper reporter from Chicago. They put their life savings into the quixotic project and persuaded friends and family to invest too. Unfortunately, a monster recession intervened, drastically slowing demand for specialty reclaimed wood.

The company’s mortgage lender is now threatening to foreclose, and it’s not likely the bank – or whoever buys the 8-acre property at the sheriff’s sale – is going to care about the lumber, given the difficulty of taking it down. Dave and Judy are trying desperately to save the wood before it gets blown up, chipped up, land-filled, or incinerated. It’s probably too late to save the company or recoup any of our investment. But we still have more than 5 million board feet – the equivalent of about 20,000 trees – of irreplaceable old-growth white pine. We need to get this incredible resource into the hands of someone who can continue the task we started, and that could take more time than we have left.  

What We Need & What You Get

It takes approximately $9,000 a month to keep the bank at bay. So if we can raise $56,000, we can buy six months. More would be better, but any amount would be valuable.

The money will not be used for regular operating expenses or salaries. It will cover loan payments ($37,830), taxes ($3,250), insurance ($9,306), attorneys’ fees ($3,000), and a publicity campaign ($2,600) to find a buyer who will carry on our mission to save the wood. We’re already getting some important help in that regard: The hit TV series Ax Men is telling our story. You can watch it at 9 p.m. Eastern (8 p.m. Central) Sundays on the HISTORY Channel.    

Everyone who contributes to this campaign will get a piece of the historic Globe Elevator as well as a big wet one from Dave and Judy. If you dig deep, you could get a fine-art print of a photograph or video still taken during the deconstruction project, or the hard hat worn by one of the crew during the filiming of Ax Men. If you dig really deep, you could get a ride in the crane basket and lunch with Mike, our cantankerous construction manager, in beautiful downtown Superior.

The Impact

You don’t have to be a tree hugger to appreciate the value of preserving a rare resource. Old-growth Eastern White Pine is virtually extinct: The great stands that once covered much of the northeastern United States are gone, and the only way to get it is to reclaim it from an existing structure. The Globe Elevator is the biggest known source of this wood. Simply put, not using it would be a big, fat waste. It’s like your mother said: Eat your dinner, because children somewhere are starving. You’ll feel bad if you waste it. And you won’t get a second chance.

Re-using this wood is good for the end user because it’s beautiful and durable and distinctive and has a great story to tell. But it’s also good for the planet because it reduces harmful greenhouse gases.

Trees remove carbon from the atmosphere in the form of carbon dioxide, and harvested wood continues to store that carbon. If the wood is burned, or left to decay in a landfill, the carbon is released into the atmosphere. What’s more, green trees will be cut down and processed to replace what’s lost – or builders will use alternative materials with a much bigger carbon footprint. Do you want that on your conscience?

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute, that’s OK. You can support the project in other ways:

  • Tell your friends about the campaign to Save the Globe by sharing it on Facebook, Twitter, and other social media
  • Share our video on YouTube
  • Watch us in Ax Men on HISTORY and let the producers of the show know you think what Wisconsin Woodchuck is doing is important
  • Spread the word about how reclaiming lumber helps the planet
  • Visit our Web site, sign up for our newsletter and our blog, and tell your friends to do the same
  • Use the “SHARE” tools on the Indiegogo site

story:
Summary

Climbers are nature people. They’re nature people who get to enjoy the views from places the rest of us only dream of. Looking down from the face of a rock wall, or the peak of a valley, it’s hard not to embrace the raw beauty of our planet. Gaining the sense that not only do we need to live in harmony with nature, but we are a part of it. It is with this love of the land that climbers around the globe are putting their minds and bodies to raise money for the Mindfulness Project. Money to replenish and protect the forests, starting in the north east of Thailand.

On the 29th and 30th of November climbers engaged to the saving of our planet climbed the height of Mount Everest in various locations simultaneously in order to attract attention to the global problem of deforestations and to raise funds to make the World a better place to live.

Background

The Mindfulness Project is a worldwide, spiritually based community dedicated to serve humanity. They strive to create a world where people live harmoniously with each other and with nature. It is run by Christian Carow and Anja Carow, originally from Germany. They decided to live in Thailand 5 years ago, and to build a community there.

Problem

It’s unfathomable to think about how much of Earth we have destroyed, how many trees have been cut down, oceans have been poisoned, how much land we’ve dug up. Statistic show, that if we continue to progress forward with these processes of destruction (development) within 20 years Thailand will have no forests left. It’s time to work with nature and understand it, not against it and destroy it.

In the North East of Thailand, already 98% of forests have been culled leaving the soil depleted of minerals, preventing water retention and making the areas virtually un-farmable.  The people of the region, specifically where the Mindfulness Project is situated, are at a loss. With no water, poor farming land and limited access to other sources of income they are just one example of the devastating effects caused by living against nature.

Solution

The solutions to our current problems and ways of life exist, and they exist in the many. Albert Einstein can be quoted: “You can’t fix a problem with the same mindset that created it”. Real and lasting change comes with education and demonstration and needs to be accessible by the masses. Using the most up to date and proven systems including permaculture and agro-forestry, alongside traditional Thai farming techniques, the Mindfulness Project is working on community land to create a fully functioning model for sustainable living. This community project will demonstrate established food forests, the reintroduction of native flora and fauna, erosion prevention, organic farming, crop rotation and varying methods of water retention, just to start. At the forefront of the project will be a learning centre where leading experts will teach both Thai and foreign students techniques for farming in harmony with nature to create better yield while sustaining, and in many cases, improving soil quality. This site will also be used to demonstrate the beauty, functionality and wonder of the forests and will serve as a platform for educating people about the important role forests play in creating balance on our planet.

The Mindfulness Project has a dream: buy land, plant forests and ensure those forests are protected for the future. In order to fulfill this dream, they founded a charity in Germany to collect money to buy land and turn it into beautiful forest.

Everybody at the Mindfulness Project is dedicated to create a future that has fresh water, clean air and fertile soil and willingly give their time so that all income can go directly to this cause. Even the visiting volunteers that work at the project, pay for their stay so that 100% of donations to the charity get planted in the ground. But as Dr Suess say “unless someone like you cares a whole awful lot, nothing is going to get better. It's not.” With the forest being torn down at a net rate of 9.4 million hectares a year, we need more people working to protect the last standing forests and replenishing those that have been cut down.

It’s time for change, it’s time for big change, and the change starts at the Mindfulness Project.

What we need

1. We need 110.000 EUR to buy a piece of farm land, turn it back into rain forest and subsequently into a nature reserve.

2. The figure above also helps to legally fight off an oil company that plans to frack on that land.

3. We need 1000 EUR in order to purchase a woodchipper (woodchippers help to revitalise old soil in order to grow plants effectively).

4. We need 10.000 EUR to purchase a new pick-up truck for the transport of plants, tools and natural building material.

We know we cannot do everything in one day, that’s why we start our first campaign with a smaller target. It’s enough to continue our work in short term.

When will we see the difference?

We've been working on our project for 5 years now. We're not waiting for donations, we're making progress every day. You can see the difference if you come to visit us, and you can also help us with your voluntary work.

You can also follow us on our website: http://charity.mindfulness-project.org/

Other Ways You Can Help

Sharing this campaign with your friends, family, and networks like Facebook and Twitter is super important - so more people will have the chance to participate!

story:
1. Mycological Remediation Of Slash/Beetle-Kill/Erosion For Restoration And Promoting Fire Mitigation

In Nederland, the current fire mitigation wood slash removal is an inefficient use of forest nutrient resources, is not helpful and creating a larger carbon footprint for the town. It is proposed the slash to be viewed as and transformed into an asset for forest health to be integrated into unstable slopes  to prevent erosion. This process will filter toxins, stabilize the ecosystem through redistributing  vital nutrients to the forest floor. Town residents would be benefiting by receiving an expandable mushroom culture for use in gardens and water conservation. 

 

This process would involve inoculating slash piles with locally grown cultured varieties of Reishi (Ganoderma Lucidium) and  North American Oyster( Pleurotis Ostrealis) mycelium. Mycelium could be used to help manage the risk of wildfires from ground wood while  aiding in soil buildup in the forest thus encouraging future growth, water retention and biodiversity. We will be implementing a monitoring progress and reporting back to funders as regularly as they like.

 

itemized budget:

$500 for  Liquid Tissue Culture(Mycelium)

$200 Laboratory Operating Fees( electric, water, rent) 

$100 Transport 

$100Volunteer Support( Example: Snacks  for volunteers on group work days)

$100 newspaper, radio, and social media advertising for  community work days

 

The implementation of this process will be conducted by a local team comprised of agents from IMC and NedCompost who report to the SAB.Through this ecological restoration project, our team will expand upon the existing local culture of non-violence towards our environment in the Nederland community. I will report on behalf of our team monthly on project evolution to both the Mountain Forum for Peace and the Nederland Sustainbility Advisory Board. We could incorporate groups in town like Saws and Slaws, NedCompost, Teens Inc, Community Centert Foundation, Town, County, NedFest, Peak to Peak Healthy Communities Project, Ned Communiiy Garden, and Ned Seniors to our field team so that we can address larger community needs, and promote community environmental stewardship. 

 

 

Here is a link to a larger version of the type of project we are planning. They were in Montana so the actual strains of both mushrooms and trees will be different but the basic idea is the same. 

http://plantsciences.montana.edu/facultyorstaff...

story:
Short Summary

Hello, I am Clara Silvie, a retired teacher and I currently serve as President of Campti Field of Dreams, Inc. Campti Field of Dreams is the 501(c)3 nonprofit organization that operates the Campti Historic Museum in the old Citizens Bank and Trust in Campti, Louisiana. I am a 30 year resident of the Town of Campti, the oldest settlement on the Red River. Since 2001 I have served as the volunteer curator at the Campti Historic Museum. The building is owned by the Natchitoches Parish Government and up until recently the Town of Campti paid the utilities. Now Campti Field of Dreams has to assume the operating expenses as well as plan for the maintenance of the museum.

Fortunately, there are several historic preservation grants that would assist us in rehabilitating the building and creating a plan for downtown Campti that would help revitalize this distressed community. However, these grants require a 1:1 local cost share match. So for us to get a grant for $5,000 we need to have a $5,000 cash match. This is where you come in. Please help us to raise $8,600 to save this historic structure and provide a little hope for the people of Campti, where 4 out of 10 people are living in poverty.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $8,600 to keep the doors open and plan for the future.

$3,600 will keep our lights on and doors open for the next year. This will cover our basic utilities, phone, internet and insurance which is budgeted at $300 per month. The museum is operated by an all volunteer staff so none of this money will go to salaries.

$5,000 will be used as a cash match for grant applications to plan for the rehabilitation of the building and develop a design plan for historic Campti. In 2013, both Clara Silvie, President and Donna Isaacs, Executive Director, received diversity scholarships to the National Trust for Historic Preservation's annual conference in Indianapolis, Indiana where they were able to meet with Ray Scriber (Louisiana MainStreet and CLG) and Jessica Richardson (Louisiana SHPO) and learn about the process of nominating the Town of Campti to the National Register for Historic Places. To do this we need to hire consultants to research, document and develop the nomination to the National Register. In addition a preservation architect is needed to develop design guidelines for the community.

In appreciation for your generous support, we have some wonderful thank you gifts for you. Depending on the amount you contribute you can get all sorts of fun goodies like personalized certificates, t-shirts, posters featuring the historic Citizens Bank, autographed books by local author Dee Scriber with her candid humor, and handmade quilts from our local quilting circle that meets in the museum from 11-2 Tuesday through Friday.

While we are hoping that with your help we will be able to meet and maybe even exceed our goal but if we don't  we will use what we get pay our utilities so that we can keep our doors open and continue the campaign to save the building and help to revitalize the community.

The Impact

Campti is the oldest settlement on the Red River, but it's contribution to American History is relatively unknown. While most people have heard of the Lewis and Clark Expedition during Thomas Jefferson's presidency but very few have heard of the Freeman-Custis Expedition which was funded at the same time and began in Campti, Louisiana. Campti was also where Captain Shreve began to clear the Great Raft to open the Red River for commerce between Campti and Shreveport. The timber industry that created the log jam in Campti that required the services of Captain Shreve is the same timber industry that kept many Americans working during the great depression. Even though Campti was one of the towns that was burned by Union soldiers as they retreated down the Red River as part of the Red River Campaign, it was rebuilt and became a major part of the economic engine for Central Louisiana. 

Campti has a story to tell and its rich past can help to revitalize this community for generations to come. Please help us to research and document Campti's rich history in its entirety so that it can take its rightful place in America's history.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that things are tight and you may not be able to offer financial support at this time, but that doesn't mean you can’t help:

  • Help us to get the word out. Please tell all your friends and family about our campaign. Let them know that we are trying to save the museum and help preserve the community. Visit: www.camptifieldofdreams.org
  • If you are on FaceBook, please share this online. https://www.facebook.com/camptifieldofdreams
Your advocacy for our campaign can make the difference between success and failure.

And that’s all there is to it.

The timber industry that created the log jam in Campti that required the services of Captain Shreve is the same timber industry that kept many Americans working during the great depression. Even though Campti was one of the towns that was burned by Union soldiers as they retreated down the Red River as part of the Red River Campaign, it was rebuilt and became a major part of the economic engine for Central Louisiana. Campti has a story to tell and its rich past can help to revitalize this community for generations to come. Please help us to research and document Campti's rich history in its entirety so that it can take its rightful place in America's history.Other Ways You Can HelpWe understand that things are tight and you may not be able to offer financial support at this time, but that doesn't mean you can’t help:
Help us to get the word out. Please tell all your friends and family about our campaign. Let them know that we are trying to save the museum and help preserve the community. Visit: www.camptifieldofdreams.org

If you are on FaceBook, please share this online. https://www.facebook.com/camptifieldofdreams

Your advocacy for our campaign can make the difference between success and failure.And that’s all there is to it.

story:
BES Expedition to Norway, Finnmark

During the expedition we will be carrying out field work studies on the glaciers in that area, including; glaciology, geology, photography, wildlife, plant surveys and environmental engineering projects, to assess the effects of global warming on glaciers. As well as the field work we will also be mountaineering, and travelling across the glacier where we will often camp on the ice, we will also be working alongside highly experienced experts from the royal geographical society.

£2500 pounds is a lot of money! Somehow I have managed to raise £1600 even though I have been pretty busy with exams and all, much of it came from charitable trusts, to reach my goal i am going to kayak the length of the river Avon a journey of over 100 miles and hopefully with your sponsorship i will reach my target! 

 I also believe that the adventurous experiences would be phenomenal and would help me develop a sense of self-reliance, and leadership skills. I am also studying geography at A-level and plan to carry it on and do a degree at university, the opportunities available on the expedition would not only benefit me personally, but it would also help me get into a good university by supporting my UCAS as well as appearing on my CV.

If you want to contact me you can do so by email or letter:

alexander.hyde@btconnect.com

Fernbank, Kissing-tree-lane, Alveston

Stratford-upon-avon, Warks

CV377QS

story:
***UPDATE*** WHAT I CAN DO WITH EXTRA $1,000:

Wow, thank you to all for your support! I am incredibly excited and am preparing my move to San Jose De Bocay. This week, I am buying the machinery, establishing lodging in Bocay, and renting a truck and hiring a driver.

In recent preparations, I am discovering more costs as well as more opportunities.

What I can do with an extra $1,000:

  • Transport machinery from Laguna del Apoyo to Managua ($100)
  • Cover full cost of transportation (car rental, driver, gas, insurance) to Bocay (additional $200, $350 total)
  • Build a drying rack for the briquette production line ($100)
  • Build a shed for machine and briquette storage ($200)
  • Unexpected costs ($400)

****************************************************************************

Short Summary

My name is Caleb Hopler, and I am a recent graduate from Virginia Tech. During my time attaining my B.S. in Environmental Resource Management, I visited Nicaragua twice for internships and eco-tourism, and simply fell in love with the country and its culture. After graduation, I decided to head back to Nicaragua to seek sustainability and entrepreneurship, my two greatest passions.

After spending some time in Nicaragua and talking with local communities, businesses, and international non-profits and NGOs, it became clear to me that there is a great need for both waste reduction and an alternative energy use for cooking and heating other than wood. Trash collects in the streets and trees are being cut down in great amounts, often illegally. Factories use up to 6 truckloads of firewood PER DAY, and the smoke produced from woodburning in homes cause respiratory diseases and shorter lifespans in families, especially the women who spend all day in the home, cooking and cleaning.

Firewood is also expensive, often up to 25 Cordobas (equivalent to USD$0.89). Since the average daily income is about $6 to $8, firewood is 5-8% of the daily income.

Briquettes, or compressed combustable organic material, may just be an answer to these issues.

By utilizing sawdust and agricultural wastes, such as maize stalks and rise husks, and by discovering the proper blends for the briquettes, these quick and easy to use energy sources can be made by local communities (largely for free) and sell the briquettes for income, thus creating jobs. When blended right, the briquettes can provide more energy for longer (than firewood) and produce far less smoke. Because the raw material is largely free, briquettes can be sold for only 1 or 2 Cordobas each. Since a production team can produce up to about 120 briquettes per hour, daily income can increase to $8 to $10, which is higher than the national average.

The dream is to lead a briquette-producing company with a social component. I would love to see a change in the heart of the country, its capital city Managua, where the major factories and businesses switch from burning wood to burning briquettes for energy, which reduces deforestation and slows deforestation.

Secondly, production teams of mothers looking for work would be trained in rural communities in efforts to empower women, create jobs, and decrease disease caused by wood smoke pollutants. 

Socially, reforestation education would be widely spread through these communities, encouraging tree plantings and trash pickup for healthy forests.

The possibilities and benefits are far-reaching, and there are many ways to contribute. I need your help to get this started.

What I Need For This Project

After much research and meeting with several NGOs, non-profits, and mentors in Nicaragua, I am ready to begin the project.

I need to first create a proof of concept. This requires discovering the best blends utilizing local wastes, educating families about the benefits of briquettes, and stirring up excitement about switching over to this energy source.

I believe the best place for me to start is in San Jose de Bocay, a rural community in northern Nicaragua. I have been there 3 times before, spending a total of about 4 weeks there. I have many connections and close friends there willing to help and can stay in a family's home while I get this project started.

What I need and its costs:

  • Briquette Metal Press $200
  • Organic Material Thresher Machine $200
  • Tools $100
  • Personal transport to San Jose de Bocay $150
  • 2-Month Living Expenses (Lodging, Food, Local Transport) $850
This amounts to $1,500 total.
Any amount toward this endeavor helps and is greatly appreciated. Even $10 is a great help: I only need $10 from 150 people to get this proof of concept under way!
Please note that this fundraising is only for the proof of concept, which will last 1-2 months in San Jose de Bocay. If found to be a success, I will be able to go into an official round of production that will reach both Managua and San Jose de Bocay. This will kickstart another round of investing, where I will seek grant money and higher level investments.


Other Ways You Can Help

There greater traffic this site gets, the better! Please share this through Facebook, email, twitter, word-of-mouth, prayer chains, social or church groups, and any other network you would like to share this with.


Thank you for your time! Together, we can help transform lives and work to create a healthier world :)

This amounts to $1,500 total.
