This will kickstart another round of investing, where I will seek grant money and higher level investments.   

    Other Ways You Can Help There greater traffic this site gets, the better! Please share this through Facebook, email, twitter, word-of-mouth, prayer chains, social or church groups, and any other network you would like to share this with.

Thank you for your time! Together, we can help transform lives and work to create a healthier world :)

story:
In Crisis Lies Opportunity

Building on the great accomplishments of the 60 day Indiegogo portion of this campaign, which ended on 2/1/15, this urgent fundraising effort remains active throughout 2015.  All the information below seeking to get a vessel to the Vanua-tai remains current.  While you can no longer make a donation through Indiegogo, you can review this campaign and, if inspired, make a tax deductible donation throughout the year directly through The Ocean Foundation's Friends of Island Reach at: 

http://oceanfdn.org/donate/island-reach


We are also at: www.BerkshireSweetGold.com

email: bsgfarm@peoplepc.com

Please reach out with any questions. 

Kind regards,   Janis & Brooks

           Research Vessel Llyr ("of the sea")

In an era of collapsing biological and cultural diversity, Vanuatu is one of our planet's last great places.  Lying west of Fiji and on the eastern edge of The Coral Sea, this remote archipelago of 83 islands and open ocean is home to a vast treasure trove of biological riches -- from coral reefs to mangrove and rain forests -- and an enduring interdependence between its people and their natural environment.  The archipelago's conservation champions and best hope are the Vanua-tai  (Land & Sea),  a remarkable Indigenous group of 400 environmental stewards crafting local solutions to global crises.  The Vanua-tai have asked Island Reach, a unique, US-based conservation project operating in Vanuatu, to provide a vessel for the Vanua-tai.  Working on board Research Vessel Llyr, Island Reach is partnering with them to fill transportation gaps  and provide a mobile work platform, skilled and professional services and training, and greater opportunities for collaboration and exchange among the Vanua-tai.


WE NEED YOUR FINANCIAL SUPPORT TO MAKE THIS HAPPEN! Although this Indiegogo campaign is closed, our fundraising effort continues independently throughout 2015 and donations can be made to The Ocean Foundation for Friends of Island Reach:

http://oceanfdn.org/donate/island-reach



The intimate relationship between Ni-Vanuatu  (the people of Vanuatu) and their lands and seas finds expression in the densest language diversity on the planet, with over 120 languages in active use!  In most of Vanuatu's 1000 villages, there is no electricity, there are no roads, and small boat motors are rare.   Work -- from fishing to forest farming -- is done with skilled hands.  Vanuatu is in a race to protect this rich heritage from the rapidly intensifying effects of climate change, extractive industries such as logging, mining, and foreign fishing fleets, and population shifts.

                                                             Children of Futuna

  Now, more than ever, there is urgent need for these volunteers to work with their village Chiefs, farmers, fishers, and families to build sustainable solutions.  The  Vanua-tai are eager to engage;  they know what they need: but for many of them, especially those in remote locations, access to resources, training, and opportunities for exchange is insufficient to meet the sheer number of mounting challenges.  As a result, many Vanua-tai are struggling with projects that are stalled or under-developed.

Headed offshore to Cook's Reef with Vanua-tai and Emae villagers.  (Aqualung USA snorkel packs donated to Island Reach for distribution in Vanuatu.)

What is Island Reach?

Island Reach is a volunteer, ocean-going project in Vanuatu, conceived and built by a New England farming family headed by a couple of social scientists trained in Human Ecology and Cultural Anthropology.  

As forest farmers, we've spent many years developing strategies to support small-scale harvesters and we've spoken widely about food, economies, culture, and the environment.  In 2010, with dire reports about the state of the planet and our oceans on the rise, we were compelled to greater action. 

Our plan was to target the resource shortages that impede conservation efforts in island and coastal settings.  This was a personal and professional decision that involved mortgaging the farm, purchasing and refitting Research Vessel Llyr, and training as offshore "bluewater" mariners.  Harvesting a perennial crop meant that our work schedule could be adjusted so that we could be on the farm for half the year and spend the other half working in a biological and cultural conservation hotspot.

Island Reach now operates Research Vessel Llyr and partners with local communities and regional groups in Vanuatu -- a vast archipelago of islands spanning 600 nautical miles -- to build social and environmental resilience from ridge to reef.

Island Reach was conceived and built precisely to serve an Indigenous group of conservation stewards like the Vanua-tai.

"Island Reach has supported partners in Vanuatu to fill critical extension and information gaps in the most remote, unconnected and vulnerable communities. The training and capacity building they have provided with indigenous Networks like the Nguna-Pele Marine and Land Protected Area Network and Tasi Vanua Resource Management Network and with individual communities has contributed to resilience building across the country.  Having PhD scientists engaging directly with communities is a rare and invaluable voluntary contribution to the nation of Vanuatu." 

Dr. Christopher Y Bartlett, Country Director SPC-GIZ  

In crisis lies opportunity

We can all respond and get the Vanua-tai conservation champions the core services and resources they need to thrive in one of our world's biocultural hotspots;  or... they risk being "snowed under" by the escalating intensity of changes on their doorstep.

What your donation will do 

Your contribution will fuel Island Reach's direct actions for the Vanua-tai.  We'll provide them with a broad range of essential resources, services, and actions, at no-cost to them:

  • Live-aboard and transport costs for Vanua-tai and training partners as well as participating marine biologists and other specialists.
  • Fabrication of collection hooks and bags, and purchase of injection guns for Crown of Thorns starfish mitigation;  supplies to construct coral gardening frames.
  • Transportation of conservation and food & water security materials:  e.g., water collection tanks & systems; construction supplies; agroforestry/agriculture & aquaculture resources such as seedlings, fish stocks, erosion control plants.
  • Operation and maintenance of snorkel equipment,  dive compressor, tanks and gear and RV Llyr's First Responder dive tender. 
  • Educational outreach: e.g., maintenance of portable video equipment and generator for community presentations; reef survey and coral gardening training and tool kits; Crown of Thorns mitigation; copying of DVD and paper instructional materials concerning climate change, coral reefs, agroecology, and food security strategies.
  • Identifying species at risk and options for establishing community-managed conservation areas.
  • Cultural anthropology-oriented documentary film productions for a) filming village reefs & actions for local community awareness and school presentations; and b) films for wider audiences & supporters.
  • Delivery of construction skills for conservation projects: electrical, mechanical, building, plumbing, motors, alternative energy.
  • Delivery of intellectual resources: expertise in agroforestry, permaculture & food security adaptations; reef ecology and reef husbandry; experience in climate change adaptation and carbon farming;  artisanal harvesting and direct market practices that advantage family-scale producers; citizen science methodologies for surveying coral reefs, marine, and forest ecosystems.

As we direct all of our farm's available resources to Island Reach, we are fundraising to reach the minimum budget that will allow us to return to Vanuatu in 2015 between April and September.  Any additional funds raised will go to expanding Island Reach support of urgent Vanua-tai conservation projects in the archipelago.

provides oversight of the Island Reach budget.     

Buninga Island Water Security Project 

Who are the Vanua-tai?

The Vanua-tai Resouce Monitor Network was created 20 years ago by the renowned community arts and activist organization, Wan Smolbag (read: "one small bag"). Initially established to address the decline of turtle populations around the main island of Efate, the group has greatly expanded its mission in response to mounting pressures in the archipelago.  Today, the Vanua-tai work with their communities across Vanuatu to develop strategies for dealing with issues ranging from coastal erosion to coral reefs in crisis, from climate change impacts on food and water security to sustainable tourism, to protecting species at risk and establishing marine and land conservation areas. 

The network has grown to over 400 community volunteers, individuals woven into the social fabric of their villages and islands who have stepped forward to be agents of positive change.  They act as cultural mediaries, building connections between traditional ecological knowledge and practices that have evolved over generations and Western science-based information and methods.

Reef Guardians hunting Crown of Thorn starfish with Island Reach crew.

By helping their own communities and ecosystems, the Vanua-tai are benefiting all of us by helping stem the great wave of extinctions.  By some estimates, we are losing up to 140,000 plant and animal species a year.  On average, one language disappears every 14 days, and with it usually goes unique ecological knowledge about the Earth.  80% of the planet's biological diversity and 95% of its cultural diversity resides in the homelands of Indigenous peoples.  Empowering the Vanua-tai is a critical part of achieving global conservation goals.

                                                      Crab Bay, Malekula Island

Internationally, the Vanua-tai are a model of Indigenous Peoples designing and implementing locally appropriate and culturally sensitive adaptive strategies. Their work can enrich global dialogues and strengthen global alliances responding to the collapse of biological and cultural diversity.

                      Vanua-tai meeting                                        An educational coral garden

"We are establishing sub-networks for the Vanua-tai to improve collaboration and services.  We currently have nine sub-networks in place with more in development.  Island Reach will get out to the more remote islands to deliver training and services and support new sub-networks so that no one lags behind."                                                   Donald James, Vanua-tai Coordinator                                                 

                  

"Wan Smolbag (WSB) is a Vanuatu registered non-profit that serves a wide array of community interests throughout the Vanuatu archipelago. WSB has over 400 registered Vanua tai (Land & Sea) Resource Monitors ......We're excited about collaborating with Island Reach and having RV Llyr as a mobile service platform for the Vanua-tai in 2015." Michael Taurakoto, Chief Executive Officer, Wan Smolbag Theatre

  • Have a look at some of the multi-tasking services Island Reach delivered in 2014 for many groups, including the Vanua-tai:    

 Please pitch in--Donate!--and let's get resources like these to the Vanua-tai in 2015!

          The girls of Sangalai, Meskalyne Islands

What makes Island Reach Different?

  • We're efficient

-- Island Reach is lean and focused on direct action.

--We work with our hands and have mechanical and construction skills.  We do our own maintenance and refit on RV Llyr, allowing more funds to go directly to projects.

--Island Reach is ready to multitask, folding numerous projects into the same expedition, saving resources and encouraging collaboration.

--Offshore marine vessels are notoriously costly to operate and maintain.   Conditions are rough, the ocean is relentlessly corrosive, and complex, rugged materials must be well maintained with backups for safety.  This is one important reason such vital resources are mostly unavailable to conservation workers in archipelagos.  Research Vessel Llyr, built in Europe, is a modest sized, heavy displacement, steel work-yacht, ketch-rigged for sail with sturdy hardware.  Llyr was carefully selected and fitted for proven efficiency, durability and low cost of operations.

  • We're a family of farmers

--Internationally, family farming is recognized for its important economic, cultural, and environmental roles (2014, International Year of Family Farming).  Most Ni-Vanuatu are skilled subsistence and artisanal harvesters, feeding their families and securing small incomes from working land and sea.

--We know first hand about connections between labor and the land.  We're sensitive to the economic, generational, and environmental challenges that farm & fisher families face around the globe. 

--As a vessel with kids on board, we aim to make forest and ocean conservation cool and fun for young people! Today's youth need to be inspired by possibilities and instilled with hope and a sense of adventure.

  • We take a holistic approach

--We're human ecologists which means we focus on relationships between people and our environments.  Our approach is interdisciplinary.  Advanced training in the social sciences of cultural anthropology and psychology gives us deeper understandings of forces which shape collective action, and the importance of self-representation for Indigenous Peoples. 

  • We engage risk through careful planning and training

After roughly 15,000 nautical miles at sea and five years of training and volunteer work from the coast of Maine to Dominican Republic, Haiti, Panama, and across the South Pacific Ocean States of French Polynesia, Cook Islands, Tonga, and Fiji, working towards our destination of Vanuatu, we've build a dynamic project that:

--attests to our resourcefulness and fortitude when encountering adversity.

--demonstrates creativity, passion and dedication.

--has been well received in both the US and Vanuatu with new partners, like Mission Blue, coming on board to pitch in.

  • We keep you connected!

    --We stay in touch with  Island Reach Videos  and social media!

    --Half of the year we're in the US engaged in Island Reach development and public/professional outreach, working the farm, and meeting BSG-Farm's community of customers.  We bring all of us a little closer to land and sea; from ridge to reef!

                                                                              350 Pacific Vanuatu Climate Change Warrior

                                                   Family "palm-frond" sailing home to Lamen Island from their forest garden


        What you can do right now!

    Many of you have known our family for years as friends and neighbors, and as members of our farm-to-table community;  many of you are just meeting us for the first time.  We're asking all of you to be the wind in Island Reach sails and partner with the Vanua-tai, invigorating this remarkable network and helping build their capacity for creativity and innovation, collaboration, and long-term sustainability.  Together, we can protect one of the planet's last great places for all of us and for future generations.

    Let's get a vessel to the Vanua-tai! 


    Please make a tax deductible donation and begin enjoying the many tangible and intangible benefits of this rare opportunity!

    go to The Ocean Foundation's Friend of Fund Island Reach at:

    http://oceanfdn.org/donate/island-reach


    There are other vital ways you can pitch in:

    ---Share this story with family, friends and colleagues.                                                

    ---Learn more about oceans in crisis and the sixth wave of extinction and share this knowledge with those around you.                                                                       

    --Help find new venues to host Island Reach multi-media, ridge to reef presentations.

    ---This fundraising campaign extends into January 2015.   We hope this suits some folks' giving plans who might be interested in donating in the new tax year as well.


    Thanks and warm regards,

    Janis & Brooks, Connor, Rowan & Gavin  

    Janis Steele, Ph.D. & Brooks McCutchen, Ph.D.                                                              Island Reach and Research Vessel Llyr, Vanuatu                                                                     & Berkshire Sweet Gold Maple Farm, Heath, MA                                                   farmhouse: 413-337-8301                                                                                                   website:    www.berkshiresweetgold.com                                                                   

    email:  bsgfarm@peoplepc.com


    Island Reach collaborates with many partners in the US and Vanuatu:

    The Ocean Foundation, Mission  Blue, Aqualung USA, Wan Smolbag, GIZ-SPC Coping with Climate Change in the South Pacific, Vanuatu Scuba Operators Association, Vanuatu Depts. of Fisheries and Tourism, Live & Learn Vanuatu,  Vanuatu Society of Disabled Peoples.

         

                      Founder of the Vanua-tai


    Coping with Climate Change in the South Pacific


    Supplies Snorkel Packs to Island Reach for Vanua-tai & schools


      350 Pacific Climate Change Activists   


        Training volunteers to carry out reef check survey    



                                                                       One Earth--Four Hemispheres--from Ridge to Reef

services and training, and greater opportunities for collaboration and 
exchange among the Vanua-tai. WE NEED YOUR FINANCIAL SUPPORT TO MAKE THIS HAPPEN! Although this Indiegogo campaign is closed, our fundraising effort continues independently throughout 2015 and donations can be made to The Ocean Foundation for Friends of Island Reach:http://oceanfdn.org/donate/island-reachThe intimate relationship between Ni-Vanuatu  (the people of Vanuatu) and their lands and seas finds expression in the densest language diversity on the planet, with over 120 languages in active use!  In most of Vanuatu's 1000 villages, there is no electricity, there are no roads, and small boat motors are rare.   Work -- from fishing to forest farming -- is done with skilled hands.  Vanuatu is in a race to protect this rich heritage from the rapidly intensifying effects of climate change, extractive industries such as logging, mining, and foreign fishing fleets, and population shifts.                                                              Children of Futuna  Now, more than ever, there is urgent need for these volunteers to work with their village Chiefs, farmers, fishers, and families to build sustainable solutions.  The  Vanua-tai are eager to engage;  they know what they need: but for many of them, especially those in remote locations, access to resources, training, and opportunities for exchange is insufficient to meet the sheer number of mounting challenges.  As a result, many Vanua-tai are struggling with projects that are stalled or under-developed. Headed offshore to Cook's Reef with Vanua-tai and Emae villagers.  (Aqualung USA snorkel packs donated to Island Reach for distribution in Vanuatu.)What is Island Reach?
Island Reach is a volunteer, ocean-going project in Vanuatu, conceived and built by a New England farming family headed by a couple of social scientists trained in Human Ecology and Cultural Anthropology.  As forest farmers, we've spent many years developing strategies to support small-scale harvesters and we've spoken widely about food, economies, culture, and the environment.  In 2010, with dire reports about the state of the planet and our oceans on the rise, we were compelled to greater action.  Our plan was to target the resource shortages that impede conservation efforts in island and coastal settings.  This was a personal and professional decision that involved mortgaging the farm, purchasing and refitting Research Vessel Llyr, and training as offshore "bluewater" mariners.  Harvesting a perennial crop meant that our work schedule could be adjusted so that we could be on the farm for half the year and spend the other half working in a biological and cultural conservation hotspot.Island Reach now operates Research Vessel Llyr and partners with local communities and regional groups in Vanuatu -- a vast archipelago of islands spanning 600 nautical miles -- to build social and environmental resilience from ridge to reef. Island Reach was conceived and built precisely to serve an Indigenous group of conservation stewards like the Vanua-tai.

"Island Reach has supported partners in Vanuatu to
fill critical extension and information gaps in the most remote,
unconnected and vulnerable communities.  The training and capacity
building they have provided with indigenous Networks like the
Nguna-Pele Marine and Land Protected Area Network and Tasi Vanua
Resource Management Network and with individual communities has
contributed to resilience building across the country.  Having PhD
scientists engaging directly with communities is a rare and
invaluable voluntary contribution to the nation of Vanuatu."  
Dr. Christopher Y Bartlett, Country Director SPC-GIZ   
In crisis lies opportunity
 We can all respond and get the Vanua-tai 
conservation champions the core services and resources they need to 
thrive in one of our world's biocultural hotspots;  or... they risk being "snowed under" by the escalating intensity of changes on their doorstep.What your donation will do  
Your contribution will fuel Island Reach's direct actions for the Vanua-tai.  We'll provide them with a broad range of essential resources, services, and actions, at no-cost to them:
Live-aboard and transport costs for Vanua-tai and training partners 
as well as participating marine biologists and other specialists.
Fabrication of collection hooks and bags, and purchase of injection 
guns for Crown of Thorns starfish mitigation;  supplies to construct 
coral gardening frames.
Transportation of conservation and food & water security 
materials:  e.g., water collection tanks & systems; construction 
supplies; agroforestry/agriculture & aquaculture resources such as 
seedlings, fish stocks, erosion control plants. 
Operation and maintenance of snorkel equipment,  dive compressor, tanks and gear and RV Llyr's First Responder dive tender. 
Educational outreach: e.g., maintenance of portable video equipment 
and generator for community presentations; reef survey and coral 
gardening training and tool kits; Crown of Thorns mitigation; copying of DVD and paper instructional
 materials concerning climate change, coral reefs, agroecology, and food 
security strategies. 
Identifying species at risk and options for establishing community-managed conservation areas.
Cultural anthropology-oriented documentary film productions for a) 
filming village reefs & actions for local community awareness and 
school presentations; and b) films for wider audiences & supporters.
Delivery of construction skills for conservation projects: 
electrical, mechanical, building, plumbing, motors, alternative energy.
Delivery of intellectual resources: expertise in agroforestry, permaculture & food security adaptations; reef ecology and reef 
husbandry; experience in climate change adaptation and carbon 
farming;  artisanal harvesting and direct market practices that 
advantage family-scale producers; citizen science methodologies for 
surveying coral reefs, marine, and forest ecosystems.
As we direct all of our farm's available resources to Island 
Reach, we are fundraising to reach the minimum budget that will 
allow us to return to Vanuatu in 2015 between April and September.  Any additional funds raised will go to expanding Island Reach support of urgent Vanua-tai conservation projects in the archipelago.  provides oversight of the Island Reach budget.      Buninga Island Water Security Project Who are the Vanua-tai?The Vanua-tai Resouce Monitor Network was created 20 years ago by the renowned community arts and activist organization, Wan Smolbag (read: "one small bag"). Initially established to address the decline of turtle populations around the main island of Efate, the group has greatly expanded its mission in response to mounting pressures in the archipelago.  Today, the Vanua-tai work with their communities across Vanuatu to develop strategies for dealing with issues ranging from coastal erosion to coral reefs in crisis, from climate change impacts on food and water security to sustainable tourism, to protecting species at risk and establishing marine and land conservation areas.  The network has grown to over 400 community volunteers, individuals woven into the social fabric of their villages and islands who have stepped forward to be agents of positive change.  They act as cultural mediaries, building connections between traditional ecological knowledge and practices that have evolved over generations and Western science-based information and methods. Reef Guardians hunting Crown of Thorn starfish with Island Reach crew.By helping their own communities and ecosystems, the Vanua-tai are benefiting all of us by helping stem the great wave of extinctions.  By some estimates, we are losing up to 140,000 plant and animal species a year.  On average, one language disappears every 14 days, and with it usually goes unique ecological knowledge about the Earth.  80% of the planet's biological diversity and 95% of its cultural diversity resides in the homelands of Indigenous peoples.  Empowering the Vanua-tai is a critical part of achieving global conservation goals.                                                       Crab Bay, Malekula Island Internationally, the Vanua-tai are a model of Indigenous Peoples designing and implementing locally appropriate and culturally sensitive adaptive strategies. Their work can enrich global dialogues and strengthen global alliances responding to the collapse of biological and cultural diversity.                       Vanua-tai meeting                                        An educational coral garden
"We are establishing sub-networks for the Vanua-tai to improve collaboration and services.  We currently have nine sub-networks in place with more in development.  Island Reach will get out to the more remote islands to deliver training and services and support new sub-networks so that no one lags behind."                                                   Donald James, Vanua-tai Coordinator                                                  
                   
"Wan
Smolbag (WSB) is a Vanuatu registered non-profit that serves a wide
array of community interests throughout the Vanuatu archipelago. WSB
has over 400 registered Vanua tai (Land & Sea) Resource Monitors
......We're excited about collaborating with Island Reach and having
RV Llyr as a mobile service platform for the Vanua-tai in 2015." Michael Taurakoto, Chief Executive Officer, Wan Smolbag Theatre 
Have a look at some of the multi-tasking services Island Reach delivered in 2014 for many groups, including the Vanua-tai:     
 Please pitch in--Donate!--and let's get resources like these to the Vanua-tai in 2015!          The girls of Sangalai, Meskalyne IslandsWhat makes Island Reach Different? 
We're efficient-- Island Reach is lean and focused on direct action.--We work with our hands and have mechanical and construction skills.  We do our own maintenance and refit on RV Llyr, allowing more funds to go directly to projects.--Island Reach is ready to multitask, folding numerous projects into the same expedition, saving resources and encouraging collaboration.--Offshore marine vessels are notoriously costly to operate and maintain.   Conditions are rough, the ocean is relentlessly corrosive, and complex, rugged materials must be well maintained with backups for safety.  This is one important reason such vital resources are mostly unavailable to conservation workers in archipelagos.  Research Vessel Llyr, built in Europe, is a modest sized, heavy displacement, steel work-yacht, ketch-rigged for sail with sturdy hardware.  Llyr was carefully selected and fitted for proven efficiency, durability and low cost of operations.We're a family of farmers--Internationally, family farming is recognized for its important economic, cultural, and environmental roles (2014, International Year of Family Farming).  Most Ni-Vanuatu are skilled subsistence and artisanal harvesters, feeding their families and securing small incomes from working land and sea. --We know first hand about connections between labor and the land.  We're sensitive to the economic, generational, and environmental challenges that farm & fisher families face around the globe. --As a vessel with kids on board, we aim to make forest and ocean conservation cool and fun for young people! Today's youth need to be inspired by possibilities and instilled with hope and a sense of adventure. We take a holistic approach--We're human ecologists which means we focus on relationships between people and our environments.  Our approach is interdisciplinary.  Advanced training in the social sciences of cultural anthropology and psychology gives us deeper understandings of forces which shape collective action, and the importance of self-representation for Indigenous Peoples. We engage risk through careful planning and trainingAfter roughly 15,000 nautical miles at sea and five years of training and volunteer work from the coast of Maine to Dominican Republic, Haiti, Panama, and across the South Pacific Ocean States of French Polynesia, Cook Islands, Tonga, and Fiji, working towards our destination of Vanuatu, we've build a dynamic project that:--attests to our resourcefulness and fortitude when encountering adversity.--demonstrates creativity, passion and dedication.--has been well received in both the US and Vanuatu with new partners, like Mission Blue, coming on board to pitch in.We keep you connected!
--We stay in touch with  Island Reach Videos  and social media!--Half of the year we're in the US engaged in Island Reach development and public/professional outreach, working the farm, and meeting BSG-Farm's community of customers.  We bring all of us a little closer to land and sea; from ridge to reef!                                                                          350 Pacific Vanuatu Climate Change Warrior                                               Family "palm-frond" sailing home to Lamen Island from their forest garden    What you can do right now!Many of you have known our family for years as friends and neighbors, and as members of our farm-to-table community;  many of you are just meeting us for the first time.  We're asking all of you to be the wind in Island Reach sails and partner with the Vanua-tai, invigorating this remarkable network and helping build their capacity for creativity and innovation, collaboration, and long-term sustainability.  Together, we can protect one of the planet's last great places for all of us and for future generations. Let's get a vessel to the Vanua-tai! Please make a tax deductible donation and begin enjoying the many tangible and intangible benefits of this rare opportunity!go to The Ocean Foundation's Friend of Fund Island Reach at:http://oceanfdn.org/donate/island-reachThere are other vital ways you can pitch in:---Share this story with family, friends and colleagues.                                                 ---Learn more about oceans in crisis and the sixth wave of extinction and share this knowledge with those around you.                                                                         --Help find new venues to host Island Reach multi-media, ridge to reef presentations.---This fundraising campaign extends into January 2015.   We hope this suits some folks' giving plans who might be interested in donating in the new tax year as well.Thanks and warm regards,Janis & Brooks, Connor, Rowan & Gavin   Janis Steele, Ph.D. & Brooks McCutchen, Ph.D.                                                              Island Reach and Research Vessel Llyr, Vanuatu                                                                     & Berkshire Sweet Gold Maple Farm, Heath, MA                                                   farmhouse: 413-337-8301                                                                                                   website:    www.berkshiresweetgold.com                                                                    email:  bsgfarm@peoplepc.comIsland Reach collaborates with many partners in the US and Vanuatu:The Ocean Foundation, Mission  Blue, Aqualung USA, Wan Smolbag, GIZ-SPC Coping with Climate Change in the South Pacific, Vanuatu Scuba Operators Association, Vanuatu Depts. of Fisheries and Tourism, Live & Learn Vanuatu,  Vanuatu Society of Disabled Peoples.                        Founder of the Vanua-taiCoping with Climate Change in the South Pacific Supplies Snorkel Packs to Island Reach for Vanua-tai & schools  350 Pacific Climate Change Activists       Training volunteers to carry out reef check survey                                                                        One Earth--Four Hemispheres--from Ridge to Reef

story:
Summary

I live in Gurgaon, a not so small city bordering New Delhi (India's capital). It is a fast growing city which is growing in a manner which is not sustainable. We have environmental problems such as acute shortage of ground water.

I am trying to gather support for a small group of people I am associated with. They are trying to bring about change in the current state of affairs. They want to plant 1 million trees in Gurgaon. What does this do?

  • This will generate enough oxygen for the entire population of Gurgaon
  • These many trees will intercept near 3.5 billion rainwater every year and put it in the ground
  • These many trees will remove 8,750 million tons of carbon dioxide every year
  • It will make this small part of the planet greener
 

What We Need

This is a multi-year project and we are in year two of this. It is gathering momentum, but we aren't even half way there yet. There is a specific season when the saplings can be planted for ensuring survival and that season for this year is coming around.

Every tree costs roughly $10 to plant and sustain for 3 years. It takes about 3 years for it to establish its roots and become self-sustaining. In the meantime, it has to be watered and protected.

We need as much funding as we get. The $10,000 goal for this campaign is more of a 1000 trees goal. But, the real goal is 1 million trees and this will contribute towards it.

Any money raised through this campaign (even if it doesn't meet the goal) will go directly to the milliontreesgurgaon campaign.

 

Help

You can help in many ways:

  • Spread the word
  • Adopt a tree ($10)
  • Adopt part of a tree (less than $10)
  • Get your corporate to sponsor some trees through CSR channels (contact me, or the team behind milliontreesgurgaon directly from their site)

story:
Permaculture in Action at the Farm!

What We Need & What You Get

Contributors to this campaign will have the opportunity to walk alongside Warren Brush as he shares his insights and perspectives at the Malibu Fig Ranch, witnessing real-life ways to incorporate and apply Permaculture Design and Regenerative Practices. Afterwards, we will enjoy fresh, brick-oven-fired pizza!

The money raised in this campaign will go toward covering the travel and consulting expenses for Warren Brush to visit the farm. Any and all remaining funds will go directly into materials, tools and labor involved in the implementation of Warren's consultation. Welcome to the beginning stages of building a farm and community gathering space full of life and vibrancy!

My Story

Hello and thank you for reading. My name is Nicki Anderson and I started farming organically/sustainably in 2011. 

I was led to agriculture through the lens of food justice: how can farming provide solutions to the socio-economic-cultural divisions and inequity?

Once I started farming, I learned of the environmental and “well-being” solutions also available in land stewardship. 

A few years ago, I left food farming for a career in cannabis because I wanted to earn more income. In a short time, years of bottled-up depression and anxiety exploded and I fell into a dark place, riddled with suicidal fantasy. 

Kerry Clasby (aka “The Intuitive Forager”) called me unexpectedly and asked if I would help her rebuild her farm after she had lost everything in the Woolsey Fire of 2018. I agreed to come out for a few days in April 2019.

Now, more than a year later, I have found life again and am endlessly grateful for the support and recovery the land has provided me. I want to reciprocate that healing and establish a farm that offers life and abundance for all to enjoy.

The Dream

The farm has so much potential for being a demonstrative resource in regenerative agriculture. I want to create this space and share it with community members, near and far.

The contour of the property and the low water pressure (5 gallons per minute!!) have created considerable challenges for me, precluding my ability to expand operations (like planting an orchard and hedgerows!). Government agencies offer excellent support, but their methods and strategies which support farms on a much larger scale don’t necessarily offer the best options for my little plot.

In February, I had the privilege of hearing Warren Brush speak. Not only did his presentation make my heart explode, it also reminded me that even though I “think” I know a lot, I still have SO much more to learn. 

Warren’s resume is impressive (see bio below), but it doesn’t even “brush” the surface of the inspiring impact he has had. He does real work that produces real results. It would be an honor to have him walk the property and consult on projects that can bring recovery and healing to land that has provided so much healing to me. 

With the support of his expertise, we can develop a Holistic system of Farming at the Malibu Fig Ranch that’s suitable for the Demonstration of methods that regenerate our precious resources.

Furthermore, the gifts that he’ll be imparting in the management of this land will be made open to the public by me through classes and workshops I will hold throughout the implementation of regenerating this land.

Other Ways You Can Help

Just because you can't contribute doesn't mean you can't help. If you know someone interested in sustainable agriculture that's in the Los Angeles region that would want to help out or get involved, please forward this along. Help us make some noise. Check out the Indiegogo share tools.

Warren's Bio

Warren Brush is a global resilience design consultant, educator, lecturer and storyteller. He has worked for over 30 years in agroecological education and regenerative system design for communities, private and public organizations, households, farms, and conservation properties worldwide. He is co-founder of Quail Springs Permaculture, Wilderness Youth Project, Papillion Cellars, Practical Resilience Consulting and is an advising founder of the Permaculture Research Institute of Kenya. He was also a member of the USAID’s TOPS team where he helped to develop the Resilience Design Framework and is currently working as a consultant for the USAID Food for Peace funded SCALE award. His efforts with youth globally have spanned working with former child soldiers in West Africa, teaching organic gardening skills with refugee families, inspiring inner-city youth to discover their inherent gifts, to developing unique education programs to inspire nature connection and the expression of their true nature.

Learn more about his work by listening here.

story:
Want to give someone special a special present? Why not donate one of the below items on their behalf and help them make a difference in the world? Please email deborah@earthship.com after you have made your donation and we can send your charitable gift to a person of your choice! Thanks! :)

Who we are...

Biotecture Planet Earth is a registered non-profit organization formed with the goal of expanding the use of affordable, resilient and sustainable buildings around the world while educating the public about the architecture, construction and functionality of these buildings. 

Biotecture Planet Earth was founded by Earthship Biotecture in 2014.  Earthship Biotecture is a global company lead by biotecture expert Michael Reynolds, which for the past 40 years has been focusing on building "radically sustainable buildings" that reduce the impact on the environment all over the world. Michael Reynolds first started experimenting with self sustainable architecture in 1972, and today is a well known and admired leader in the areas of green and self sustainable architecture.

Some examples of previous humanitarian and disaster relief projects have been done in locations such as Haiti, Honduras, Sierra Leone, Guatemala, Bolivia, Andaman Islands and Taos, New Mexico.

Our goal is to raise the funds to finish two important projects!

This campaign aims to fund two upcoming humanitarian projects in both Malawi and the Philippines in early 2015. The objective is to raise $60,000 which will fund the necessary tools and building materials for Malawi's Kapita Community Center Second Hit (January 12-24th, 2015) and the Philippines Windship Finish Hit (February 9th-20th, 2015).

THE PROJECTS:
Malawi Community Center

Earthship Biotecture started working in Malawi in 2013, with the construction of a much needed community center in a remote village called Kapita which is aiming towards self-sustainability and independence from external help. The finished building (Earthship Flower Design) will have 8 rooms and will provide the local community with a bank, a library, a storage room, a women's center, and most importantly, water and power to subsist. 

Two rooms were already completed in 2013, and they are currently being used as safe materials storage and a bank for the 38 surrounding villages, making a huge difference in the community. But due to a lack of funds and time we were not able to complete the build, causing the community to run out of water half way through the dry season. It became clear that we need to go back and finish the building to cover all the community's needs, provide cool shelter, and be able to catch and harvest sufficient water for everyone.


Philippines Windship

Responding to 2014's Typhoon Haiyan, Earthship Biotecture has been joined by a team of local, national and international volunteers building what we call the “Windship” Earthship design in the Philippines. The Windship has evolved from the Simple Survival Earthship design and functions to serve as an aerodynamic storm shelter and school building for a community outside of Tacloban in Leyte Island. 

Partnering with the Earth Village Project and One Block for Batug, Earthship is ready to launch a second hit in order to complete the structure's finishes and to install the power and water systems.  We are also looking to simultaneously building a zero-cost hut in the community made solely from salvaged, local and recycled materials.

Our crew works with our volunteers in training onsite and providing educational presentations throughout the build.  Our goal is to empower all of our participants to implement these techniques in rebuilding resilient structures and creating a more sustainable future.


Why Earthships  

Earthships are buildings that:

  • Heat and cool themselves naturally via solar/thermal dynamics
  •  Collect their own power from the sun and wind
  • Harvest their own water from rain and snow melt
  • Contain and treat their own sewage on site
  • Produce a significant amount of food
  • Are constructed using the byproducts of modern society like cans, bottles and tires.

Earthships include their own utilities made on site. An Earthship uses little to no fossil fuels to provide modern amenities. We are simply adapting basic human needs to the already existing activities of the planet, creating independence for the communities that will benefit from them.

We aim to educate our registered volunteers and local community members of these concepts so they are able to implement these building techniques and further empower their own communities.

Here is what your donation will do:
By donating to our project, you are allowing for all of the necessary tools to be available for our crew and local community members to work and train together!

$20 - Sunscreen for Workers 
Our international and local volunteers work hard and under extreme conditions. We camp and build in extreme temperatures, torrential rains, and anything in between. Water, sunscreen and the appropriate medical kit for emergencies is a must. With your donation, we will be able to provide this to our volunteers and make the project a safer place to be for all participants.


$50 – A Shovel and a Pick
Without the right tools, we would not be able to build these projects. By donating towards these tools, you are not only helping us to fund these projects, but most tools are left behind when the project is over and become a durable resource to the community.


 $100 – A Truckload of Tires
Tires are a byproduct of our society and available in massive quantities. Nevertheless, our projects are in very remote locations and transporting tires and other materials can easily become the most expensive part of our projects. 


 $225 – A solar system
With these projects, we are able to provide communities with essential electricty and light for a long time. The panels generate DC energy which is then stored in batteries and can be used for lighting and to charge essential electrical appliances.


 $350 – A Water Cistern
Both the Philippines and Malawi go through heavy rain periods and then have long dry seasons. Last year we installed one cistern in Malawi and half way through the dry season the community ran out of water and had to go back to getting water from the two only water holes - which are not very hygienic. Rain water catchment and harvesting is therefore very important and a water cistern is key.


 $500 – A Wall of THANKS (completed with a coat of plaster)!
A completed room or structural wall provides shelter, protection from the sun, rain and typhoons, a space to gather, to store, to teach, to learn, to grow... But finishing just one wall or room requires material (steel, cement, clay...), workforce and a lot of dirty hands. By donating towards a finished wall you are providing invaluable safety for an entire community. 

Want to give someone special a special present? Why not donate one of the below items on their behalf and help them make a difference in the world? Please email deborah@earthship.com after you have made your donation and we can send your charitable gift to a person of your choice! Thanks! :)

The impact of your donation goes far and wide

By bringing safe, resilient and sustainable buildings to these remote areas of the world, you are taking part in a revolution in building design and construction. 

By contributing to this campaign, you will be helping to complete sustainable community buildings with and for the people of Malawi and the Philippines.   You will make a difference to these people and to the world.

If you can't contribute…

Sign up as a student and join us! You can join us and participate in either project for a once in a lifetime experience. To do so, a contribution fee of $1,000 USD is required, which all goes toward funding the project and purchasing the materials needed to complete either project. Please visit our website to find out more:  http://www.biotectureplanetearth.com
Join our community and share with your family and friends! We need your help to share this campaign as much as possible so if you are not able to make a donation yourself, please share this with those who think would be able to contribute! Thank you!  https://www.facebook.com/earthship
Thank you for contributing to a more sustainable future!
story_txt:
Want to give someone special a special present? Why not donate one of the below items on their behalf and help them make a difference in the world? Please email deborah@earthship.com after you have made your donation and we can send your charitable gift to a person of your choice! Thanks! :)

Who we are...
Biotecture Planet Earth is a registered non-profit organization formed with the goal of expanding the use of affordable, resilient and sustainable buildings around the world while educating the public about the architecture, construction and functionality of these buildings. 

Biotecture Planet Earth was founded by Earthship Biotecture in 2014.  Earthship Biotecture is a global company lead by biotecture expert Michael Reynolds, which for the past 40 years has been focusing on building "radically sustainable buildings" that reduce the impact on the environment all over the world. Michael Reynolds first started experimenting with self sustainable architecture in 1972, and today is a well known and admired leader in the areas of green and self sustainable architecture.
Some examples of previous humanitarian and disaster relief projects have been done in locations such as Haiti, Honduras, Sierra Leone, Guatemala, Bolivia, Andaman Islands and Taos, New Mexico.


Our goal is to raise the funds to finish two important projects!
This campaign aims to fund two upcoming humanitarian projects in both Malawi and the Philippines in early 2015. The objective is to raise $60,000 which will fund the necessary tools and building materials for Malawi's Kapita Community Center Second Hit (January 12-24th, 2015) and the Philippines Windship Finish Hit (February 9th-20th, 2015).




THE PROJECTS:Malawi Community Center



Earthship Biotecture started working in Malawi in 2013, with the construction of a much needed community center in a remote village called Kapita which is aiming towards self-sustainability and independence from external help. The finished building (Earthship Flower Design) will have 8 rooms and will provide the local community with a bank, a library, a storage room, a women's center, and most importantly, water and power to subsist. 
Two rooms were already completed in 2013, and they are currently being used as safe materials storage and a bank for the 38 surrounding villages, making a huge difference in the community. But due to a lack of funds and time we were not able to complete the build, causing the community to run out of water half way through the dry season. It became clear that we need to go back and finish the building to cover all the community's needs, provide cool shelter, and be able to catch and harvest sufficient water for everyone.


Philippines Windship

Responding to 2014's Typhoon Haiyan, Earthship Biotecture has been joined by a team of local, national and international volunteers building what we call the “Windship” Earthship design in the Philippines. The Windship has evolved from the Simple Survival Earthship design and functions to serve as an aerodynamic storm shelter and school building for a community outside of Tacloban in Leyte Island. 
Partnering with the Earth Village Project and One Block for Batug, Earthship is ready to launch a second hit in order to complete the structure's finishes and to install the power and water systems.  We are also looking to simultaneously building a zero-cost hut in the community made solely from salvaged, local and recycled materials.


Our crew works with our volunteers in training onsite and providing educational presentations throughout the build.  Our goal is to empower all of our participants to implement these techniques in rebuilding resilient structures and creating a more sustainable future.



Why Earthships  



Earthships are buildings that:




Heat and cool themselves naturally via solar/thermal dynamics


 Collect their own power from the sun and wind


Harvest their own water from rain and snow melt


Contain and treat their own sewage on site


Produce a significant amount of food


Are constructed using the byproducts of modern society like cans, bottles and tires.



Earthships include their own utilities made on site. An Earthship uses little to no fossil fuels to provide modern amenities. We are simply adapting basic human needs to the already existing activities of the planet, creating independence for the communities that will benefit from them.


We aim to educate our registered volunteers and local community members of these concepts so they are able to implement these building techniques and further empower their own communities.
Here is what your donation will do:By donating to our project, you are allowing for all of the necessary tools to be available for our crew and local community members to work and train together!
$20 - Sunscreen for Workers Our international and local volunteers work hard and under extreme conditions. We camp and build in extreme temperatures, torrential rains, and anything in between. Water, sunscreen and the appropriate medical kit for emergencies is a must. With your donation, we will be able to provide this to our volunteers and make the project a safer place to be for all participants.
$50 – A Shovel and a PickWithout the right tools, we would not be able to build these projects. By donating towards these tools, you are not only helping us to fund these projects, but most tools are left behind when the project is over and become a durable resource to the community.
 $100 – A Truckload of TiresTires are a byproduct of our society and available in massive quantities. Nevertheless, our projects are in very remote locations and transporting tires and other materials can easily become the most expensive part of our projects. 
 $225 – A solar systemWith these projects, we are able to provide communities with essential electricty and light for a long time. The panels generate DC energy which is then stored in batteries and can be used for lighting and to charge essential electrical appliances.
 $350 – A Water CisternBoth the Philippines and Malawi go through heavy rain periods and then have long dry seasons. Last year we installed one cistern in Malawi and half way through the dry season the community ran out of water and had to go back to getting water from the two only water holes - which are not very hygienic. Rain water catchment and harvesting is therefore very important and a water cistern is key.
 $500 – A Wall of THANKS (completed with a coat of plaster)!A completed room or structural wall provides shelter, protection from the sun, rain and typhoons, a space to gather, to store, to teach, to learn, to grow... But finishing just one wall or room requires material (steel, cement, clay...), workforce and a lot of dirty hands. By donating towards a finished wall you are providing invaluable safety for an entire community. 

Want to give someone special a special present? Why not donate one of the below items on their behalf and help them make a difference in the world? Please email deborah@earthship.com after you have made your donation and we can send your charitable gift to a person of your choice! Thanks! :)

The impact of your donation goes far and wide By bringing safe, resilient and sustainable buildings to these remote areas of the world, you are taking part in a revolution in building design and construction. 

By contributing to this campaign, you will be helping to complete sustainable community buildings with and for the people of Malawi and the Philippines.   You will make a difference to these people and to the world.
If you can't contribute…

Sign up as a student and join us! You can join us and participate in either project for a once in a lifetime experience. To do so, a contribution fee of $1,000 USD is required, which all goes toward funding the project and purchasing the materials needed to complete either project. Please visit our website to find out more:  http://www.biotectureplanetearth.com

Join our community and share with your family and friends! We need your help to share this campaign as much as possible so if you are not able to make a donation yourself, please share this with those who think would be able to contribute! Thank you!  https://www.facebook.com/earthship

Thank you for contributing to a more sustainable future!

story:
Short Summary

Hello there! My name is Sarah, and I'm turning 23 this month. I was looking for something that I wanted for my birthday, but came to the conclusion that what I wanted wasn't a thing, but rather was a lot of things. I wanted to raise awareness of sustainability and efficiency programs. I wanted to protect wildlife, including a large variety of flora and fauna. I wanted to preserve the few spots of wilderness we have left in North America, despite the sprawling cities. I wanted all of these things, but they wouldn't really be for me. I want to help better the world I live in, the world we live in, and thought it best if I set up a fundraiser.

I was raised to care for the environment, and leave a place looking better than when I came to it. The environment needs our help, the animals can't speak up and tell us that they need their nesting grounds protected, just like the cypress can't wave a branch in desperation to tell us that we need to protect their habitat and keep it clean and free from deforestation.
I've always stood by this motto: "Be a voice for those who cannot speak for themselves." This year, I want to make this happen, but I can't do it without your help. Let's see this happen, let's fundraise for a cleaner, safer, and more beautiful earth. Let's raise our voices and our dollar bills in the air, and fight for habitat conservation, renewable energy, and environmental education. 
We can do this together!

Sierra Club's Campaigns

Here are a few of Sierra Club's current campaigns:
  • Keeping Dirty Fuels in the Ground
    Protecting public lands from mining and drilling while maintaining natural heritage, preserving wildlife habitats, keeping air and water clean and free from pollution, and combating climate change.
  •  Nearby Nature
    Protecting natural spaces near cities and suburbs to ensure Americans have the opportunity to explore and enjoy the great outdoors.
  • Protecting and Restoring Forests
     Our national forests are diverse habitats for our most treasured wildlife, providing wild places where Americans hike, camp, fish, and hunt.

What We Need & What You Get

  • All of the proceeds from this fundraiser will go directly to The Sierra Club. The way Indiegogo is set up, is that any amount submitted to this crowdfunding page is directly submitted to the Sierra Club. There is no transferring of money on my end of things, so you can rest assured that all of your money will go right where it belongs.
  • If you are from my blog and are able to donate at least $1, I will feature you as a contributor (unless you mention otherwise.) This way, other blog followers can see your act of kindness and stewardship.
  • Donations from anyone will result in a physical or virtual hug from me (and from all of the flora and fauna that will be protected because of your donation, though I can only guarantee a hug from me at this current time)
  • In addition, donations to The Sierra Club are tax deductible, so you are able to use that if you'd like on your taxes in the upcoming year.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    • Share on social media! Even if a dollar isn't doable at this current time, share with others, so that they might be able to donate money for the cause, and share with their friends. The more people we meet, the more potential this fundraiser has reaching it's goal!
    • Indiegogo has sharing tools set up for your convenience. Take advantage of those and share this birthday wish with everyone you can! 

    Thank you to everyone for reading this and thank you in advance for your donations and support! This means the world to me, and I can't wait to see this actually happen.

story:
We're a little company on a mission to bring you, Protection without Pollution. 

What does that mean?

 

Sunscreen to protect your skin and your world.

We're done with nasty chemicals. We're done with disappointing natural sunscreens.

We're done with plastic.

We are stepping up natural sunscreen in Europe with new formulas and

100% recyclable packaging.

No scary ingredients. No plastic. Just 100% natural, daily skin protection.

 

Let's dive in.

 

We think about what we put in our bodies but it’s time to consider what we put on our bodies, too.

The skin is the body’s largest organ. You’ve heard it before, right? Yet still, we take this for granted, applying synthetic beauty products with little consideration for how much the impact on our bodies. 

As part of our mission to promote protection without pollution, we’re developing natural sunscreen formulas with zero pollution for your skin and your world. Palm & Pine will provide your skin with the sun protection it needs. Natural, nourishing ingredients, and zero plastic waste.

 

 

Conventional sunscreens contain traditional UV filters and synthetic fragrances, all packaged in convenient plastic pumps, sprays, and tubes. Bad for our skin and producing plastic waste that will end up in landfills or worse, the ocean - until the end of time. Although there are natural sunscreens available, the often sticky formulas leave you looking like a ghost.

 

 

It would be predictable if we told you that we're better than the rest, so it's easier if we show you...

 

 

 

We need sunscreen. In fact, to prevent sun damage and ageing, we should be using it every single day. Sunscreen is not just for summer.

And yet, the thought of putting traditional sunscreens on our skin every day makes us feel, well... a little uncomfortable. We believe, however, that if you don't want to put sunscreen on your skin every morning, then you're using the wrong sunscreen.

 

 

Developed with leading experts in natural skincare and tested to European standards - the highest in global sunscreen regulation - Palm & Pine uses mineral-based filters to provide 100% natural sun protection against both UVA and UVB rays.

However, we go one step further.

Palm & Pine not only provides sun protection but also nourishment and rejuvenation with a combination of ingredients that harness the power of nature. Add UV protection to your daily skincare routine, whatever the weather.

One product. Every day. 

 

 

We think it's safe to assume we all want the same from sunscreen.

We don't want stinging eyes. We don't want uncertain chemicals. We don't want to look like a ghost (the number 1 complaint about natural sunscreen).

We want natural protection that works, feels nice, and at the same time cares for the world we live in.

 

 

Zero-plastic packaging. Recycled, recyclable, and reusable.

Enriched with aloe vera, and cocoa butter, Palm & Pine provides protection and hydration. In addition, antioxidant and antibacterial properties from grape seed oil nourish the skin, preventing irritation and breakouts. 

 

 

Feel the freedom of using Palm & Pine every day, all over your body and face. The delicate areas are particularly vulnerable to sun damage and skin cancer and are often neglected. Palm & Pine is gentle enough to be used on sensitive areas such as your lips while providing tough UV protection. On the beach, up the mountain, wherever you play.

 

Our tinted zinc SPF is designed with the surfer and water lover in mind. Subtle but reliable face protection that you can wear with pride. Water and sweat-resistance come from natural wax and tint from cacao. Tough sports protection leaving you to focus on getting stoked.

 

So what's the problem with normal sunscreen?

Earlier this year the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) – one of the two main global regulators of sunscreen ingredients around the world alongside the European Commission – removed 14 of the 16 chemicals found in sunscreens from its GRASE (generally accepted as safe and effective) category due to insufficient safety data. 

 

 

Traces of these filters absorb through the skin into the bloodstream and have been detected in urine and breastmilk too. 

This alone doesn’t mean sunscreen is unsafe but where there is doubt, we know what we prefer...

No uncertain chemicals. Simply nature’s best.

 

 

We believe in sunscreen that is TRULY ocean-friendly. Not just the product but the packaging too.  Ocean friendly but sold in ‘green’ plastic? Nah, we’re not buying this. So we’re on a mission.

Palm & Pine are striving to provide an alternative.

 

 

Last year between France and the UK alone, 41 million people used sun protection.

Even if only half of those people actually bought sunscreen, that’s over 20 million brand new plastic bottles entering the environment, (and potentially the ocean), from this one product alone.

 

 

We chose aluminium containers. Why?

They are made from recycled aluminium, plus they can be recycled and reused.

Sleek, minimalist, lightweight.

 

 

We could’ve used squeezy bio-plastic tubes made of sugarcane and other plant-based materials, but they do not biodegrade as you are led to believe*. 

 

 

You're told plant-based plastics are biodegradable but they will only break down in an industrial composting facility, not your average garden compost bin. They won’t biodegrade at all buried in a landfill. There, they will sit for hundreds or thousands of years like any other piece of plastic waste.

That's not all...

The recycling infrastructure isn't yet in place which means that most bio-plastics can't even be recycled. 

So out of the options currently available, we believe that 

Recycled | Reusable | Recyclable

Is the best way to go. 

 

 

And the future? 100% compostable. Not the industrial compostable kind but the real, garden compost bin kind. The technology is a little way off being ready but we’re patient and committed to making zero waste our goal.

 

 

So who are we for? The sunshine lovers who adventure amongst the palms and the pines,
summer, and winter. The surfers, snowboarders, nomads, and travellers. Protection wherever and whenever you play. 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

At Palm & Pine, we have designed sunscreen that combines skin and environmental care. Our mission is to offer suncare that has minimal impact on our shared environment. Products that we are free to enjoy and move us all closer towards a plastic-free life.

The purchases made here will fund the production of the first batch of Palm & Pine, enabling the company to launch. 

Thank you for taking the time to look at our campaign. If you have any questions, please reach out. We’re here to help.

story:
About MSCJ & XL Dissent

Maine Students for Climate Justice (MSCJ), is a student-run coalition dedicated to confronting the systems and institutions fueling the climate crisis. We bring youth voices to the climate struggle in Maine, and provide resources and support for one another as we work towards ecological sustainability and social justice.  We have worked across campuses and environmental groups on issues like fossil fuel divestment, tar sands, and more.

On March 2nd, we are going to join hundreds of other students at a completely student-led, student-organized direct action against the approval of the dangerous Keystone XL pipeline.  XL Dissent is an event for young people to raise our voices in solidarity with communities most impacted by extreme energy. These include Indigenous First Nations in Alberta resisting tar sands extraction, people along the pipeline route opposing TransCanada’s use of eminent domain, and those near major refineries in Texas fighting environmental racism. Approval of the pipeline would ensure that our generation will also experience environmental devastation. We are coming together to register our dissent.

What We Need

In order to ensure that Maine's youth voice is heard, we need your help.  Every cent we raise of the 2,000 dollar goal will go towards securing a bus to transport Maine students to Washington, DC and back.  Without this transportation, The XL Dissent action will lose the power of the Maine student voice.  Right now, we have been loaned the $2,000 in time for the action, but will need to pay it back soon after the action (hence why the end date of the campaign is after the date of the action)

The Impact

The climate wont wait.  We are looking at our last chance to slow and reverse the effects of global warming, the brunt of which will be felt by those who contributed the least, populations of developing countries and today's youth and future generations.  The XL pipeline, if approved, will severely endanger the climate.

Read more here: http://xldissent.org/call-to-action/

Other Ways You Can Help

Get the word out!  Any donation amount is welcome, but if you are unable to donate, sharing the link of this campaign would be immensely appreciated!

Thank you!
