story:
THE CREW

We are the Buffalo Bridge!
   During the winter of 2013, Katie Russell, Professional Wilderbabe, stumbled upon the native buffalo hunt outside Yellowstone National Park.  After meeting a few of the hunters and diggin' around in some gut piles, she knew she HAD to return to explore the possibilities.  In winter of 2014, Katie gathered a small crew (us!) and returned to Yellowstone to make use of the left-behind pieces of the hunt - hides, skulls, bones, fur, organs, and more.  We set up camp right outside the hunting grounds, ready at any time to help, to share knowledge, and to offer our skills in anyway the families needed. In the process, we began making connections with the buffalo, the native hunters, the Buffalo Field Campaign, park officials, tourists and townsfolk alike. Focused on using every part of the animal, The Buffalo Bridge Project is building a bridge between cultures, factions, and political lines in the common recognition of the innate worth of the buffalo, and our own shared humanity.

Last year was so successful that we'd like to return this winter, and we need your help!

Ecological Impact

Less than 200 years ago, 60 million buffalo roamed the country. Their grazing patterns maintained the integrity of our native grasslands. They recycled nutrients back into the soil with every step, planting seeds, fertilizing and watering as the herds migrated over the prairies. Their wallows created much needed prairie lakes and ponds with precious freshwater ecosystems. They provided food and shelter for innumerable species, from frogs and lizards to antelope and beetles. The buffalo were one of the most important keystone species in the ecology of the plains, often referred to as "large scale ecological engineers."

Cultural Impact         

Many of the nation's First People depended on the buffalo for most of their survival needs. Because they provided so much, the herds of bison became integral to almost every part of human life; they offered food, shelter, clothing, children's toys, silverware, blankets, clothing, rope, bags, water carriers, bowstrings, glue, tools, fire fuel, and more.


The herds once numbered in the millions, and provided a comfortably abundant life for many of the buffalo hunting people. By the early 1900's, however,  European colonization had almost completely eradicated the species. Within a few generations, as few as 23 wild Bison remained. These solitary animals had survived by finding refuge deep in Yellowstone National Park's boundaries.

The decimation of the wild buffalo was crippling to the cultural biosphere of the First Nations. The very fabric of the native's way of life had been destroyed, and as a result, much of the culture of the buffalo people was lost, relegated to the memories and stories of the people who still remembered the way it once was.

Today, through many years of political conflict and ecological turmoil, the bison population in Yellowstone has grown to around 4,900. These are the last truly wild bison in the country. Yet every year, there is a state-funded culling of the bison, in which Yellowstone officials ship portions of the buffalo herd out to slaughter.

Very recently, several Native tribes have started exercising their treaty rights to hunt the wild bison, just as their ancestors have for hundreds, if not thousands of years. After almost 200 years of being severed from the very animal that was once the very heart of everyday life, many families are finally able to reclaim their traditions and reconnect with their cultural heritage once again.

                So what does Buffalo Bridge do?

Buffalo Bridge is there to help!  Historically, tribes would have had many more members present to assist with the harvest of meat, hides, entrails, bones, skulls, and everything else in a buffalo. Now, with limited hunters and limited time frames, the Buffalo Bridge crew can offer the vital service of helping hunters, while seizing the opportunity to learn a tremendous amount about buffalo, buffalo culture, primitive skills relating to buffalo, as well as the underrated skills of connection and cooperation across cultures.  We are there to offer our hands, our skills, and our hearts. 

                             Katie and Harmony helping skin

Giving Back    

Buffalo bridge is working to help restore and revitalize the cultural traditions that have been destroyed or forgotten with the decimation of the wild buffalo.  We believe we are at a turning point in American history- when we, as descendants of the colonizers, can offer ourselves and our services to the lineages of those who were colonized.  

Many of us on the crew are  "Primitive Skills" specialists (we like saying "Ancestral Skills"- these traditions are highly advanced technologies requiring high-level critical thinking) with a huge emphasis on Brain Tanning. 
      
"What is Brain Tanning?!" you ask?  It's the traditional way of transforming raw animal skin into supple, beautiful, usable leather.  Using brains.  Yep.  Brains.
 
This year we will be attempting to keep the tradition of Brain Tanning alive by harvesting and processing buffalo primarily using the technologies that would have been available to hunters before the onset of European colonization, just how humans have been doing here in the Yellowstone area for generations.  That means all kinds of fun things, like using flint knapped obsidian knives for skinning and scraping hides, antler and bone tools to treat the hides, and brains (yep.  brains!) to soften and work them.

                     Fleshing a hide: removing the meat and fat
We believe that there's an importance not only to preserve this ancient technique, which is in danger of being lost to time, but also to PRACTICE these skills and use them in our everyday lives, in order to become fluent in them so that we may teach, be taught, share and expand this knowledge in fluid and flexible ways.  (Because watching youtube videos isn't enough!)
                                      Salting hides for long term storage
Buffalo Bridge is dedicated to honoring Buffalo Culture by remembering the traditions of the Buffalo People who have been living with and hunting buffalo since time immemorial.  We wish to celebrate the sophistication, ingenuity, and resilience of these people by attempting to reconnect with these Old Ways of living and being.  We also recognize that these traditions are not our own, and we think that its important to re-imagine our own ways of connecting with the land we now call our home.  We feel that all of humanity has a shared past; one in which we all hunted animals and transformed animal skins into clothing, used stone knives, gathered plants, and made friction fire, and through enacting these very ancient patterns, we are able to remember our shared humanity.
 

That is how we are using the buffalo -  to reconnect with each other, ourselves, and our home. 

                    The heads and horns have many uses.
Last year, we had an open camp to all hunters and curious public eyes alike.  We began sharing and teaching much of our knowledge as we ourselves began to piece back together the puzzle of this shattered past.  Along with tanning hides, we were also interested in utlizing every part of the animal.  We collected and processed all kinds of beautiful, wonderful gifts from the buffalo!  

We cleaned bones to make tools for processing hides, or boiled them into bone broth medicine, we began bark tanning the honeycomb stomachs to make bags and hats, we rendered the fat for eating and for salves, we boiled the hooves and hide scrapings for glue,  we cut the horns into buttons and bowls and spoons, we spun rope from the wool, and more.  As we began piecing back together very fragmented knowledge of how all these parts were used,  our connections with the hunters grew as they revived old stories, almost forgotten, and began to make those stories real once again.

                                            

                                    Bark-Tanned Buffalo Stomach Bag
Last year was so successful that Buffalo Bridge has since grown to encompass more than just our time out there on the hunt.  We were invited back to the Nee Mee Poo (Nez Perce) Reservation outside of Lewiston, Idaho to teach a Brain Tanning workshop.  We were able to share our skills while learning a tremendous amount from the families we lived with, and we are invited back this spring for an even longer immersive skill share!

The Plan    

This year we have better ideas at how we can be more efficient out at Buffalo Bridge.  Like last year, The Bridge will be an open camp to all hunters, townsfolk, tourists, students, and newspaper reporters who are interested in what we do.

We will be teaching primitive skills pertaining to the buffalo on many levels during and after the project.  Alot of energy will be put into collecting and processing buffalo hides in extreme conditions.  Efforts will be made to set up classes with local school children like we did last year: 

               Seventh and Eighth Graders from Harrison, Montana
We're elaborating on how we can more effectively utilize every part of these gracious, generous animals.  We've expanded our Buffalo Horizons; bladder bags, parfleche paintings using bone paint brushes, scrotum bags, buffalo trunks, face grinding bowls, buffalo rib bone sleds, and much, much more!
After the project, we are headed back to the Nee Mee Poo (Nez Perce) Reservation to continue the process of Brain Tanning buffalo skins, and will also be sharing other ancestral skills as well, like flint knapping and friction fire.  This year we are hoping to share our laughter with even more Nez Perce families as we experiment with and practice the things that once, not so long ago, made us all human.
Many of the crew will go on to teach at various primitive skills gatherings throughout the year.   Like last year, members of the Buffalo Bridge crew will gift many items out into the broader skills community so more people will have the chance to learn the unique skills pertaining to wild buffalo.
 

                     A racked buffalo hide, ready for scraping!   
We think that with the restoration of these buffalo technologies, more people will begin to see the generosity and importance of the last truly wild buffalo.  We hope that as the cultures of the First Nations grows stronger in the reclamation of a stolen past, that we, as friends and as family, may also grow stronger with the reconnection to our own forgotten history. 

What We Need & What You Get

Our total funding goal is 10,000 dollars.  BUT we have already raised 1,000 of that, and our supporting grant foundation The Primtive Found, has agreed to match us up to 5000 dollars (thanks Primitive Found!).  

So we are asking for 4,000 dollars from people like you!

This is our Budget Outline:

Item Description

How Many?

Cost

Source

Total

Landowner Fee

1

$500

Paid to Phil Currie, landowner

$500

Cords of firewood

4

$180

Locally sourced through Phil

$720

Porta-Pottie

1

$50 set up, $170/month

Jim’s Backhoe and Septic Service, Livingston MT (406)222-0025

$390

Buffalo Dry Scrapers

3

$85 + shipping

www.braintan.com

$280

Salt

20

$6.99/50 lbs

Murdoch’s Feed Store in Bozeman

$139.80

Bolts for racks

16

$2/each

Ace Hardware

$32

Tarps for hides, 10’x12’

10

$19.20 each, when purchased in case of 10

www.tarpsplus.com

$192

Fuel reimbursement

11,955 miles

$00.30/ mile

Distance traveled by main crew members

$3,586.50

Food per diem

120 person-days

$35/day

Per diem for three crew members

$4,200

TOTAL:  $10,040.30

Risks & Challenges

Out there in the wild Yellowstone valley, we'll face extreme winter weather, including sub-zero temperatures and blistering blizzards.  We'll be living and working using ancestral technologies to harvest massive amounts of buffalo bounty, which will be a great feat of both physical and emotional strength.  We'll be piecing back together a very fragmented and incomplete knowledge of how to brain tan buffalo skins in such extreme conditions, basing most of our technique on personal experience, the limited literature that exists, and the stories of native hunters and their families.  We'll learn to overcome these challenges, we'll work to bring back the Old Ways, and we'll build the bridge between past and present, cultures and races, using the adaptability and vitality of our connections as the bridge between humans.

Other Ways You Can Help

This is about the buffalo, not about us.  Read buffalo books, check out online buffalo resources, and scope other projects who are interested in helping these critters.  If you can't donate to our project, we encourage you to share this with friends and families who might be interested.  Thank you!

Wanna learn more?

For more information on the Buffalo Bridge Project last year, check out:

http://primitivefound.org/blog/index.php

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VuZrmodoX5M

http://www.bozemandailychronicle.com/news/sunda...

story:
A call for action by Dr Jeremy Leggett, social entrepreneur

Everyone who worries about climate change and development knows we are running out of time to act. 

This is why I am launching this campaign from the climate summit in Lima, Peru, where you can almost smell in the air how much we need examples of ambitious projects that work. 

I am living in hope that I have two. 

First, I want to form a club of companies donating 5% of their profits to the struggle against climate change and for development. 

Second, with this campaign, I want to turbo-charge an organisation, SolarAid, that demonstrates just how much social good you can create with 5% of a company's profits. 

Why now?

There is just a year to go before the vital Paris Climate Summit, where governments must deliver a climate treaty that safeguards the future without leaving millions in poverty. We need to show what important pieces of that future can look like. 

Also, the British government will double any donation to SolarAid made between Lima and until 5th February by UK residents. (Please don't let this generosity put you off, Rest of World!)                                                                                                                                                             

What a 5% gift of company profits can achieve

Solarcentury, the for-profit solar company I founded, gives 5% of its profits each year to SolarAid. In turn, SolarAid has attracted further funding and created a retail arm, SunnyMoney that sells solar lights in Africa, recycling not 5% but 100% of profits to the cause. 

SolarAid's goal is to lift millions from fuel poverty and replace every toxic oil burning lamp in Africa with solar lighting by 2020. Now that would be one massive hit for development and against climate change.

So far they have sold 1.4 million solar lights, becoming the biggest retailer of solar lights on the continent, operating out of only 4 of the 54 African countries. 

Over their lifetime, these lights will save almost a quarter of a billion dollars of African household income. They will allow 1.7 billion hours of extra homework and keep almost 700,000 tonnes of carbon dioxide out of the atmosphere*. 

You can see for yourself the impact every £ invested makes using this Impact Calculator.

And here is the detailed research from the field that bears this out. 

What we still need to do

The challenging news is that we, and the rest of the solar lighting industry, have 249 million more oil-burning lamps to get rid of. 


SolarAid and SunnyMoney are doing everything they can to expand into new countries, reach more families and raise more funds. 

This is why I am launching a Founder's crowdfunding campaign. I want to do everything within my power to accelerate SolarAid's work and to provide core funding to strengthen the team and boost expansion. 

The stronger the core team, the faster they can achieve their mission, the quicker they create the examplar that can attract other companies to follow the Solarcentury-SolarAid model in a 5% club.

The Goal 

A 5% For Climate & Development Club** would be a huge prize: one capable of building a whole new type of capital in the world, a potentially huge pool of it, all dedicated to social good.

We all know the power of story telling. This potentially amazing story would help solve a global injustice and embody a new era of the possible, giving us a weapon against those incumbents who say low-carbon poverty reduction is expensive or impossible. 

Why crowdfunding?

I believe that people power is a vital ingredient to create a sane and survivable future. 

SolarAid and SunnyMoney show how people-power funding in the developed world can fuel people-power energy - literally! - via solar lighting in the developing world. 

SolarAid is an continent-wide dream with a big chance of coming true. The 5% club is a global dream with a fighting chance of coming true. If ordinary people can help bring both these dreams alive, fast, then we create hope of a road to wider wider renaissance in the years to come.

Please join me, support my appeal over Christmas and into the New Year, and lets  light a great big candle for hope for the climate negotiators to respond to.


The team at SolarAid will be supporting my Founders Campaign by providing contributors with solar lights, news from the field and further information. Please see details below. 

I will also answer questions you have on SolarAid and the 5% For Climate & Development Club via my website:

http://www.jeremyleggett.net

Thank you for your support with whatever your means. 

-----------------------------------------------------
*SolarAid impact research and data can be found here. 

Please note that the Impact of lights noted in the perks listed to the right of this page is estimated over the lifetime of the solar lights. 

Please also note that UK Aid match by the British government is only available to those resident within the UK. For details of the impact of donations to SolarAid with, and without UK Aid match, please see the SolarAid Impact Calculator. 

**More details on the 5% Club For Climate & Development Club can be found in Business Green.

SolarAid is a registered UK charity number: 1115960
------------------------------------------------------


Perks for supporting this campaign

SolarAid perks: details of solar lights, ambassador packs and reports from Africa. 

Join this campaign and you could receive one of the very same lights that are changing lives every day - as well as other perks and astounding impacts. 

The Economist "WHICH plastic gadget, fitting neatly in one hand, can most quickly improve the lives of the world’s poorest people? For the past decade the answer has been clear: the mobile phone. But over the next decade it will be the solar-powered lamp."

http://www.economist.com/node/21560983


The Greenlight Planet Sun King Eco

The Sun King Eco provides 30 hours of clean, safe light - you get one to tell the story of incredible change happening all across Africa, while families get the life-changing benefits  this simple light can bring. 

The Greenlight Planet Sun King Mobile

The Sun King Mobile solar light  also charges phones enabling families to stay connected and supporting enterprise and opportunity.

The Greenlight Planet Sun King Pro

The Sun King Pro is a bigger solar lamp, often used by solar entrepreneurs to create revenue as they charge mobile phones for neighbours.

The d.light S2

                                     

The S2 solar light is used by millions of schools children every night - improving education, exam results and helping to provide better opportunities for the future.


The Environmentalist perk also includes a personalised copy of Jeremy's recent book: The Energy of Nations. 


In support of Jeremy's campaign, SolarAid would also love to host a supporter and guest in rural Africa - an unforgettable experience.

Solar Ambassadors will receive these packs which include everything you need to inspire others and join the mission to eradicate the kerosene lamp by catalysing solar markets across the continent. 

In Africa, 600 million people live without access to electricity, often relying on dangerous kerosene to light their homes. 

The toxic fumes caused by a kerosene light can cause respiratory illness and eye infections, they can also increase the risk of fire and lock families into fuel poverty, with lighting costs eating up around 15% of their annual income*.



Updates from the Field

Supporters receiving updates from our work in Africa will hear from solar light users, entrepreneurs and teachers. We work to ensure we get detailed feedback and hear directly about the impacts of solar lights. 

Examples of some of the incredible things we hear: 

"If not for the solar lights, we would have been in darkness." Alex Mulungu, Malawi

"Kerosene was expensive... I did not allow [my daughter] to study at night.. [with a solar light] she is free to study anytime." Honoratha Elipidi, Tanzania

"I used to find soot in the noses of my children every morning when they slept in a room with kerosene, and they would complain for chest pains." Veledian Phiri, Zambia

 

Key events for you to attend

World Changers will be invited to our high profile launch events in 2015 (London, New York and Africa) during the UNESCO International Year of Light. 

These will be an incredible occasion to join key stakeholders in the mission to eradicate the kerosene lamp. 

And, of course, the celebrations will be no-holes barred in 2020 when we achieve our goal and see solar lights shining across Africa.  Support this initiative and we will invite you to the end of decade party.

SolarAid & SunnyMoney 

SolarAid is a London-based international charity that believes in business-based solutions to poverty and climate change. SolarAid was founded in 2006 by solar company Solarcentury to explore and create clean, safe, affordable energy for all.

Solarcentury established SolarAid by making a long-term commitment of donating 5% of annual company profits. In 2008, SolarAid created a social enterprise called SunnyMoney to run its on the ground operations in Africa. SunnyMoney currently operates in Kenya, Tanzania, Zambia, Malawi and Uganda. 

SolarAid is working on major research projects with Google and Stanford University and is building the Alliance to Eradicate the Kerosene Lamp from Africa by 2020. 

Awards
SolarAid has won the Ashden Gold Award, the Business Green Award, the Google Global Impact Challenge and the Guardian Sustainable Business Awards. 

 


Videos about SolarAid


Video created for the Google Global Impact Campaign

Video made when SolarAid reached sales of 1,000,000 solar lights


Video made for the Ashden Awards
story_txt:
A call for action by Dr Jeremy Leggett, social entrepreneurEveryone who worries about climate change and development knows we are running out of time to act. This is why I am launching this campaign from the climate summit in Lima, Peru, where you can almost smell in the air how much we need examples of ambitious projects that work. I am living in hope that I have two. First, I want to form a club of companies donating 5% of their profits to the struggle against climate change and for development. Second, with this campaign, I want to turbo-charge an organisation, SolarAid, that demonstrates just how much social good you can create with 5% of a company's profits. Why now?There is just a year to go before the vital Paris Climate Summit, where governments must deliver a climate treaty that safeguards the future without leaving millions in poverty. We need to show what important pieces of that future can look like. Also, the British government will double any donation to SolarAid made between Lima and until 5th February by UK residents. (Please don't let this generosity put you off, Rest of World!)                                                                                                                                                             What a 5% gift of company profits can achieveSolarcentury, the for-profit solar company I founded, gives 5% of its profits each year to SolarAid. In turn, SolarAid has attracted further funding and created a retail arm, SunnyMoney that sells solar lights in Africa, recycling not 5% but 100% of profits to the cause. SolarAid's goal is to lift millions from fuel poverty and replace every toxic oil burning lamp in Africa with solar lighting by 2020. Now that would be one massive hit for development and against climate change.So far they have sold 1.4 million solar lights, becoming the biggest retailer of solar lights on the continent, operating out of only 4 of the 54 African countries. Over their lifetime, these lights will save almost a quarter of a billion dollars of African household income. They will allow 1.7 billion hours of extra homework and keep almost 700,000 tonnes of carbon dioxide out of the atmosphere*. You can see for yourself the impact every £ invested makes using this Impact Calculator.And here is the detailed research from the field that bears this out. What we still need to doThe challenging news is that we, and the rest of the solar lighting industry, have 249 million more oil-burning lamps to get rid of. SolarAid and SunnyMoney are doing everything they can to expand into new countries, reach more families and raise more funds. This is why I am launching a Founder's crowdfunding campaign. I want to do everything within my power to accelerate SolarAid's work and to provide core funding to strengthen the team and boost expansion. The stronger the core team, the faster they can achieve their mission, the quicker they create the examplar that can attract other companies to follow the Solarcentury-SolarAid model in a 5% club.
The Goal 
A 5% For Climate & Development Club** would be a huge prize: one capable of building a whole new type of capital in the world, a potentially huge pool of it, all dedicated to social good.We all know the power of story telling. This potentially amazing story would help solve a global injustice and embody a new era of the possible, giving us a weapon against those incumbents who say low-carbon poverty reduction is expensive or impossible. Why crowdfunding?I believe that people power is a vital ingredient to create a sane and survivable future. SolarAid and SunnyMoney show how people-power
funding in the developed world can fuel people-power energy - literally! - via
solar lighting in the developing world. 

SolarAid is an continent-wide dream with a big
chance of coming true. The 5% club is a global dream with a fighting chance of
coming true. If ordinary people can help bring both these dreams alive, fast, then we create hope of a road to wider wider renaissance in the years to come.
Please join me, support my appeal over Christmas
and into the New Year, and lets  light a
great big candle for hope for the climate negotiators to respond to.


The team at SolarAid will be supporting my Founders Campaign by providing contributors with solar lights, news from the field and further information. Please see details below. I will also answer questions you have on SolarAid and the 5% For Climate & Development Club via my website:
http://www.jeremyleggett.net
Thank you for your support with whatever your means. -----------------------------------------------------
*SolarAid impact research and data can be found here. 

Please note that the Impact of lights noted in the perks listed to the right of this page is estimated over the lifetime of the solar lights. 

Please also note that UK Aid match by the British government is only available to those resident within the UK. For details of the impact of donations to SolarAid with, and without UK Aid match, please see the SolarAid Impact Calculator. 

**More details on the 5% Club For Climate & Development Club can be found in Business Green.

SolarAid is a registered UK charity number: 1115960
------------------------------------------------------

Perks for supporting this campaign

SolarAid perks: details of solar lights, ambassador packs and reports from Africa. 


Join this campaign and you could receive one of the very same lights that are changing lives every day - as well as other perks and astounding impacts. 


The Economist "WHICH plastic gadget, fitting neatly in one hand, can most quickly improve the lives of the world’s poorest people? For the past decade the answer has been clear: the mobile phone. But over the next decade it will be the solar-powered lamp."
http://www.economist.com/node/21560983


The Greenlight Planet Sun King Eco


The Sun King Eco provides 30 hours of clean, safe light - you get one to tell the story of incredible change happening all across Africa, while families get the life-changing benefits  this simple light can bring. The Greenlight Planet Sun King Mobile

The Sun King Mobile solar light  also charges phones enabling families to stay connected and supporting enterprise and opportunity.
The Greenlight Planet Sun King Pro


The Sun King Pro is a bigger solar lamp, often used by solar entrepreneurs to create revenue as they charge mobile phones for neighbours.


The d.light S2


                                     
The S2 solar light is used by millions of schools children every night - improving education, exam results and helping to provide better opportunities for the future.

The Environmentalist perk also includes a personalised copy of Jeremy's recent book: The Energy of Nations. 




In support of Jeremy's campaign, SolarAid would also love to host a supporter and guest in rural Africa - an unforgettable experience.




Solar Ambassadors will receive these packs which include everything you need to inspire others and join the mission to eradicate the kerosene lamp by catalysing solar markets across the continent.

story:
Summary

Hi my name is Davida Ingram and I am an artist and cultural worker who lives in Seattle. My neighborhood--Cascade and South Lake Union-- is one of the oldest places in the city. It's also one of the fastest changing areas. In fact the project takes its name from all the DETOUR street signs in the area that signify the ongoing construction.

Cascade and South Lake Union are rapidly developing. DETOUR is an experiment in listening to community voices to gather a sense of how to design better communities that include existing residents while adding new ones. 

The DETOUR project team is Lara Davis, Laura O'Quin, Robb Kunz, Rodrigo Valenzuela, Victor Ramirez and Rodrigo Valenzuela. They are a dream team of local Seattle artists who work in design, museum education, visual arts, and sound engineering, bring them all to bear in DETOURS interviews, photography and design work.

Your support will help fund a way to share the perspectives of 10 community members who have lived and worked in Cascade and South Lake Union. It will also help us make a permanent website to house an important community history.

What We Need & What You Get

We are hoping to raise $3,000 to pay our production costs for the collected audio and for a community event that will galvanize more support for the project and a tool kit to help other communities in transition do listening projects that highlight the voices of local residents.

DONOR PERKS include one or more of the following:

DETOUR MP3s

Limited edition DETOUR silk screen poster

Posts from the DETOUR Tumblr

A DETOUR interviewee portrait

You can call 206 686 8566 to listen to the recorded interviews as a cell phone tour. There are currently 19 audio stops. To select a track dial the number followed by the #key.

All funds raised will go towards the production cost that have been financed out of pocket.

 

The Impact

DETOUR explores a model that takes a different tangent on gentrification. Rather than rail against change, we propose that people who live in neglected areas have meaningful ways to imagine co-creating viable and sustainable communities with more equity, along side developers and city planners.

Cascade is historically one of Seattle's most impoverished areas. Private wealth is fueling the redevelopment of the area, especially nearby South Lake Union. This project is a way of imagining voice and visibility for community members who have a vision that is vibrant and thought-provoking.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us spread the word by sharing the link for this campaign.

Tweet us pics of you in the area with DETOUR signs in the background. Our Twitter handle is @detour15 and our fundraising hashtag is #detourseattle.

Read our Tumblr and leave comments: http://detour-watchthis.tumblr.com/.

story:
Send TR to St. Olaf

T.R McKenzie is a queer Xican@ warrior and land defender who grew up on the west side of Sioux City, occupied Dakota territory and is currently based out of occupied Lakota territory , in so-called South Dakota. He is a fierce defender of life, land, and justice. T.R. co-founded Deep Roots United Front (DRUF), an all POC and Indigenous led grassroots organization whose work centers – and provides direct support for – Indigenous communities and communities of color in active resistance to environmental and social ecocide and genocide. His work has placed him alongside the frontlines of resistance movements and focuses on the intersections of settler colonialism, white supremacy, climate change, environmental destruction and genocide, and homophobia. T.R is an organizer and educator who has facilitated and participated in workshops, trainings, and speaking engagements. A main tenet of his work involves moving people currently involved in the mainstream “environmental movement” to a more strategic place in which they would provide active support to – and respect the self determination of – marginalized communities on the frontlines of struggles who are most heavily impacted by social and environmental ills.

Money raised will go directly toward covering speaking and transportation fees for TR McKenzie's visit to St. Olaf College in Northfield, Minnesota, from February 9th through 11th.

story:
FreeGeek Chicago is a not-for-profit community organization that recycles used computers and parts to provide functional computers, education, internet access and job skills training to those who want them. At FreeGeek, volunteers learn to tear down, test, and build functional computers. After 24 hours in our program, volunteers earn themselves a free computer.

Since 2005, FreeGeek Chicago has carried out a dual mission: to reduce the environmental impact of personal computers and to ensure that all Chicagoans have access to basic information technology and the knowledge to use it effectively. By training our volunteers to refurbish and recycle second-hand computers, we educate and empower while responsibly managing electronic waste.

5 tons, $1,643.04

Recycling old electronics the right way takes some serious resources: time, energy, money, and a lot of hard work. As you can see, we've got the hard work part covered, but our revenue from sales haven't kept up with the growth of our volunteer program or the size of "palletopia", our name for the growing expanse of our space devoted to boxes full of old electronics to recycle.

On our last two recycling runs (Dec 10, 2010, Mar 11, 2011), we took 5 metric tons of electronic waste to be responsibly recycled by Supply Chain Services, Inc in Lombard, IL. At $0.12 a pound and $6 a monitor, our final bill was $1,643.04. We need your tax-deductible donations to help cover our costs.

Why should I care what happens to my electronic waste?

In the United States, more than 3 million tons of electronic waste end up in landfills every year. The fraction that is recycled is often sent overseas. In Asia and Africa, at places like Agbogbloshie, Ghana and Guiyu, China, our old computers, TVs, and cell phones damage the environment and undermine the health of the local population. The Internet, computers, and cell phones do great things for the people who can afford them, but how we make them and how we throw them away poisons the land, water, and bodies of those who can't.

FreeGeek Chicago reuses and refurbishes everything we possibly can, and make sure that what we can't use is recycled according to the highest environmental and worker safety standards available, whether we send it to Belgium or Zion, Illinois. We try our best to be transparent about our how we dispose of waste: you can learn more about our recyclers, view our recent recycling figures, and learn how to recycle a ton of circuit boards yourself.

Join us on a recycling tour with a donation of $100 or more

The best perk we're offering is the possibility to join us on a recycling day and and come tour a recycler as scheduling permits. We know our work isn't glamorous or sexy (our definition of "all expenses paid consists of a donut, a cup of coffee, and a ride to a random suburb), but we think somebody will get a kick out of seeing what happens to electronics when they die.

Support a strong community

A few weeks ago, a volunteer found herself locked out of her car as people milled around before a community council meeting and after the biggest day in our history (58 volunteers!). Within 10 minutes, our volunteers had found a towing company that could open her car and put together the $75 needed to get on her way. FreeGeek Chicago is a strong community that needs your money, time, and friendship to get our job done.

story:
Project Mermaids was started in 2012 by celebrity fashion photographer Angelina Venturella and acclaimed underwater photographer Chiara Salomoni who share the same passion for photography and preserving the ocean.  The goal of Project Mermaids is to bring awareness as to how precious the ocean and beaches are and to keep this beautiful environment healthy and clean. 50% of the proceeds are going to be addressed to the Save Our Beach foundation.

To help raise awareness, Project Mermaids is capturing celebrities in mermaid form working with The Mertailor Eric from Florida, who is making and donating the tails for our models. The Project has gone viral with over 140,000 followers on Instagram and has continued to grow awareness. Project Mermaids has had recent press coverage in the Huffington Post, US Weekly, Just Jared, Cosmopolitan, Perez Hilton, and many more .

The photographs will be shown April 22nd, 2015 at an art show and in a table book for the world to see how much more there is beneath the surface of the seas, and how much more there is to work on. The world needs to become aware of our problems, in order to take action.

story:
Qui sommes-nous ?

Nous sommes une équipe constituée de sept étudiants en première année de Baccalauréat d'Administration des Affaires au HEC de Montréal.

Dans le cadre de notre projet d’intégration académique, nous sommes chargés de créer un projet qui nous tient à cœur. Pour notre part, nous sommes un groupe hétérogène et nous avons tous un parcours différent, mais nous avons su trouver une sujet qui nous rejoignait.

Que voulons-nous réaliser ?

Le développement durable et l'écoresponsabilité sont des sujets actuels. Nous savons que le HEC souhaite être avant-gardiste dans ses pratiques et dans les projets qu'il entreprend. Cependant, nous nous sommes aperçus que notre université ne possédait aucune certification pour démontrer qu'elle est écoresponsable. Pourtant, à ce jour, plusieurs mesures ont été mises en place pour faire du HEC un établissement vert.  Nous avons étudié le cas, de nombreuses autres écoles d'études supérieurs pour finalement déterminer que le HEC ne supporte pas le mouvement «Vélo sympatique» (pour de plus amples informations consulté la page http://www.velo.qc.ca/velosympathique/mvs).  

Notre but ultime est d'obtenir la certification «Vélo sympatique». Par contre, notre première action en ce sens sera de construire un atelier de réparations et d'entretien pour les vélos au pavillon Côte-Sainte-Catherine. Pourquoi ? Les installations actuelles, tels que les supports à bicycles, sont suffisantes pour l'instant. Nous voulons commencer par obtenir un service qui n'était pas déjà offert au HEC et ensuite passer un sondage pour prendre le pouls de la population. De cette façon, nous serons déterminer les besoins futurs.

Pourquoi avons-nous besoin de financement ?

À l'aide de cette campagne de financement, nous souhaitons amasser 1200$. Avec cet argent, nous allons acheter l'équipement d'entretien et de remplacement nécessaire (des outils, des chambres à air supplémentaires, de la graisse, de l'huile, etc.) De plus, nous avons déjà un emplacement idéal pour cet atelier.

Les installations actuelles, tels que les supports à bicycles, sont suffisantes pour l'instant. Nous voulons commencer par obtenir un service qui n'était pas déjà offert au HEC et ensuite passer un sondage pour prendre le pouls de la population. De cette façon, nous serons déterminer les besoins futurs.Pourquoi avons-nous besoin de financement ?À l'aide de cette campagne de financement, nous souhaitons amasser 1200$. Avec cet argent, nous allons acheter l'équipement d'entretien et de remplacement nécessaire (des outils, des chambres à air supplémentaires, de la graisse, de l'huile, etc.) De plus, nous avons déjà un emplacement idéal pour cet atelier.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Curt Linderman Sr. I am happily married and the father of four children. My youngest son Kaden was vaccine injured at the age of 20 months. He was so profoundly injured that the doctors suggested putting him into an institution. That's what started me on my journey for truth.

My campaign is to support the radio program that I started 6 years ago. Linderman Unleashed started as a radio program to warn parents about the dangers of vaccines and how to avoid those injuries. It has morphed into something greater. We cover Vaccines, GMOs, Organic Foods, Chem Trails, Pharma, Government, you name it!

With your help, I will be able to finish my basement radio studio, attain the equipment needed for my in studio and mobile units to get the message out to more parents worldwide! We have approximately 150,000 - 200,000 listeners right now and we are making a difference...a very real difference. It's time to up the ante! 

What We Need & What You Get

We need $10,000.00 and that's not a lot when you think about recording studio equipment. The actual studio is close to finished. We need one more wall with a door and window and complete sound proofing. The equipment I have priced from Sweetwater and it will run anywhere from 8 - 9,000.00.

With this equipment I will be able to create a more professional program that will reach more people. I will also be able to go mobile to conferences and even out on the street with my program which is always important. 

I have been contacted 100's of times and been told that my program made the difference in their child's life. Whether they started to research allopathic medicine prior to treating their child or they figured out a way to heal their child, we have made a huge difference and you can help continue this success!

The Impact

The impact is educating parents, helping families and ultimately changing the world one mind at a time!

Other Ways You Can Help

I know these are particularly hard times so if you can't support the campaign monetarily, please let your friends and family know about it. If you know of a company that might like to get their ad on my program, this is a way to do it at a substantial savings!

story:
When the BP oil rig exploded in the Gulf Coast in April, it triggered an outpouring of frustration and anger from New Yorkers. In response to the outrage, a brave few stepped forward to lead efforts in pushing for accountability; we organized hundreds of protesters to speak out against BP by shutting down the main Manhattan BP station for over six hours.

Building off of this momentum, in the months following the spill, we hosted community meetings with more than three hundred active participants. From these meetings one theme emerged loud and clear: we, as American citizens, need to address our relationship with oil; our own consumption of petroleum products, our sense of disconnectedness from our national energy policy, and the flagrant waste and overuse of oil and energy taking place in our own neighborhoods every day. Together we formed a group, Stop Oil! NYC, and we began a campaign, the Oil Addicts Anonymous Program, to raise awareness and channel our efforts. We made it our mission to reach out to people on the streets, to businesses, and to policymakers in order to stop the next oil spill disaster here
and now.

Our Oil Addicts Anonymous campaign highlights the creative side of our members; we have a team working on a PSA about New Yorker’s oil use due out this fall, a NYC
Subway performance piece about plastic bags, and an interactive recruitment day at Times Square scheduled to register people for our 12 step “end your oil addiction” program. Together, we marched in the annual Coney Island Mermaid Parade as the oil- soaked mermaid survivors of the BP explosion, we sponsored an educational fundraiser for the Gulf Restoration Network, and we are planning an October 10th (10/10/10) work day with the NYC White Roofs Initiative (painting roofs a reflective white in our city saves 10% of their buildings’ energy use). Our work has been covered by dozens of
international, national and local news sources (see our web site for pictures and links to some of the coverage!) and we have enlisted the help of some fantastic local
organizations: the Sierra Club, Code Pink, the NYC Climate Coalition, Time’s Up!, 350.org and NYPIRG are among our partners on various projects.

So far, we have relied on the donated time, energy and contributions of our active members to support our work, but to finish some of our most exciting projects (a Boycott BP iPhone app, a public service announcement, and in-person visits to legislators to name a few, as well as outreach and materials), we need funding. Our goal is to raise $3000 this month, and with more funding we can accomplish even more.

Here is our wishlist for how we plan on spending the money:

A PROFESSIONAL PSA: $1000
A BOYCOTT BP IPHONE APP: $350
SIGNS & POSTERS FOR AC WASTE PROTESTS: $50
OUTREACH DAY AT TIMES SQUARE: $300
A CITIZENS’ TRIP TO DC FOR CLEAN ENERGY: $500
10:10:10 GLOBAL WORK DAY: $700

If you would like your donation to go to a particular project, please let us know! Unfortunately we do not have 501©(3) status so donations are not tax deductible, but if you would like to make a large donation and need the deduction, please shoot us a message and we can make that happen through a fiscal sponsor. The future of this venture is in your hands – empower us to help New Yorkers overcome their oil addiction – we need your help!

story:
9/13 Update: Thanks to your support we've reached our funding target!! $30K towards the completion of our new facility! We've still got about $50K of bills to pay to complete the new space so we'd love to keep the momentum going. Please continue to spread the word!

9/12 Update: Fay Rotenburg, venture investor and cleantech supporter, has generously offered to match the next $850 of Greentown Grows donations received!


Greentown Labs - A space for big ideas to grow

Just over two years ago (4) start-ups joined forces in search of a location from which to launch their entrepreneurial ventures. They were each looking for space to build and test prototypes for their solar-powered refrigeration system, energy management solution, airborne wind turbine, and innovative new compression technology.

They met by coincidence and ended up creating Greentown Labs, now one of the largest, fastest-growing, and perhaps only entrepreneur-founded clean energy incubator in the world. Greentown is currently home to nearly (30) organizations working to solve our biggest energy and environmental challenges. Our companies currently employ more than 100 people and have already raised more that $25 million to build their innovations.

We are a vibrant group of passionate entrepreneurs, innovators, students, and budding cleantech leaders. We've got a great community presence, too. In the last twelve months we've organized dozens of events, given tours to more than 5,000 visitors from around the world, and become a sort of de facto hub for our regional cleantech ecosystem.

In case you're asking, "What is a cleantech incubator?"

Don't worry. Our families often ask the same thing. There are many different types of organizations designed to help small businesses and early stage entrepreneurs, like accelerators, co-working spaces, and incubators. They come in lots of different shapes and sizes, but our incubator focuses on helping early-stage companies and organizations working to build high-impact clean energy innovations (e.g. solar, wind, energy efficiency). We provide them a place to build prototypes, desks for their employees, a place to expand their network, and tools and resources to help them build better businesses. We provide our member companies with desks, prototyping space, discounted access to software and tools, connections to mentors, other founders, and a great network of supporters. 

Companies pay Greentown a small monthly fee based on their space requirements. We don't take equity or ownership in these companies and we aren't backed by a venture capital or investment fund. We're just a group of entrepreneurs trying to help each other advance clean energy innovations that can help transform our world. Without an organization like Greentown Labs, many of our early-stage innovators would not have the financial runway to launch their businesses. We've never taken a profit from Greentown, nor do we intend to. Our mission and operating model is designed to help get their innovative, game-changing ideas off the ground.

We're building a new home in Somerville, MA!

The amazing demand for our unique combination of prototyping space, co-located offices, and access to a community of energy entrepreneurs and supporters has pushed Greentown Labs to its capacity. We've outgrown our current space and have been forced to put a number of promising young companies on a waiting list. To meet this demand and create a permanent home we're creating a fantastic new space in Somerville, Massachusetts. This is allowing us to more than double our prototyping areas and to add more than 50 new desks for our new and existing companies, in a much-improved facility.

We're also creating a larger event space to enable us to grow our event programming and further promote clean energy in partnership with organizations like the Massachusetts Clean Energy Center, Cleantech Open, and the New England Clean Energy Council.

Construction is underway and we're incredibly excited about our new facility at 28 Dane Street in Somerville, Massachusetts – a great location and an emerging innovation cluster, just a few minutes walk from the Harvard Square T station, and easily accessible by bike, bus, and car. We're also locating next to some amazing neighbors like Artisan's Asylum (community maker space), Brooklyn Boulders (climbing gym), and the MIT Museum!

More support for cleanweb and water innovators

Greentown Labs follows entrepreneurs and the cutting-edge places they go. We are finding more and more companies focused on solving problems at the water-energy nexus as well as at the intersection of energy, IT, and data (often called cleanweb). After housing half a dozen companies in these spaces and hosting the last two Boston Cleanweb Hackathons, Greentown Labs plans is expanding its space to better support companies working on cleanweb and water innovations.

The Details: Our Greentown Grows campaign

We need your help to meet the demands of the community of clean energy entrepreneurs we support! We've already pulled in an incredible amount of sponsorship from public sources and corporate sponsors, but we're hoping to raise the final $30,000 from our community of supporters we've served for the last several years with inspiring tours, access to our entrepreneurs, high-quality events, and overall clean energy advocacy. Please consider joining our hundreds of our fans and friends that have already lent their financial support to this effort.

As if supporting entrepreneurs and cleaner sources of energy wasn't motivation enough, we've got some fun gifts to say thank you! We strongly encourage you to become an official "Friend of Greentown" in order to take advantage of all the great perks, but we've got something for every budget:

  • Domino's #PoweredByPizza Perk ($10 contribution*):

  • The Bumper/Laptop Sticker + Facebook Shout Out ($25 contribution and up**):

  • Your choice of the T-shirt or the Pint Glass ($50 contribution and up**):

  • "Friend of Greentown" ($100 and up**): Get the t-shirt, pint glass, and bumper sticker!
  • Become a "Super Friend of Greentown" ($250**) T-shirt, pint glass,bumper sticker, and the great perks listed below!
  • Lifetime "Super Friend of Greentown" ($1,000**): Lifetime membership plus become permanently recognized on a plaque in our new facility.
  • "Greentown Entrepreneur Sponsor" ($5,000**): Permanent name recognition in an entrepreneur's work area. Also, personal letter of appreciation from an entrepreneur and opportunities for one-on-one interaction with the company!

*The #PoweredByPizza Perk from Domino's will be delivered to the e-mail address you provide approximately two weeks after the close of the campaign. By requesting this Perk you hereby agree to allow Greentown Labs to provide to Domino’s Pizza LLC (“Domino’s”) your name and email address for the sole purpose of delivering Domino’s Gift Cards as Greentown Grows’ Campaign Perks.  Domino’s will not use your name or email address for any other purpose, including for marketing and/or mailing list purposes.”

**All other perks (except for the #PoweredByPizza Perk) are available for pickup at our new facility in Somerville, MA where you'll also get a chance to meet with a member of the Greentown team! If you'd like to contribute but are not in the Boston area, contact us to discuss shipping costs.

The Benefits of becoming a "Super Friend of Greentown":

You get to take advantage of all the great perks at the lower contribution levels, plus the following benefits for 12 months:

  • Recognition by name on our website as an official "Friend of Greentown"
  • Personal VIP tour of our new Somerville facility before its opening to the public
  • Invitation to the VIP reception during our annual Demo Day (November, 2013), where entrepreneurs will demonstrate working prototypes and conduct small-scale, informal pitch sessions to investors and sponsors
  • Lunch with the Greentown Team & Founders: learn about the history and future of Greentown from the entrepreneurs that made it all happen

Our impact

The world faces massive environmental challenges; we believe that our companies are an important part of the solution. Whether it be high altitude wind turbines, water capturing nanotechnology, or milk-chilling systems for use in rural India, the innovative technologies being brought to market by our start-ups will change the way we live by preserving resources and reducing our impact on the environment.

 

Our companies are already changing the world. Greentown entrepreneurs have been featured in TED Talks, the New York Times, and the Forbes 30 under 30 list! Be a part of this impact by helping us double the amount of companies we can house in our new, custom-built prototyping facility. Not only will we continue to provide machines and electronics tools, a prototyping lab, and office space, but–with your help–we will also expand our impact with water and clean web clusters!

Other ways you can help

We understand that not everyone has the financial means to help out - we run on a pretty tight budget, too! But you can have a big impact just by spreading the word. Please forward this campaign and pass on these links to your family, friends, and anyone else who cares about living on a clean, healthy planet!

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/GreentownLabs

Twitter: https://twitter.com/GreentownLabs

Web: www.greentownlabs.org

Video: http://goo.gl/fU136

Press: http://goo.gl/xrdoz

**Greentown Labs is a mission-driven for-profit enterprise that plans to file as a benefit corporation later this year (a somewhat involved process). Contributions are not tax-deductible.**

Governor Patrick Celebrates Greentown Expansion: "Growth is a Choice"

“Jason (Hanna, Founder, Greentown Labs), it was a year or two ago that you toured me around Greentown Labs in your existing location, the old location in Boston. And I was dazzled by the creativity, the by imagination, by the determination of the people who were there creating our future. Building tomorrow. And making it real. And here in a very short time, you are moving into double the available space for precisely that kind of entrepreneurship and creativity. I am thrilled to be a part of it. I want to thank all of the folks that have helped making Greentown Labs the reality that it is and continue that growth.” - Governor Patrick, July 18, 2013

story:
About Me!

I am trying to fund my Trip to USDAA Nationals.

This is my last year being a junior handler and my first year for my first agility dog Jessi to Qualify to go to Nationasl. I have been in love with dogs my whole life. I wanted to do agility since I was five and saw a local agility trial. When I was 12 I got jessi and started training her. after doing agility for about 5 years we are ready for our first Nationals.

 

What We Need

For this trip I will need to raise 3,000$ (agility is not cheap) I have been competing for 5 years and payd for short trips and local trials this is the biggest event I have been to and the most expensive.

I will be using the money for

  • travel (driving from Idaho to Tenessee)
  • Hotel during travel and driving
  • my dogs entry fee
  • food
  • and the other fees that come with competing in agility

If I do not reach my goal to go my dream will not stop there. The money would be put towards my dogs and I competing to qualify for Nationals Next year!

 

The Impact

Like I said it has been my dream to do agility with my dogs since I was a little girl. The first time to Qualify for Nationals only comes once in a life time. At the start of this qualifying year I had no idea that I would Qualify. Our training and hard work had payed off when we made it to our first regional competition. We went in with the mind set of having fun and we found ourselves qualifying for Nationals. Helping fund this trip to Nationasl is helping me fund my dreams.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • share this with all of your friends and family!
  • any support helps!

I will be using the money for

travel (driving from Idaho to Tenessee)
Hotel during travel and driving
my dogs entry fee
food
and the other fees that come with competing in agility
If I do not reach my goal to go my dream will not stop there. The money would be put towards my dogs and I competing to qualify for Nationals Next year!
 

The Impact
Like I said it has been my dream to do agility with my dogs since I was a little girl. The first time to Qualify for Nationals only comes once in a life time. At the start of this qualifying year I had no idea that I would Qualify. Our training and hard work had payed off when we made it to our first regional competition. We went in with the mind set of having fun and we found ourselves qualifying for Nationals. Helping fund this trip to Nationasl is helping me fund my dreams.


Other Ways You Can Help

share this with all of your friends and family!
any support helps!

story:
Reduce, Reuse, Recycle - it's an often heard mantra. We're getting better at recycling, but why are we still so rubbish about reuse?

It's just too hard. For most people, their first experience of reuse is wading through umpteen different websites only to find information which is out of date or doesn't say what they need to know (e.g. that their local charity shop doesn't take TVs any more). So they give up, and throw it away. Wouldn't you?

We wouldn't. It doesn't have to be that hard. Using our Give It For Good website all you have to do is enter your item and where you are, see what your options are nearby, then you can decide if you want to give to a charity, to an individual and so on. Let us do the research, so you can do the giving. We'll always be free for individuals to use.

If you're an organisation you will benefit too. Give It For Good will help you get more donations of what you need, more often. If you're a little community project that needs spare fabric, now you have somewhere for people to find you. If you're a larger organisation, you can update your details yourself without having to hassle the council. And it's easier for councils - less maintaining of websites and less rubbish to collect means lower council tax.

We have a prototype at http://giveitforgood.com, and years of experience in promoting reuse via Freegle (http://ilovefreegle.org). This crowdfunder is to develop the full site and fund a 6 month pilot project listing all the options in Brighton and Hove. In future we intend to follow that up with a regional roll out across the South East and then extending nationally. We will make this self-sustaining, probably by organisations paying a small annual fee for a location to be listed - more than covered if they get a couple of extra donations a year.

Reuse will never be mainstream in the UK unless it's easy. Let's make it happen.

We're aiming for £15,000 to fund the development and pilot.

  • If we get less than £5,000 then, sadly, we cannot proceed. We will offer you a refund of your donation (including the 9% indiegogo will have deducated).
  • If we get between £5,000 and £10,000 then we cannot proceed with the pilot, but we will be able to build something which will give us a much better chance of winning further funding. We will ask you if you want your donation to go towards this or have it back.
  • If we get between £10,000 and £15,000 then we will be able to run a pilot with some significant restrictions.
  • If we get more than £15,000 then we will expand the pilot to cover other areas or more features.

story:
With your donation we can enhance public access to two much-loved destinations in the Middle Fork Snoqualmie Valley: the Middle Fork Snoqualmie Trail and the Pratt Bar, a sunny Middle Fork beach with spectacular mountain views. The Mountains to Sound Greenway Trust needs your help to raise $25,000 by May 1st for two trail construction projects - so everyone can enjoy these wilderness jewels, tucked away in a wild valley just beyond the Seattle metro area.

Once plagued by illegal dumping, shooting and widespread trashing of the river corridor, the Middle Fork Valley today is an amazing story of a regional treasure reclaimed. For nearly 20 years, the Greenway Trust has worked with land managers and other community partners to improve public access and restore the natural habitat and ecosystems of the Middle Fork. The Valley is now a haven for our outdoor-loving Puget Sound community, but existing trails and recreational infrastructure are insufficient, unable to handle this surging attention. Valley trails are deteriorating and riverbanks are once again taking a beating.

We need to turn this around, and make sure the Valley has the recreational amenities to handle all this love. In 2014 the Greenway Trust is teaming up with the US Forest Service and other long-time partners on these two high-priority projects – and we need your help!

Every donation, no matter how small, carries us closer to our goal of $25,000. We have something incredibly special here, with towering mountains, lush forests, clean rivers, and hundreds of wilderness adventures reachable within minutes of our cities. To sustain such natural splendor in harmony with a growing metropolis is a major community achievement and a continuing challenge. Your donation will help maintain this precious balance. Please take part in continuing this legacy.

2014 Project ... Middle Fork Trail Reroute

For hikers, mountain bikers and equestrians the Middle Fork Trail is the primary route into the wilds of the Upper Middle Fork Valley. This 15-mile-long path features big views of Mt Garfield and the Middle Fork Snoqualmie River.  However, severe washouts only three miles from the Middle Fork Trailhead have made the trail impassable for horses. Further deterioration will impact access for all users. Funds raised through this campaign will enable us to reroute this endangered section of the trail and restore native vegetation along the way.

2014 Project ... New Pratt Bar Trail 


In this valley of wetlands and streams, there are surprisingly few areas that can provide river access year after year without damage. The Pratt Bar is such a place, a sunny Middle Fork gravel bar big enough to accommodate lots of visitors while maintaining the feel of a remote mountain stream. Today, access to the Pratt Bar is difficult: you must ford a creek and negotiate a confusing tangle of unofficial trails. Follow the wrong trail and you’ll end up bushwhacking or straying into a wetland.  With funds raised through this campaign, we will install a footbridge and build a well-defined trail to the Pratt Bar, creating dependable four-season access for visitors to enjoy this amazing spot.


2014 Project Funding ... Your donation will make a difference


Campaign donations will pay for construction supplies, equipment like a mini-excavator (looks like an overgrown Tonka Toy, but is the best tool for roughing-out new trail), but most importantly, the people-power that is the main story behind every trail – the folks who excavate tread with shovels and grub hoes, build rock retaining walls, fabricate turnpikes through wet areas, and lay bridges across streams. You would be amazed how much work can be accomplished with $25,000, thanks to resources like Washington Conservation Corps crews, and legions of passionate volunteers.

A National Forest Foundation grant will account for almost 50 percent of our budget. To boost the impact of their grants, this federal program requires a dollar-for-dollar match from local sources.  Donations qualify, so your donation is central to our fund-raising effort.

Shrinking land management budgets mean that projects like ours rarely get funded. How to fund recreation and resource protection is part of a national debate about public lands, one that won’t end soon. In the meantime, the work must continue. By leveraging public funds with private donations, non-profit expertise, and volunteer energy, we can still move ahead. Please make your donation today!

Other ways you can help Ask your friends and networks to get the word out about this campaign! With the share tools at the top of this page, Indiegogo gives us a way to use social networking platforms like Facebook and Twitter to make a real impact on our community.

We welcome volunteers. If you would like to join us in the field or have campaign questions, please contact Mackenzie Dolstad, Greenway Trust Stewardship Program Administrator mackenzie.dolstad@mtsgreenway.org.  Or contact one of our community partners: Washington Trails Association, Evergreen Mountain Bike Alliance, American Whitewater, The Mountaineers, Issaquah Alps Trails Club, or Backcountry Horsemen of Washington.

What happens if we don't meet our campaign goal? If our funding falls short, we'll reschedule both projects for 2015 and continue fundraising. Your donation will support the Pratt Bar and Middle Fork Trail projects; we are committed to seeing both projects to completion.

Beyond 2014 ... What's next for the Middle Fork?

The Pratt Bar and Middle Fork Trail projects are elements of a multi-year effort to prepare the Middle Fork for growing public use. The Washington State Department of Natural Resources, the major land manager in the lower Middle Fork Valley, completed the Granite Creek Road-to-Trail project in 2013 and, in partnership with the Greenway Trust, will soon complete a new, family-friendly trail up Mailbox Peak. In the pipeline are additional trails, improved river-access areas, and much-needed facilities like bathrooms.

The need for these facilities is rapidly growing. Parking areas often fill early and overflow onto the narrow Middle Fork Road. We see restoration gains reversed as more campsites are hacked from riverbanks and more unsanctioned trails cut through wetlands and fragile soils. In heavily used areas with no toilets, campsites are dotted with piles of human waste and toilet paper that extend like little cairns into adjacent forests.

In 2016, a newly paved Middle Fork Road will reopen to the Middle Fork campground, a $20 million upgrade managed by the Federal Highway Administration. Surprisingly to some, a paved surface will greatly enhance water quality in the Valley: rainstorms will no longer flush road gravel and sediment into wetlands and creeks, and summer dust clouds will no longer coat vegetation and campers. New drainage structures will reopen coastal cutthroat trout migration routes that have been blocked for decades. And the notorious Middle Fork Road potholes will no long deter visitors.

This beautiful, wild place with so many recreational opportunities is a perfect place for people to make a personal connection with the natural wonders that surround us in this region. Every person who makes that connection is another advocate for preserving this fragile, precious resource. To properly welcome a new generation to outdoor recreation in the Middle Fork, we need to get ready!

story:
The Youth Walkout For Climate Justice

Climate change is one of the most pressing issues facing our generation, and youth across the nation are rising up to the challenge to create a better world for ourselves and for future generations.


Students For a Just and Stable Future (SJSF) is a youth-led climate action group. Alongside 350MA and the Better Future Project, we are calling on Governor Patrick to fulfill the promises he made in the Global Warming Solutions Act. Join us as we create support for the Governor to create a policy of building only the best- clean, renewable energy sources- in Massachusetts. We want to commit to building only clean, renewable energy infrastructure in our state. On March 31st, college and high school students from across Massachusetts will walk out of their classes and converge at the State House at 10:30 AM to call on Governor Patrick to live up to his promises. Together, we are calling on the Governor to meet us outside of the Statehouse for a public rally to address this goal. You can help us make this walkout as powerful as possible by donating any amount, no matter how small.

Where does this money go?

To bring in students from all across the state, we will need to provide transport from Western Mass to Boston. Your money will also go to art, stage/sound equipment, and general rally costs.

Our Impact

Under the Global Warming Solutions Act, Massachusetts has committed to reducing our carbon emissions  80% by the year 2050. In order to achieve such significant cuts by that time, all major energy infrastructure investments should be directed solely towards renewable energy, and a ban on coal and fracking infrastructure should be put in place.To read more about the Climate Legacy Campaign, click here.

Can't donate? You can still help! Share this page with your family, friends, supporters, and on social media.

story:
WE ARE CUNY DIVEST:

A coalition of students, faculty, alumni, and staff in the City University of New York (CUNY) community campaigning for the divestment of fossil fuel holdings from CUNY's endowment.

Our Mission

Since March 2013, we have been working to convince the CUNY Board of Trustees to divest the institution's endowment from fossil fuel companies.

It is our conviction that since the continued burning of fossil fuels has been empirically proven to be a grave threat to the sustainability of life on Earth, it is imperative that an academic institution such as CUNY no longer tacitly support fossil fuel companies with their investments.

We are working in the tradition of previous successful divestment movements. Much as divestment from South Africa was fundamental in dismantling apartheid, divestment from fossil fuels will be a resounding message of commitment to climate justice.

Why We Are Walking

Inspired by the Nihígaal bee Iiná Walk for Existence, we, along with our supporters, will be walking for 4 days between Friday, Aug. 21 through Monday, Aug. 24 to all 24 CUNY campuses in the 5 boroughs. We will be starting from the College of Staten Island and ending with a rally at the CUNY Administrative Office unifying our voices to bring attention to the urgency of the climate crisis, and to pressure the CUNY Board of Trustees to pass a resolution for fossil fuel divestment and reinvestment in renewable energy, sustainability, and socially-responsible companies.

We have passed 15 fossil fuel divestment and reinvestment resolutions at more than half of the CUNY campuses and organizations, including PSC-CUNY and the University Student Senate - whom passed a resolution three times between October 2013 and May 2015.

On Sept. 8 2014, we met with the CUNY administration to discuss CUNY's fossil investments, but have not heard sufficient updates regarding their decision since then.

The CUNY administration need to adhere to their students' calls.

Climate change impacts us all, and CUNY is no stranger to this fact: during Hurricane Sandy in 2012, four student lives were lost, 10 CUNY facilities were used as shelters during the storm, and infrastructural damage occurred on several CUNY campuses including Borough of Manhattan Community College, which was closed for a week post-Hurricane Sandy.

Approximately 10% of CUNY's $241 million endowment is invested in the top 200 fossil fuel companies, including Exxon Mobil Corp., and Chevron Corp. By walking to each campus, we are unifying the CUNY community and using our collective voices to demand fossil fuel divestment.

As the leading urban public university in the nation, CUNY also needs to lead the way for fossil fuel divestment within NYC. 

We need a new social and political climate in which fossil fuel companies are not upheld by our universities and political leaders.

Help us persuade the CUNY Board of Trustees to divest from fossil fuels. Help us win the fight for climate justice.

YOU WILL HELP PROVIDE:

  • Food (dinner) and drinks (~$15/person): $1,500.00 total
  • Leaflet printing costs: $350.00 total
  • Tent (x2): $150.00 total
  • First aid kit (x7): $72.00 total
  • Orange flags: $25.00 total

story:
My name is Adam Davis and I am a Naturalist. I enjoy helping people deepen their nature connections through multiple ways of experiencing and knowing. I am seeking contributions to cover flight, lodging, and other travel expenses for a trip to Scotland. I plan to travel to parts of the highlands, coastal regions, and other locations in Scotland to connect with land energies, wildlife, and other naturalists. The goal of this late summer trip is to develop nature connections and allow them to enrich and nourish the Connecting With The Land Workshop Series which has been helping folks experience new ways of engaging with nature since 1998. 

All monetary contributions are helpful. In return for contributions at or above specific levels you are eligible to receive services and/or publications ("perks"). The contribution thresholds required to trigger the perks are consistent with fair market values and the perks are cumulative. For example, a contribution of $15 entitles you to receive an interpreted Tree Ogham reading. A contribution of $25 gets you both the Tree Ogham reading and a water publication in PDF format. With a contribution of $40 or higher you are entitled to receive the reading, the water publication, and a tree PDF publication that is a handy field identification companion. At $70 a rune cast is added. For seven people contributing $173 or higher, messages from the lands and/or waters of Scotland will be relayed from four locations.

Donations will be greatly appreciated and spreading the word about the campaign is also very helpful. Monies that are not used for Scotland travel costs will be used to develop nature connection activities for a urban revitalization charity. Thank you for your support!

story:
I want to start with a quote from the book "The Little Prince" written by Antoine de Saint-Exupery...

“I am looking for friends. What does that mean -- tame?"
"It is an act too often neglected," said the fox. "It means to establish ties." 
"To establish ties?" 
"Just that," said the fox. "To me, you are still nothing more than a little boy who is just like a hundred thousand other little boys. To you I am nothing more than a fox like a hundred thousand other foxes. But if you tame me, then we shall need each other. To me, you will be unique in all the world. To you, I shall be unique in all the world....”

This quote perfectly describes animal and human relationships. Trust. Responsibility. Love. But we don't live in a perfect world, so these qualities are not known to everyone. Without these qualities we end up with abandoned cats, dogs and other animals. Exactly - we end up! Not just the person, who abandoned his animal. That's the main reason why I want to help shelter animals live as comfortable as possible till they find a new forever home.

My name is Anete Dziluma, I live in Europe, in a country named Latvia. Although, compared to other countries we are quite small, that doesn't mean we don't have animal shelters. As said in the TV series "Game of Thrones", winter is coming (as well as Christmas) and that means animal shelters will need additional resources to  keep animals safe and warm. 

Because this is the first time I will participate in a  fundraising campaign, I want to concentrate on 3 shelters in Latvia: 

  • Ulubele http://www.ulubele.org/lv/rigas-pilsetas-dzivnieku-patversme/      ~200 animals;
  • Dzīvnieku draugs http://www.dzd.lv ~60 animals;
  • Juglas dzivnieku aizsardzības biedrība http://www.patversme.lv ~100 animals.
One dog living in a shelter 1 day costs ~5$, one cat ~3$. 
My goal is to rise as much as possible, every dollar counts and regardles of the amount raised, it will be transfered to animal shelters to help in buying food, blankets, medicine, microchips and all the other things needed for animals living there.
Raised funds will be split in 3 parts, each of it will be trasfered to one of the above mentioned animal shelters. 
Let's make a difference and help those who are in need but can not ask!

P.S.

I know that not everyone can contribute, so to those who can not, but supports this idea, I kindly ask to share this information (on social networks - facebook, twitter etc.).

P.P.S.

Big thanks to animal shelter supporter "Natural Horsemanship Center," Missy Wrin for contribution. See her educational youtube videos: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC5b4PJeuS4IroYcFND92zAg

P.P.P.S.

To those who haven't heard of country Latvia, please see this nice video made by Latvian institute: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CtnIUr8Q4E4
