story:
Help fund our Conference Attendance:

In March of 2014, community planners and designers from around the world will converge in Taiwan at the 9th annual Conference of The Pacific Rim Community Design Network. SAVE International has had a strong presence at the Pacific Rim Community Design Conference in recent years and brings valuable skills to the conference and workshop. Our goal is to send 5 SAVE International members (3 students and 2 non-students) to the 9thAnnual conference-taking place in Taiwan from March 14-19, 2014. These members have submitted full paper research topics and received acceptance by the conference organizers. SAVE International is looking for support to send these members to present their work and gain valuable community planning and ecological design skills.

The funds raised here are to purchase airfare, conference fees, accommodations during the conference, and transportation to scheduled events and workshop tours. Any funds raised beyond our goal will be directed to supporting future SAVE campaigns.

About SAVE International:
The purpose of Spoonbill Action Voluntary Echo (SAVE) International is to protect the critically endangered Black-faced Spoonbill (Platalea minor) and its habitat throughout its flyway by promoting alternative economic development and long-term sustainability of the ecosystems and local communities where it lives.

Founded in 1997, SAVE began as a volunteer group of professors, students, and staff from the University of California, Berkeley and the National Taiwan University. For the first 10 years, SAVE focused its work in the area around the Tsengwen Estuary in Taiwan, wintering site to over half the world population of Black-faced Spoonbills. Working with local fishermen, national legislators, and Taiwan environmental organizations, SAVE successfully battled the development of a petrochemical plant in this crucial habitat site and proposed ecotourism as the sustainable alternative. SAVE also worked to ensure that the master plan for what became the Southwest Coast National Scenic Area included adequate stepping-stone habitat for spoonbills as the population recovers and grows. This was a major outcome pf the Taiwan spoonbill fight.

In addition to ongoing protection efforts in Taiwan, SAVE has expanded its work to include the spoonbill’s entire flyway. SAVE is now working to preserve the breeding habitat in South Korea and in Japan. This critical habitat is currently threatened where diking of wetlands, government plans for industrial and power plants, highway construction, and residential/commercial/university development is occurring or proposed. These same forces threaten local fishermen and rice farmers as well as some of the most important cultural sites in Korea’s history.

SAVE International is a project of Earth Island Institute.

About the Conference:

Established in 1998, democratic planning and participatory design have been at the heart of the Pacific Rim Community Design Network. The Pacific Rim Community Design Conference provides an opportunity for academics, local governments, scientists, community planners, and environmental designers from around the world to share research, case studies, and projects.

The 2014 conference theme is “Engaging the grassroots: Social Justice and Bio-diversity.” With eight conferences held in various countries across the Pacific Rim, issues and foci have been expanded over time according to the environmental and social changes. For the 9th gathering, the theme “Engaging the grassroots: Social Justice and Biodiversity” encompasses five key issues:

(1) Urban social housing

(2) ‘New ruralism’ experiments

(3) Wetland conservation

(4) Placemaking in displacement

(5) Service-learning education

The format of the conference consists of “small groups” organized around these five sub-areas, followed by a common forum – “big tables”.

Thank you for your support:

Thank you for your interest in our organization. Your support will help SAVE to continue its work to educate international audiences on the threats to the critically endangered Black-faced Spoonbill. It will also help young environmental planners and designers showcase their work to design a more sustainable future for this species.In addition to your donation to this campaign, please spread the word. Any effort to reach out to your friends, family, coworkers, and community will help us to continue to build momentum towards our research and attendance at the Pacific Rim Community Design Conference.

story:
Short Summary

Since 2004 ONC has been working hard on ocean based solutions to climate and food security.  We are a small specialized team comprising engineers, scientists and ecological modelers.  We work collaboratively with universities and marine institutes to tackle the major global challenges facing the world today.

Our campaign - Project Platypus, will enable us to design and test at sea, a viable wide-swath dispersion method that will enable precision mariculture of ocean plants in the surface ocean.

The fundamental principles of the dispersion method have already been demonstrated in a trial at one-tenth scale.  That trial represented a significant step towards the eventual dispersion goal but not in a way that can be applicable to full-scale operation.  This up-scaling requirement forms the basis for the currently proposed project, i.e.  full scale design and a one-fifth proto-type testing at sea.  

If we can do this then we open the door to a variety of ocean solutions based on the
cultivation of marine organisms for food and other products in the
open ocean.   We would be able to match nutrient supply with biological needs
of ocean plants and animals in order to reach a desired marine ecosystem outcome. In this way our processes can support valuable ecosystem services, such as the removal of waste carbon dioxide from the surface ocean and the atmosphere.
The key to remember is that the Platypus Campaign will advance implementation of ocean solutions to serious issues of major concern.

What We Need & What You Get

In order to fund Project Platypus we are seeking to raise AUD $79,000.

After reward settlements the funds will be utilized on the following core activities:
i) Engineering design of unique  ocean dispersion equipment (25%)
ii) Materials and labor for building of a 60 metre swath prototype (15%)
iii) Environmental testing and modeling to support the at sea testing (10%)
iv) Planning and execution of the at sea testing trial (20%)
v) Drone photography  (10%)
vi) Documentation and publication of findings  (20%)

We are excited to offer a range of perks from educational resources, time on board during the research work, to our project memorabilia T-shirts and caps.

If we don't reach our full goal, we will scale back our program so that tangible results can still be achieved and only the scale is reduced.

The Impact

Amazingly humans in the open ocean are still only hunters and gatherers.   As our population and our impact on the earth grows, we can no longer just sit back and take from the oceans.   To secure our future some management of the open ocean will be necessary for food production or management of waste carbon dioxide.
Multiple benefits may be brought about through managing the linkages between surface ocean community structure and the balance of nutrients available to support life for example:

Climate Change (by sequestering carbon into the deep ocean (Blue Carbon) for long term storage,contributing to atmospheric stabilization)

Food Security (by increasing marine productivity and the sustainable harvest from the oceans)

Ocean Acidification (by reducing carbon and hence carbonic acid in the surface layers of the ocean). 

Risks & Challenges

The application of new ideas is a transformational process with many challenges and risks.  When we move from land to the ocean the risks are heightened and the challenges far greater.   So why back our campaign?  ONC have been pioneering these techniques for more than ten years and have built an experienced and trusted team along the way.  To minimize risk and maximize benefit, we work in partnership with leading academics and marine institutions. 

Because our work is at the base of the marine food-chain with microscopic ocean plants there is so much to learn and so many surprising benefits to be gained.  The same plants that give us oil today can help secure a safe future for tomorrow.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Please share our campaign with friends, colleagues and family.

story:
Forest of Interbeing is a reforestation project run voluntarily by young mindfulness practitioners all over the world. Our aim is to purchase, reforest, and maintain deforested land in the Mexican state of Veracruz in cooperation with the Mexican nature conservation association DEMATAC, an internationally respected NGO in the region; local communities; international funders; and the Wake Up Community in Mexico and abroad. Los Tuxtlas is the northernmost tropical rainforest area in America and an area of high biodiversity value which is home to many threatened plant and animal species, like the Tuxtla Quail Dove and the Long-tailed Sabrewing hummingbird. By replanting parcels of land where tropical forest has been destroyed for ranching, we can have a real impact. Reforestation returns homes to many living beings and diverse wildlife who have suffered from the unskillful way in which we have related to nature. Restoring these lands will also allow our descendants to enjoy a healthy Mother Earth. Our dream is that this Forest of Interbeing will continue to grow and nourish the intercultural connections and the collective mind of love in our worldwide communities and Sanghas.

We are currently focusing our efforts on 5 project areas in Mexico, located in the municipalities of San Andrés Tuxtla and Catemaco in the Los Tuxtlas region of Veracruz.

View Interactive Map here.

All of the labor for our projects is donated by dedicated volunteers and many of the trees we plant are provided for free by a state-owned tree nursery. Your support allows the Forest of Interbeing to:

  • purchase and install fences to protect reforested areas from neighboring cattle
  • purchase additional trees, including fruit trees, which provide economic benefit to land owners willing to transform their land into a forest
  • transport trees from regional nurseries
  • provide meals and transportation for volunteers

Reforestation Areas (on map above)

A. In April we began our reforestation efforts in the community of Ruiz Cortines by collecting seeds and seedlings from the forest and planting 34 trees on the property of local resident Mauricio Vázquez.

      

Recollection of Seedlings

Newly Planted Tree

B. In July we will assist the junior high school of Sihuapan in the reforestation of a portion of the school’s land with approximately 60 trees. With your support, however, we could make a much greater impact by reforesting approximately 5 hectare (~ 12 acre) with more than 3,000 trees.

C. The largest reforestation area is in Rancho Los Amigos, a former cattle ranch transitioning into a center for ecotourism, yoga and environmental education. They have already reforested parts of their land and will allow us to reforest a space of 3.1 hectare (7.3 acre), closing a gap between forest sections on their land and a large remaining rainforest area on neighboring land. Reforestation here will start on July 25th with a short mindfulness retreat. Local Wake Up participants will be assisted by volunteers from Rancho Los Amigos, the nearby community La Barra and a group of young indigenous mindfulness practitioners from Chiapas (7 hours from Los Tuxtlas by car).

Valeria Vega, the director of Rancho Los Amigos (right) together with children from the community La Barra

D. Maxacapan is a future reforestation site and is located near the small lake of Chalchoapan. A portion of this land is forested, with the remaining hectare (2.2 acres) previously used for growing tobacco. The owner’s daughter, María López, has convinced her father to provide this land for reforestation. She and other members of her family will assist us in planting trees.

María López in front of a tree on her father’s property

E & F. Our final planned sites are located in in the community of Chuniapan de Arriba. The first (Area E) is an area of 0.7 hectare (1.3 acres) on the land of the Comisariado Ejidal Lucio Pucheta. This area protects a spring, which provides about 200 people with water. Local community members, including students from the local junior high school, will assist us in planting trees. In addition to this land, we will help the community protect an additional 7 hectare (~ 17 acres) of rainforest on communal land, also serving as an important water protection area (Area F). Currently, neighboring farmers do not respect the area’s boundaries and often enlarge their fields, encroaching onto this land. We will install a stable fence to establish a clear boundary and prevent further damages. We will also reforest 0.5 hectare (1 acre).

Area E

Forest of Interbeing member Christoph with representatives of the local community in front of area F 

These reforestation areas are just the beginning- with increased funding, we will continue to expand our efforts to other areas in the region. The need for reforestation in Los Tuxtlas is vast. All of your contributions go directly toward restoring our Mother Earth to her healthy and natural state, providing homes and joy to many living beings. 

Volunteers from Chiapas

Perks

Wake Up New York Jam Session for music download


As a thank you for your support of Forest of Interbeing, we are happy to offer you the following perks:

  • An email with a photo of a beautiful tree you helped plant
  • A digital download of music created by young mindfulness practitioners (sponsored by Wake Up New York). You'll receive a full album of uplifting songs, such as "All In My Heart," which you can listen to here. Here's a sneak preview of Wake Up New York joyfully practicing"My Roots Go Down".
  • Handmade calligraphy postcards lovingly created by a WakeUp NY sangha member
  • A tree hand-tagged with your name or the name of a loved one (we'll send a photo!)
  • NEW: Hand-drawn traditional calligraphy of the Chinese character for mindfulness (念) by a sangha family member. In his book "Savor: Mindful Eating, Mindful Life," Thich Nhat Hanh explains, "The Chinese character for mindfulness is "nian." It is a combination of two separate characters, each with its own meaning. The top part of the character means "now," and the bottom part of the character means "heart" or "mind." Literally the combined character means the act of experiencing the present moment with your heart."
  • NEW: An original drawing of a rainforest creature by a Forest of Interbeing participant
  • NEW: Make a greater impact by planting a group of 5, 10 or 20 trees. We will  mark them with a sign featuring your name or the name of a loved one.

Toucan Charcoal drawing by Christoph

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are eager to help Forest of Interbeing's reforestation efforts but cannot contribute financially at this time, you can still support the project in these ways:

  • Spread the word (and the video!) about our campaign
  • Stay connected by liking us on Facebook
  • Learn more about mindfulness practices at http://www.wkup.org/

story:
Who are we?

We are a community of 25-30 international volunteers who come to Ananda Gaorii to learn how to live, work, create and grow together in harmony. We all have different paths and walks of life but deep interest in personal growth, community living and spirituality has brought us here. We thrive for the betterment of the world through creative collaboration and spiritual wisdom. Our diet is mostly plant-based, we are vegans and vegetarians and follow the 3 ethics of permaculture: People Care, Nature Care and Fair distribution of the resources.

We live in Ananda Gaorii which is an ashram, farm and learning center located on a 13-hectare property in a small Danish village called Vig, about an hour from Copenhagen. It is part of Ananda Marga, an international network of urban and rural projects whose purpose is to serve the local community through education, spirituality, health, culture and local economy.  Our motto is “Self-Realization and Service to the Universe” that is practiced by balancing regular practice of yoga and meditation with social service and social change work. In our projects we blend spirituality, sustainability and community. Some of them are:

  • a permaculture forest garden
  • bio-intensive food growing using hugel beds
  • bee-keeping
  • community music studio
  • making jam, miso, organic cosmetics and other products
  • making a new kitchen garden
  • permaculture water management (digging a swale)
  • giving free yoga and meditation lessons in the local area
  • creating free educational, inspirational and spiritual content

Our vision

Our vision is something that inspires us deeply and guides our daily work. Whatever we do - we try not to forget why we are doing what we are doing and keep that vision in our Hearts and Minds.

Here is the Vision: We envisage a self-reliant community of living beings based on universal love interacting harmoniously with the land, surrounding region and the world, giving and receiving inspiration and practical knowledge about how to live in a way that truly expresses a sense of universal family.

Our mission

We need our mission to bring into the world what we are thriving for. Because we are the change we are so longing for. We want to be a nucleus of experiential learning which integrates spirituality, sustainability, self-reliance, holistic health, community living and social justice for the benefit of, and in cooperation with, the local environment, people and the world at large.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We've created this crowdfunding campaign as part of our vision. We want to be completely self-reliant, reduce the negative footprint from transport emissions and represent local farming. For that we need 20000 DKK to buy a polytunnel that will allow us to harvest food all year round and that will serve as a plant nursery.

If you care to help us, we'll be happy to give you some of our unique home-made products (honey, natural cosmetics, miso) or invite you to Ananda Gaorii for a yoga and meditation class or a retreat... Check the details on the right.

If you prefer supporting us through MobilePay, here is the number you can use: +45 52785933

In case we don't reach our 20000 DKK goal, we'll use what we've raised to buy a smaller and cheaper greenhouse that will anyway benefit the project.

 

The Impact

By supporting this campaign, you will help our community to continue our work that we are so inspired and happy to do. First, to teach European youth how to cultivate vegetables and be more self-reliant over a longer period, especially in Autumn and Winter. Further, we will feed ourselves with local and organic food, making sure that our food is our medicine. Second, you will help us to reduce the amount of petrol used to transport vegetables from other countries and continents to Denmark, contributing to solving Climate Change. And third, we will be able to share the excess food with local communities for a fair price.

Since 2018, we are developing our garden. You can see a few pictures. We've created a beautiful kitchen garden and built a few small caterpillars and a polytunnel where we produce cucumbers, tomatoes and some greens. Now, it is about time to take a step forward to contribute to European policies and goals such as promoting biodiversity, rural development and creation of jobs for youth who would like to stay longer in Ananda Gaorii.

You will benefit from supporting us by receiving a little piece of our heart - our work. It can, for example, be honey, natural cosmetics, a yoga lesson or a weekend retreat.

Follow us on Facebook to learn more:

https://www.facebook.com/AnandaGaorii/

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're not able to financially contribute to our project, you can still help us by getting the word out about our campaign: please share the link on social media!

Lot of Love.

story:
Why Protect Jacoby Creek and the Land Around it?

Your help is needed immediately to preserve the Jacoby Creek – a source of drinking water for Xenia and Yellow Springs. A 267-acre property, just west of the village of Yellow Springs, is going to auction in 9 parcels on March 16. The Jacoby Creek traverses the largest parcel for sale – 125 acres – and the majority of the property is within the “Jacoby Greenbelt,” a protection goal of the village of Yellow Springs for over 40 years. You can make a real difference for water protection and conservation in this community today -- please act! Tecumseh Land Trust (TLT) needs your help to permanently protect as much of this property as possible. 

 

We all live downstream from someone

The Jacoby Greenbelt is such a priority because it contains over 3,000 meandering feet of the creek and healthy wooded buffers.  Jacoby Creek provides drinking water for the city of Xenia and impacts the water source for Yellow Springs as well.  Preservation of this property is absolutely central to our mission!  We have dedicated all of our 1% for Greenspace funds towards its protection but in order to protect this critical property, we need help through donations.  Tecumseh Land Trust is seeking to raise $350,000 in order to purchase a conservation easement on the property to reduce the debt on the land purchase and create a tax benefit for bidders interested in working with TLT.  Please consider making a special donation to the Jacoby Creek Protection Fund today!  Donors wishing to do so may make a contingent donation, which means their donation will only be accepted if the fundraising goal is met. 

 

Jacoby Creek is a Valuable Headwaters Stream for the Little Miami and Beyond

Protecting small streams in the uppermost parts of river systems is an effective way to improve water quality downstream. Runoff from the land on this property forms small streams that become these “headwaters streams,” recognized for their benefits to water quality like sediment control, nutrient control, flood control, and wildlife refuges. 

Protect Drinking Water for Xenia and Yellow Springs

This particular stream, Jacoby Creek, flows toward the Little Miami River, and contributes to the ground water aquifer feeding the City of Xenia and close to the aquifer for the Village of Yellow Springs. Both Xenia and Yellow Springs rely on clean ground water for the public water supplies.

Protect Endangered Species

The Little Miami River is designated a Wild and Scenic River, home to more than 87 species of fish, 36 species of mussels (including five state endangered species), an endangered turtle and salamander, and numerous species of breeding birds.

Prevent Harmful Algal Blooms

The Little Miami flows into the Ohio River, which has seen harmful algal blooms stretching for miles, caused by increased levels of phosphorus and nitrogen. These algae are detriment to aquatic wildlife and can pollute public drinking water sources. Healthy headwaters streams can reduce nutrient pollution.

Clean up the Dead Zone

The Ohio River flows into the great Mississippi River which then flows into the Gulf of Mexico. A large “dead zone” has formed, caused by phosphorus and nitrogen largely coming from the Ohio Valley. The increased levels of nutrients have had a significant impact on the fisheries of the Gulf, causing major fish kills and reduced biodiversity. 

Think globally, Act locally!

Founded in 1990 by citizens in Yellow Springs and Miami township, Tecumseh Land Trust is a nonprofit conservation organization serving Greene and Clark Counties of Ohio and surrounding areas. The purpose of Tecumseh Land Trust is to preserve agricultural land, natural areas, water resources, and historic sites, in voluntary cooperation with landowners, and to educate the public about permanent land preservation. We assist landowners in navigating state and federal easement programs, as well as, accept donated easements on farmland and natural areas.  When current Projects are complete, we will have preserved over 28,000 acres in our working area!

Visit TecumsehLandTrust.org and donate today to help preserve our farmland, water, and natural areas around Yellow Springs that make the village the beautiful place it is to live, work, learn in and visit.
story_txt:
Why Protect Jacoby Creek and the Land Around it?
Your help is needed immediately to preserve the Jacoby Creek – a source of drinking water for Xenia and Yellow Springs. A 267-acre property, just west of the village of Yellow Springs, is going to auction in 9 parcels on March 16. The Jacoby Creek traverses the largest parcel for sale – 125 acres – and the majority of the property is within the “Jacoby Greenbelt,” a protection goal of the village of Yellow Springs for over 40 years. You can make a real difference for water protection and conservation in this community today -- please act! Tecumseh Land Trust (TLT) needs your help to permanently protect as much of this property as possible. 
 
We all live downstream from someone
The Jacoby Greenbelt is such a priority because it contains over 3,000 meandering feet of the creek and healthy wooded buffers.  Jacoby Creek provides drinking water for the city of Xenia and impacts the water source for Yellow Springs as well.  Preservation of this property is absolutely central to our mission!  We have dedicated all of our 1% for Greenspace funds towards its protection but in order to protect this critical property, we need help through donations.  Tecumseh Land Trust is seeking to raise $350,000 in order to purchase a conservation easement on the property to reduce the debt on the land purchase and create a tax benefit for bidders interested in working with TLT.  Please consider making a special donation to the Jacoby Creek Protection Fund today!  Donors wishing to do so may make a contingent donation, which means their donation will only be accepted if the fundraising goal is met. 
 
Jacoby Creek is a Valuable Headwaters Stream for the Little Miami and Beyond
Protecting small streams in the uppermost parts of river systems is an effective way to improve water quality downstream. Runoff from the land on this property forms small streams that become these “headwaters streams,” recognized for their benefits to water quality like sediment control, nutrient control, flood control, and wildlife refuges. 
Protect Drinking Water for Xenia and Yellow Springs
This particular stream, Jacoby Creek, flows toward the Little Miami River, and contributes to the ground water aquifer feeding the City of Xenia and close to the aquifer for the Village of Yellow Springs. Both Xenia and Yellow Springs rely on clean ground water for the public water supplies.
Protect Endangered Species
The Little Miami River is designated a Wild and Scenic River, home to more than 87 species of fish, 36 species of mussels (including five state endangered species), an endangered turtle and salamander, and numerous species of breeding birds.
Prevent Harmful Algal Blooms
The Little Miami flows into the Ohio River, which has seen harmful algal blooms stretching for miles, caused by increased levels of phosphorus and nitrogen. These algae are detriment to aquatic wildlife and can pollute public drinking water sources. Healthy headwaters streams can reduce nutrient pollution.
Clean up the Dead Zone
The Ohio River flows into the great Mississippi River which then flows into the Gulf of Mexico. A large “dead zone” has formed, caused by phosphorus and nitrogen largely coming from the Ohio Valley. The increased levels of nutrients have had a significant impact on the fisheries of the Gulf, causing major fish kills and reduced biodiversity. 
Think globally, Act locally!
Founded in 1990 by citizens in Yellow Springs and Miami township, Tecumseh Land Trust is a nonprofit conservation organization serving Greene and Clark Counties of Ohio and surrounding areas. The purpose of Tecumseh Land Trust is to preserve agricultural land, natural areas, water resources, and historic sites, in voluntary cooperation with landowners, and to educate the public about permanent land preservation. We assist landowners in navigating state and federal easement programs, as well as, accept donated easements on farmland and natural areas.  When current Projects are complete, we will have preserved over 28,000 acres in our working area!
Visit TecumsehLandTrust.org and donate today to help preserve our farmland, water, and natural areas around Yellow Springs that make the village the beautiful place it is to live, work, learn in and visit.

story:
Our Story

Help men inside San Quentin gain green knowledge and life changing skills...

Imagine a lively and passionate class of 25 students tackling some of the toughest issues humanity faces today.  People are asking questions, sharing dynamic examples from their own personal stories, strategizing ways to integrate sustainable practices into their own lives and the lives of their loved ones, and organizing action plans to green the very institution where all this is taking place.â€¨ Well, this is all happening in one of the most unexpected yet appropriate settings in Marin County…San Quentin State Prison.
â€¨

Meet The Green Life: a sustainability and self-sufficiency program for the men of San Quentin, by the men of San Quentin. In April of 2009, the peer educators from the long running Keepin' It Real program invited Van Jones, a leading voice for equitable involvement in a new Green Economy, to speak.  His talk and work served as a catalyst for collaboration between the North Block of San Quentin Peer Educator Group of Incarcerated Men, Angela Sevin (founder and director), and community volunteers to develop a groundbreaking eco-literacy and green job preparedness curriculum, striving to share practical pathways for meaningful lives. Now, co-led by Pandora Thomas and Angela Sevin, the peer educators of San Quentin have taken what they learned and launched a pilot class engaging 20 more men in the aim of fulfilling the program’s mission:

"A collaboration of solutionaries from inside and outside communities that inspires and awakens our connection to the earth and each other, by contributing to individual, community and global transformation."

 

The Impact

Fifty men inside of San Quentin have made the commitment to improve their lives and their communities through their involvement with The Green Life program.  They are clear that in order to do this, they need to understand the environmental implications of their actions, and learn viable alternatives. They, their families, and members of our communities all depend on the skills they will gain through this project.  This project is a pilot and will be spread to other men inside other prisons once we get it the funding we need to take the program to the next level.
 
In this co-creative, peer-educator learning environment, the men not only create, but prepare, guide, and implement their own curriculum for ecologically sustainable practices, thereby developing as facilitators, trainers, and leaders. By the end of the program, the men will have gained viable skills for enhancing their own living conditions, as well as invaluable personal leadership qualities for re-entry to their communities. In the words of Green Life peer educator, Lawrence Blankenship, “It is a learner centered, performance based program for inmates who want to be an asset to public safety and not a liability. By having employable skills we become positive helpers in our communities and not destroyers.”
 

 What We Need & What You Get

We need start up funds to pay for finalizing the curriculum, materials which include books and resources to teach the men using hands on activities, stipends, and a green career fair. This year begins the next phase of growth as we strengthen our infrastructure to deepen the impact of our work inside and outside of San Quentin. Broadening our program means an increasing need for support. Based on your donations and support, we would be honored to have you on board as a proud partner in The Green Life.  â€¨

All donations up to and beyond the $100 level will get a shout out on our Facebook page. And of course, a donation of any amount is deeply appreciated!

 

Your generous tax deductible donations will be channeled to our program through our awesome 501c3 sponsor, Land Empowerment Animals People (LEAP). Check out their work at www.leapspiral.org

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Get the word out, share environmental resources and stories and like our Facebook page! http://www.facebook.com/TheGreenLifeSanQuentin

 

Michael Harris, one of the men of San Quentin who was an integral leader in the formation of The Green Life is now serving time in a federal prison on a technicality in his sentencing procedure. Our acknowledgment, prayers and gratitude go out to him and his family as he seeks to get justice and freedom after serving over 20 years of incarceration.  In Michael's words: "It’s time for a change and The Green Life is the new revolution. I cannot think of any other movement that is crucial in order to sustain our communities, create meaningful lives and save the planet.”

story:
Short Summary

My name is Xiuhtezcatl Martinez.  I am a 13 year old Environmental Activist and the voice and representative for the Boulder Colorado Earth Guardians Youth Group.  Our group is standing up for the survival of our generation by educating youth and adults about the state of the planet that we are inheriting, creating environmental campaigns, and taking them into action to create a sustainable, just healthy planet.  States and Countries around the world want to model what we are doing here in Boulder, by creating Earth Guardian Hubs in their communities.  The hubs will empower youth to have a positive impact on environmental issues that are directly affecting them where they live, and give them hope that their voice can make a difference.  Locally we have gotten pesticides out of parks, gotten deadly coal ash contained, helped get a fee on plastic bags and much more. Your donation will help to spread the Earth Guardian mission by supporting us in forming hubs globally.

What We Need & What You Get

We are raising 15,000 dollars to support the ongoing Earth Guardian mission and vision to develop Earth Guardian hubs nationally and globally,  We will be kicking off our first international Earth Guardian Hub in Byron Bay Australia in December of this year at the Upliftfestival.com.  Your donation will help us in completeing our six series online toolkit written and filmed by youth, to support youth and families in taking personal responsibility in their lives, their schools, their communities and nationally or globally if they are so called. Earth Guardian Toolkit

It will also support us in filming and promoting our first music video for our original song "Live as if our Future Matters"   and for recording our second message drive music album "The Hope is in our Hands" which is a compilation of original environmental rap music written and performed by youth.

We will also film our second "Youth News You Can Use" news show written and filmed by youth

We are allocating 5,000 dollars for each of these projects. If we don't raise our entire goal, our first priorities are the Earth Guardian hubs and the Toolkit.  You can check out more about us and our work at our website
EarthGuardians.org

Other Ways You Can Help

For those of you who can not contribute in the form of dollars we would totally appreciate your support by making some noise and helping us get the word out about our campaign.  Don't forget you can use the handy Indiegogo share tools to help us spread the word about our work and commitment to leaving ours and future generations a health, just, sustainable planet!

story:
Basics

Shift The Climate is a brother and sister duo, out to see the places and people affected by climate change and to present a solution based outlook to the world's biggest problem. You can visit our website to explore all we are up to. 

Who We are

Kate and Sam are a brother/sister team living in Charlotte, NC. Their passion for the outdoors grew into a greater concern for the climate crisis that the planet faces. Together, they both felt that they could no longer sit on the side lines watching this happen. Shift is their chance to jump in head first.  

How You're Helping

We will be using the funds raised from this campaign to help us finance part one of Shift. This phase consists of a road trip around the U.S. where we hope to meet those most directly affected by climate change, and also those making the changes we, as a country, should be moving towards. We will be building an online resource for people to learn the facts of climate change and what they can to do to help combat it. We hope to foster an overall community of climate activist. Part one will culminate in a feature length documentary of our findings.
 
Donations will also go towards funding a Street Team. The Street Team is a youth movement to raise awareness of climate change in local communities through distribution of stickers, stencils, and other street art based medias. The Street Team will also include action packets which will outline a clear path for aspiring climate activist to take in order to create real change in their communities. We hope this will become a free resource on our website.

What We Need & What You Get

What We Need

We're diving into this project head first. Cutting the ties loose, and going for it. We want to make this happen and we need your help! We're breaking our funding down into a few categories. 
  • Travel Cost [$1,000]: We're traveling the country to meet, learn, and film those directly effected by climate change. A big chunk of funding will head towards all the cost we accrue during the trip. The basics, you know? Food, lodging, and travel cost. 
  • Production Equipment [$1,000]: We've been filmmakers for a few years now, but we need a few extra items to pull this thing off. We need a new audio recording set up so we can make sure we capture people's stories effectively. We also would like a POV camera to help us capture the action in more incognito situations. 
  • Street Team [$1,500]:This is the big one. We're really trying to pull off a movement here. We want to empower people in two ways. The first is awareness through a guerilla style campaign of stickers, stencils, and other street art mediums. The second is distributing an information packet detailing how you can create change on an individual level all the way to a city wide level. A great majority of our funding will go towards the street team as we would like to see this become a free resource. We hope that aspiring activist can sign up and receive their packets at no cost. This will be completely donor funded.

 

What You Get

We want to make donating worth everyone's while. Each donation will be critical, whether it is $10, $25 or $1,000. We have detailed all levels of donation perks below. Any extra promotional material will be distributed to our donors if available.  

 

A little more...

Shift has been a dream in the making for many years. Kate and Sam have long been informed followers of climate change, and also of the climate movement. In the past year, they both came to the same realization: they wanted to be more involved. They both felt that they needed to be doing more, a lot more. Together they have a great combination of skill sets. Sam has a long history in video and film production and Kate studies environmental history and received a research grant from Montana State University in 2011, to study at the Smithsonian Archives and National Academy of Science archives. Shift is the beginning of their dream to raise awareness surrounding climate change, and most importantly, to make it an approachable, tangible topic for all. 

 

Can't Afford to Give?

That's ok! We know not everyone will be able to donate to the cause. If you can't make a financial donation at this time here are a few more ways to get involved.

  • Head over to our site.
  • Like us on Facebook, and share it with your friends
  • Follow us on Twitter.
  • Write a #WhyIShift, our hashtag campaign that allows people to share why they are becoming more climate aware.  
  • Suggest an environmental petition.

story:
I am traveling with a group from Whole Foods Market and we will be working in Sao Paolo helping the community in various ways. In the past groups like ours have built playgrounds, installed running water in schools, set up technology centers, repaired and constructed buildings for the community. Our trip will include a visit to the Sambazon (www.sambazon.com) acai farms in the rainforests of Amapa, and boat trips on the Amazon. 

 

We are required to pay for our plane trip to and from Brazil, as well as a plane trip from Sao Paolo to Macapa in Brazil. I am looking to help raise funds for my travel expenses.

 

Three years ago, I was chosen from the South Region of Whole Foods Market to take part in an immersion program in Guatamala.  I realized that giving a short amount of time is a very valuable gift to humanity.  The trip was very inspiring and inspirational.  We visited a mico loan community of women who were benefitting from Whole Planet Foundation's mico loans, and were able to witness the amazing benefits it had on the women and their families.  We also built nine carbon stoves in indiginoius family homes and taught in a community school. In going to Brazil, I would like to continue my work in giving to others.

 

To learn more about the Whole Planet Foundation and all the amazing ways it is helping to raise women, families and whole communities out of severe poverty around the world, please visit: www.wholeplanetfoundation.org. It is an AMAZING organization giving a hand up, not a hand out.

 

Please share my campaign and help me reach my goal!

story:
We are a veterans college group that is currently working on a veterans urban farming nonprofit. This nonprofit will provide much needed employment opportunities for veterans and their families.

What We Need & What You Get

We need your help:

  • We need about $2000 for licensing and legal fees for the formation of the nonprofit. If we receive more than that, we will use it to help fund our outstanding current community farm project at the Heritage Urban Farm Hub in Fort Myers FL.  
  • We can truly not offer much at this time and it will take several weeks after we receive funding for our crops to mature. With that said, you will have our gratitude and we would like to place a banner, with the names of all those that contribute, at the farm for all to see. We are big proponents paying it forward, and we will do so in kind.. 
  • If we fall short of our goal, we will use to help support our efforts.

The Impact

Our proposal is to create veteran owned urban farms, primarily aeroponic, to create middle income jobs and small business ownership opprotunities . We want to provide an outlet for our veterans to use the skills that they have acquired in the military and polished in college. The licensing is the first step. 

  • We have raised and have had offers for donations to the nonprofit upon its formation. However, we cannot currently accept these donations because we cannot pay for our licensing. (ironic)
  • We have a real opportunity to make a difference in our community, and we plan on replicating this model all over the country. Our members know what it is like to struggle, and many of us still are. We think that we can be the change, and have been working very hard to do so. Please give us a chance to do so!
  • The farms will help veterans by providing a livable wage for its employees, scholarships for veterans attending college, and locally grown, high quality produce.   

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Join us on facebook at https://www.facebook.com/ACEVETERANS and like us.  
  • We always need help, and if you live in the south west Florida area, we would welcome any help you can offer. look on our facebook page for updates on meetings
  • Pay it forward, help each other, and make a difference in someones life.   
  • KCCO

story:
Tu B'Shevat - the Israeli Tree Planting Festival

In the Jewish tradition, the 15th day of the Hebrew month of Shevat is considered the "New Year of the Trees". The kabbalistic rabbis of Tzafat marked this occasion with a special feast, throughout which blessings would be pronounced over all the fruits of the the land of Israel. In modern Israeli culture, this date has taken the shape of a tree planting holiday - a patriotic festival aimed at renewing the green landscape of our beloved homeland that had lain barren for nearly 2000 years, throughout the exile of the loving sons of the land, the Jewish people. In the early years of modern Zionism, the blue and white box of the Jewish National Fund became a symbol and a tool for the Jews of the diaspora to take part in the mitzvah of planting forests throughout the land of Israel.


The years of hard work have resulted in beautiful forests in many locations in Israel from north to south. In many locations, camping, hiking and picnicking among the trees are enjoyed by the citizens of Israel and visitors on vacations and holidays.


Three years ago, in the beginning of December 2010, a terrific forest fire devoured 25,000 dunams of Mount Carmel forest in northern Israel, which not only left the mountain barren again, but also claimed the lives of 44 Israelis.


In the beginning of December this year, Israel experienced the worst snow storm that it has seen in the past 150 years. For four days, the mountainous regions of Shomron and Yehuda, as well as Jerusalem, were covered in a heavy layer of snow. Roads were closed, tens of thousands of Israelis were cut off from electricity and phone lines, and many were even without water.


Now, some two weeks later, as the last of the snow is melting away, the damages are becoming apparent. Municipal work forces are still struggling to repair these damages, as are farmers and home owners. It seems that there is not a single tree that was not broken under the weight of the snow. Piles of broken branches are seen on the sides of the roads in every town on the mountain ridge. In the orchards, fruit trees have collapsed. It is a sad picture.


Shlomo said in Kohelet that there is a time to plant. That time is now.


I plan to plant new orchards and refurbish the ruined ones that can be salvaged.


Funding is needed to make this happen, and this is an opportunity for good people - wherever they might be - to pitch in and be part of the Zionist project of reviving the landscape of the land of Israel again.


I call on you to be a part of this.


The plan is to plant new sections of fruit orchards. Each dunam (1000 sq/m) will cost a total of $2650. A breakdown of this cost is below.


60 fruit trees - $850

Bulldozer for clearing land - $950

150 meter fence with 2 meter high reinforced fencing posts - $900

Drip irrigation system - $950

story:
Want to help make renewable energy projects happen in your community, but don't know where to start? Not sure how to use your limited free time to make a positive environmental impact on your community? NRDC wants to help.

NRDC is building a new generation of organizing tools to help like-minded parents and students make renewable energy projects happen in their community.  Using best practices from recent political campaigns, NRDC is building a social organizing platform to help parents and students connect, organize and win approval of school renewable energy projects.

It’s a fun and empowering project and we hope you will join us!

THE CHALLENGE

Even as an increasing number of schools nationwide are adopting solar, many schools and communities still struggle to figure out how they can jump-start solar development on their campus.

While solar projects can provide many benefits to schools, they require time and effort to evaluate, approve, and manage. While many school administrators have an interest in going solar, they do not always have the time or resources to explore solar development.

Something is needed to help organize enthusiastic community members who are interested in exploring solar development on their local school, and to expand the people-hours and resources available to school administrators to forward solar project exploration and development. That's where the Solar Schools platform comes in.

THE SOLAR SCHOOLS PLATFORM

The Solar Schools platform will help parents and students connect and organize themselves around development of specific solar projects that increase renewable energy infrastructure in their community. We are building a bridge that connects local enthusiasm for renewable energy with the experts and resources they need to build the communities they desire.

A dynamic social organizing tool ...

An interactive, step-by-step guide ...

A personal dashboard ...

A forum for Q&A with experts and peers ...

PILOT PROJECTS

We aim to launch the alpha phase of a pilot program in the first 3-5 school communities as early as January 2014 and to roll out the beta to qualifying communities 6-12 weeks later.

Through pilot projects, we hope to prove that our new social organizing tool and dynamic guide will help communities:

  • Build their solar volunteer teams quickly through friend-to-friend connections.

  • Organize and track project momentum by creating a "hub" and guide for activism.

  • Empower more parents, students and teachers as leaders - creating more project "ownership" opportunities and higher levels of volunteer engagement.

For school communities participating in the alpha phase, we will provide organizational training and ongoing support in addition to the online platform. Throughout this phase, we will be testing and refining our organizer training and tools. With your help, we can develop the country's most effective platform for bringing clean solar energy to our classrooms ... and equally as important, spark the interest of many young minds in science, technology, engineering and math.

Many thanks!

The Solar Schools Team

PARTNERING ORGANIZATIONS

There are many stellar organizations helping communities bring solar to schools and we are are excited to connect them with the schools that need their help. Their expertise, matched with the enthusiasm of communities across the country, is a driving force behind Solar Schools.

THE SOLAR SCHOOLS TEAM

We didn't have many solar schools when we were growing up, but we're out to fix that for present and future generations.

Nathanael Greene directs NRDC’s work on renewable energy, which advocates for more wind, solar and other forms of energy that will never run out—and helps ensure that those clean energy projects are built where they’ll have the least impact on our wildlife and wild places. He's the father of two beautiful girls, a happy husband and a native New Yorker.

Jay Orfield helps NRDC develop innovative financing and deployment strategies for energy efficiency and renewable energy. Jay is a civil engineer with expertise in real estate development and financing, and explores opportunities at NRDC for environmental innovation. With Southern roots, he believes there is a conservationist inside of every American, and he's committed to creating opportunities for them to show it.

Rob Friedman runs NRDC’s youth engagement work, bridging the gap between policy campaigns and young people on issues like climate change, extreme energy extraction and renewables. Much of what he's learned about environmental campaigning has come through his experience exploring this planet we all call home, from Patagonia, Chile to the Catskill Mountains of New York.

Paul Davis helps NRDC incubate and promote innovative solutions aimed at accelerating the adoption of sustainable urban infrastructure. Over the years, his work as a community organizer and environmental educator has taken him from southwest Missouri to Cochabamba, Bolivia—and proven to him time and again that there is no work more rewarding than organizing communities around investments in their future.

JOIN THE SOLAR SCHOOLS MOVEMENT

Note: each perk includes a "vote" for your preferred pilot project location.

story:
Hey, I'm Carter

I'm an environmentally-friendly almost-vegetarian and I love the Michigan outdoors. I would love to make an impact on my little corner of Southeast MI--with your help! Let me tell you a bit about myself first:

  • I'm a rain garden enthusiast
  • ^ Rain gardens collect and filter stormwater runoff
  • ^^ Stormwater runoff pollution is what you get after a rain or snow melt event; it takes all the trash, feces, fertilizers, etc. and slugs it into a sewer, where it drains into our precious waterways
  • I want to learn how to better create natural landscapes that improve water quality and give others a sense of connectivity with the environment and their community
  • I would love to learn how to grow fruits and vegetables more efficiently to become more self-sustaining and environmentally-friendly

Basically, I like clean water and home-grown vegetables. If you like those things too, you should help me learn how to be better at it!

Michigan needs people like me

Michigan a land of watersheds, streams, rivers, and obviously lakes! That's why it's so absolutely important for Michiganders like myself to be good stewards of the environment and practice conscious, sustainable landscaping for water quality and self-sustainability.

  • If I can raise $300.00, I can pay for my Master Gardener training
  • If I raise additional funds (an extra $200.00), I can put it to good use by working with other motivated individuals in my community--and I know quite a few!--to make a positive difference
  • ^ Specifically, I would love to use any additional funding to create a rain garden somewhere in my city for others to enjoy its beauty, and learn why they should plant a rain garden too

Why donate?

Ever since I interned with a national non-profit in 2012 (an organization that focused specifically on water quality) I've learned a great deal about how and why Michigan's waterways become unhealthy.

  • Becoming a Master Gardener will give me the knowledge and experience to get environmental projects done in harmony with the environment
  • ^ It will take time, but once I "master gardening," I can teach others in the community about it too
  • ^^ I'm a people-person and was actually voted "Most Helpful" in my Senior year of high school. I want to help others take care of themselves and the waterways they rely upon

No money to donate?

I get it. I'm impoverished too, that's why I'm asking for help! But you can do your part for Michigan--or wherever you live--by taking some small, simple steps to care for your little corner of planet Earth.

  • Grow your own tomatoes and such (saves $$$, is delicious)
  • Compost scraps in your backyard (just make sure the squirrels can't get to it)
  • Volunteer with a local environmental group (they make fantastic friends!)
  • Share this campaign with others to help me raise a few bucks!

Maybe you're a friend of mine, or maybe you're my family. Perhaps you're a stranger and you're not quite sure how you clicked this link in first place, but here you are, reading my plea for money and education. No matter who you are, please know that your help is appreciated more than I know how to say--and I'm pretty wordy! Not only will your donation help me achieve a personal dream, but you're helping me help others. I will one day teach people everything and anything I can to help them be good stewards of the environment, even if it's just in their own backyard. I care about the environment, the state of our water supply, the land I live upon, and my fellow man. Help me, and you help many more.

"I am I plus my surroundings; and if I do not preserve the latter, I do not preserve myself." -- José Ortega y Gasset

story:
The Problem:
Americans throw away 40% of their food, most of which which ends up in landfills where it takes up space and releases greenhouse gases.
 
The  Solution:
 collects the food waste from restaurants, schools, and food courts and uses proven technology to turn it into organic fertilizer and renewable energy that are then delivered right back into the community.

 

We specialize in developing local, community based recycling facilities that turn organic waste into renewabele energy and all-natural fertilizer for sustainable farming.

 

Although the digesters are relatively affordable, the environmental permits are not. 

And thus your contributions will go towards air, solid waste, and waste water permits granted only after an arduous review process performed by local, state and federal environmental resources departments.

Though expensive, these permits are necessary for enforcing judicious rules that ensure natural, public resources are not being exploited and ill-managed.

Below is a breakdown of costs for our first launch in the Washington, DC area.

  • Partnering with local organic waste producers (restaurants, hotels, caterers, landscapers, farmers, etc.) to help them properly sort their discarded food and clippings for environmentally safe recycling.
  • Enlisting organic waste food haulers to ensure the safe transportation of any organic food waste collected within each community.
  • Recycling this organic material to remove contaminants and extract both renewable energy and compost for continued use.  Odorless, localized, and 100% green, this anaerobic digestion period takes 18-22 days.
  • Distributing the newly created organic fertilizer to local farmers who are committed to sustainable agriculture.  And sending our renewable energy to utility companies interested in incorporating greener power sources into their portfolios.


Every $1 that you contribute moves us closer to this goal. 

If you share our vision of a cleaner world with healthier food, less waste, and greener energy, consider donating to our campaign and sharing  with all your friends.


But first a little background on why we launched in the first place.

  • As a species, we destroy precious ecosystems to extract fossil fuel (oil, gas, and coal) for our cities and highways.  This constant deforestation and energy consumption carries a terrible cost for the planet.
  • A portion of this fossil fuel goes to agribusinesses that create synthetic pesticides and petro-fertilizers.  Not only does this further harm the planet, but it also makes the food we eat incredibly unhealthy.

  • However, we don’t even eat all of this unhealthy food.  33% of all the crops grown worldwide (1.3 billion tons) never makes it to our bellies.  Instead, it gets sent to landfills to rot and produce greenhouse gases.

No part of this system is sustainable. 

It is a linear model of waste that offers nothing but disadvantages at every stag

What are the benefits of contribution to 

 

Well, in addition to healthier food, less waste, reduced reliance on fossil fuel, cleaner air, and a greener planet, you also receive:

story:
We are almost 1/2 way to our financial goal! Make a donation to get us all the way.

Thank you to Whole Foods Market Naperville for granting us their 5% Community Giving Day on September 17th. We raised $5,149!

Thank you to our community for donating $1,380!

Short Summary

We are building a demonstration edible forest garden to inspire property owners to replace their lawns with perennial food systems at their homes, schools, churches, places of work, and municipalities.

WHO?!


We are The Resiliency Institute, an educational nonprofit started in 2013 dedicated to teaching people in the suburbs about permaculture. We are a 501(c)(3) organization so your donations may be tax deductible.

WHERE?!

In the suburbs of Chicago for now—but hopefully everyone will be inspired to do this in their own city or town!

WHAT?!

“Perma—what?!?!” you say?

PERMACULTURE is “a philosophy of working with, rather than against nature; of protracted and thoughtful observation rather than protracted and thoughtless labor; and of looking at plants and animals in all their functions, rather than treating any area as a single product system." - Bill Mollison, co-founder of permaculture.

PERMANENT + CULTURE = PERMACULTURE

We are using this philosophy to help create sustainable systems for daily living, land and community.

Our goal is to put underutilized suburban land into production growing local, organic, nutrient dense food and to teach people the skills to harvest, prepare, preserve, and share the abundance.

What We Need & What You Get

To create a truly beautiful and INSPIRATIONAL place that will make everyone who visits want to grow an edible forest garden of their own, we need:

1)  PLANTS- LOTS AND LOTS OF PLANTS! $5,000 

2)  Educational materials: $6,500

Signage & Brochures—we need to educate visitors about what they are seeing.  This project will be part of the self guided sustainability tour on the Conservation Foundation property.  There is not always staffing available to give tours so we need to make sure that the information on how and why visitors can incorporate perennial edible landscaping into their own properties is provided.  We will also need materials to promote the project at outreach events we attend and to landowners that we visit or who contact us.

3)  Hardscaping Materials: $2,200

  • A drainage line to connect CSA wastewater directly into our system

  • An aesthetically pleasing materials depot to store compost, mulch, rocks, and other materials

  • Seating

  • Arbors and trellis

  • Bridges

We are using our AMAZING community of volunteers to help with installation and maintenance.

4-7% goes to Indiegogo and credit card fees, some to materials and postage for perks,  and anything else will be used to purchase plants & materials.  Any funds beyond our goal will be used toward programming and materials for future food forest installations.

The Impact

WHY?!

Replacing underutilized land with edible food forests will grow a local food system where everyone has access to local, healthy, organic, nutrient dense fruits, vegetables, nuts and herbs. People will experience the taste of fresh picked produce and reconnect with where food comes from. A scarcity mindset will be replaced with one of abundance and sharing.

THE NEED:

  • In our suburban area there are over 84,000 (regionally 300,000)  people who are food insecure. They do not know how they will pay for their next meal.

  • Our local food pantry has experienced a 780% increase in need since 2008.

  • 1,000’s of people living in food deserts don’t have access to local, organic, nutrient dense food.

  • There is a national health crisis of obesity, diabetes, and heart disease caused by poor diets based on easily accessible, cheap, low nutritionally valued, processed food.

THE RESOURCES:

There are over 9,000 potential food producing acres available in our county and tens of thousands of acres regionally. Using this land to grow food forests can provide nourishing food for food insecure families and the greater suburban populations while regenerating soil and increasing biodiversity.

  • According to a NASA study, there are approximately 30 MILLION acres of LAWN in the US—that is the size of OHIO, making it the 4th largest UNPRODUCTIVE monoculture in our country.

  • Mowed lawns degrade ecosystems because they cannot support the diversity of life needed for healthy, resilient ecosystems.  The only thing supported by mowed turf grass is Canadian Geese.

  • Mowed lawns degrade and destroy soil when fertilizers and pesticides are used.  This kills soil organisms needed to support healthy plant life, and perpetuates a continuous cycle of nutrient depletion, disease, and artificial fertilization.

  • Mowed lawns use exorbitant amounts of resources, especially WATER—usually potable.

  • Mowed lawns are the cause of over 5% of air pollution (US EPA), and the emissions of one gas mower are equivalent to eight vehicles. (Union of Concerned Scientists)

  •  Illinois is the number one contributor of phosphorous and nitrogen (lawn fertilizer) to the "dead zone" in the Gulf of Mexico. (Sierra Club)

  • Gardeners spill more fuel  every year than the Exxon Valdez (US EPA)

THE SOLUTION:

EDIBLE FOREST GARDENS - at the smaller residential scale - and FOOD FORESTS -at the larger community scale - are perennial based food production systems which, by design:
  1. Grow local, organic, nutrient dense food, creating abundance and food security
  2. Create vibrant community gathering spaces that encourage interaction, recreation, community building and sharing
  3. Restore bio-diverse, resilient ecosystems
  4. Build soil
  5. Conserve natural resources
  6. Reduce pollution by reducing the need for fossil fuels for fertilizers, pesticides, food processing and transportation
  7. Sequester carbon to help fight global warming

Other Ways You Can Help:

SHARE this campaign with EVERYONE you know!

VOLUNTEER!  Donate your time helping us with installation and implementation.  Sign up on our website: http://www.theresiliencyinstitute.net/get_involved/volunteer/

DONATE PLANTS, materials, or services directly to us.  Contact us through our website to make arrangements:  http://www.theresiliencyinstitute.net/get_involved/donate/

If you can’t directly support us—SUPPORT OR CREATE A FOOD FOREST NEAR YOU—they are popping up everywhere!


Risks & Challenges

This project WILL be completed!  The amount of funding we receive will determine the amount of time it will take to complete the project.


  • Thank you to all of our amazing volunteers who dedicated many laboring hours preparing the edible forest garden site
  • Thank you to the businesses and individuals who donated money, services and materials
  • Thank you to The Conservation Foundation for supporting us and giving us the land for the edible forest garden
  • Thank you to Andrew Van Gorp for is fun, energetic spirit that inspired the script for the IndieGoGo video and his amazing filming and editing talents!
  • Thank you to Karen Vanek for her many hours of time and talents working on this and other projects, growing the organization, and recruiting volunteers.
  • Thank you to all of our instructors, students, and community supporters for working with us to realize our mission
  • Thank YOU for making a donation today!
story_txt:
We are almost 1/2 way to our financial goal! Make a donation to get us all the way.

Thank you to Whole Foods Market Naperville for granting us their 5% Community Giving Day on September 17th. We raised $5,149!
Thank you to our community for donating $1,380!
Short Summary 

We are building a demonstration edible forest garden to inspire property owners to replace their lawns with perennial food systems at their homes, schools, churches, places of work, and municipalities. 

WHO?!






We are The Resiliency Institute, an educational nonprofit started in 2013 dedicated to teaching people in the suburbs about permaculture. We are a 501(c)(3) organization so your donations may be tax deductible. 
WHERE?!
In the suburbs of Chicago for now—but hopefully everyone will be inspired to do this in their own city or town!
WHAT?!
 “Perma—what?!?!” you say?
PERMACULTURE is “a philosophy of working with, rather than against nature; of protracted and thoughtful observation rather than protracted and thoughtless labor; and of looking at plants and animals in all their functions, rather than treating any area as a single product system." - Bill Mollison, co-founder of permaculture.
PERMANENT + CULTURE = PERMACULTURE
We are using this philosophy to help create sustainable systems for daily living, land and community. 




Our goal is to put underutilized suburban land into production growing local, organic, nutrient dense food and to teach people the skills to harvest, prepare, preserve, and share the abundance.
   What We Need & What You Get To create a truly beautiful and INSPIRATIONAL place that will make everyone who visits want to grow an edible forest garden of their own, we need:
1)  PLANTS- LOTS AND LOTS OF PLANTS! $5,000  


2)  Educational materials: $6,500
Signage & Brochures—we need to educate visitors about what they are seeing.  This project will be part of the self guided sustainability tour on the Conservation Foundation property.  There is not always staffing available to give tours so we need to make sure that the information on how and why visitors can incorporate perennial edible landscaping into their own properties is provided.  We will also need materials to promote the project at outreach events we attend and to landowners that we visit or who contact us.
3)  Hardscaping Materials: $2,200

A drainage line to connect CSA wastewater directly into our system
An aesthetically pleasing materials depot to store compost, mulch, rocks, and other materials
Seating
Arbors and trellis
Bridges



We are using our AMAZING community of volunteers to help with installation and maintenance.
4-7% goes to Indiegogo and credit card fees, some to materials and postage for perks,  and anything else will be used to purchase plants & materials.  Any funds beyond our goal will be used toward programming and materials for future food forest installations.

The Impact

 
WHY?!

Replacing underutilized land with edible food forests will grow a local food system where everyone has access to local, healthy, organic, nutrient dense fruits, vegetables, nuts and herbs. People will experience the taste of fresh picked produce and reconnect with where food comes from. A scarcity mindset will be replaced with one of abundance and sharing.THE NEED:

In our suburban area there are over 84,000 (regionally 300,000)  people who are food insecure. They do not know how they will pay for their next meal.
Our local food pantry has experienced a 780% increase in need since 2008.
1,000’s of people living in food deserts don’t have access to local, organic, nutrient dense food.
There is a national health crisis of obesity, diabetes, and heart disease caused by poor diets based on easily accessible, cheap, low nutritionally valued, processed food.

THE RESOURCES:There are over 9,000 potential food producing acres available in our county and tens of thousands of acres regionally. Using this land to grow food forests can provide nourishing food for food insecure families and the greater suburban populations while regenerating soil and increasing biodiversity.
According to a NASA study, there are approximately 30 MILLION acres of LAWN in the US—that is the size of OHIO, making it the 4th largest UNPRODUCTIVE monoculture in our country.
Mowed lawns degrade ecosystems because they cannot support the diversity of life needed for healthy, resilient ecosystems.  The only thing supported by mowed turf grass is Canadian Geese.
Mowed lawns degrade and destroy soil when fertilizers and pesticides are used.  This kills soil organisms needed to support healthy plant life, and perpetuates a continuous cycle of nutrient depletion, disease, and artificial fertilization.
Mowed lawns use exorbitant amounts of resources, especially WATER—usually potable. 
Mowed lawns are the cause of over 5% of air pollution (US EPA), and the emissions of one gas mower are equivalent to eight vehicles. (Union of Concerned Scientists)
 Illinois is the number one contributor of phosphorous and nitrogen (lawn fertilizer) to the "dead zone" in the Gulf of Mexico. (Sierra Club)


Gardeners spill more fuel  every year than the Exxon Valdez (US EPA)

THE SOLUTION:



EDIBLE FOREST GARDENS - at the smaller residential scale - and FOOD FORESTS -at the larger community scale - are perennial based food production systems which, by design:

Grow local, organic, nutrient dense food, creating abundance and food security

Create vibrant community gathering spaces that encourage interaction, recreation, community building and sharing


Restore bio-diverse, resilient ecosystems


Build soil

Conserve natural resources

Reduce pollution by reducing the need for fossil fuels for fertilizers, pesticides, food processing and transportation 


Sequester carbon to help fight global warming



  Other Ways You Can Help:


SHARE this campaign with EVERYONE you know!
